div.p: LOVES EMPIRE; Or, The AMOURS Of the FRENCH COURT.
LONDON, Printed for Dorman Newman at the Kings Arms in the Poultry. 1682.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE THE EARL OF THANET, &c.
div.p:
THE preent Times being petered with nothing but Narrative and Narrative,
Evidence upon Evidence; one to trengthen, and another to invalidate the Truth of a Plot: The Papits Libelling the Presbyterians, and the Presbyterians zealouly Anwering them, and both diturbing the Publick Peace: Inomuch that Mr. Stationer hath now nothing to Entertain his Cutomer with but ome rare Pamphlet, which he is ready to commend as excellently penned, and learnedly handled. St. Autin's City of God, The Practice of Piety, The Whole Duty of Man, &c. are grown even mouldy upon their Shelves; and none but the Adviing C—, and Intelligent V—, (the former furnihing us with News from the Pope,
and the latter with trange Stories of Things which never were) can merit their Favour, or be vouchaft an Acceptance: And therefore for me to intrude into his Shop, and deire a Place in his Claes, under the Notion of a Lover; is look't upon as the Superlative Degree of Boldnes and Impudence, and I am immediately commanded to Retire; or if I perit Intreating, I am thrut out of Doors, and called an Idle Fellow, a To • y, an Enemy to the Good Old Caue, and I know not what. Forgetting that Love ought at this time epecially, to have the greatet Empire in Mens Hearts, to nite the Dientingly Reformed to the Truly Reformed Opinion; and thus like
Ephraim and Manaeh, both would agree againt Judah (the Papits).

p.hi: And now, my Lord, being likely to be kept in Silence and Obcurity, and uncapable to appear abroad without a PROTECTION, I made bold to enter into your Lordhips Preence, and cating my elf at your Feet, humbly implore your Honourable Patronage.

div.p:
Your Lordhip will perchance be apt to ask me if this be a Time to talk of Love; To which I believe I need not tudy for an Anwer, when the high Station your Lordhip has in the World, gives you the affrighting Propect how little room Love takes up now among Men; Nay, 'tis almot forgot, and
therefore to give them this Memento of it, will not altogether be ineaonable.

My Lord, the Stage whereon Our Gallants acted their everal Parts was France, and having met with a General Acceptance and Favour in their French, I ventured to Equipp them in our Englih Garb. I hope they may give your Lordhip ome agreable Diverion, when your vacant Hours from more erious Affairs hall permit you.

p.hi: Your Lordhips Favour and Incouragement is the ole Azyle to which I hall have Recoure, with which if I am honoured, I hall not value the evere Scrutinies of of the nice Critick, nor the Opprobrious
Cenure of the Sedate Phanatick, whilt I think it my Duty to write my elf,

closer.signed: Your Lordhips mot humble and devoted Servant, R. H.

div.head: Loves Empire; Or, The GALLANTRIES Of the FRENCH COURT.
div.p:
NOtwithtanding that in the Reign of Lewis the Fourteenth the War had continued above Twenty years, yet it did not hinder Love from cauing ome Amourous Intrigues; but as the Court was only filled
with old inenible Gentlemen, and young Sparks bred up in Armies, and whom that Profeion had rendred Brutal, mot of the Ladies were become les modet than formerly; and eeing they hould have languihed in Idlenes if they had not made Advances, or at leat if they had been Cruel, a great many grew tender hearted, and ome very Confident.

Of this lat Tribe was Madam d' Olonne: She had a round Face, a pretty Noe, a little Mouth, fine parkling Eyes, and delicate Features, yet miling, which embelihes mot people, had in her a quite contrary effect; her Hair was a bright brown, her Complexion admirable, her Neck, Hands and Arms were well made, her hape was not to be commended, nor would he have been thought Charming had it not been for her Face: This much her Flatterers ay, That when he firt appeared at Court he had a handome Body; which is the uual plea of thoe who would excue Women who are too Corpulent. However this Lady was too incere in this cae to leave people in an Errour, for every one that had a mind might be informed of the contrary, and it was not her fault he did not undeceive all the World.

Madam d' Olonne had a quick and pleaant Wit when he was free; yet he was omething fale, incontant, bold, malicious, loved pleaures even to Debauch; and there was exces in her leat Divertiements: Her Beauty rather than her Etate, which was but mall, obliged the Count d' Olonne to endeavour the making her his Wife: Which he quickly effected, for being a Peron of Quality, and having a great Etate, he was agreeably received by Madam de la Louppe her Mother, and had not the leiure to igh for Charms which for two years had inflamed the deires of all the Court: This Match being conummated, thoe Lovers withdrew who pretended to Marriage, and others came who only aimed at being beloved. One of the firt who offered himelf was Beuvron, whom the Neighbourhood of Madam d' Olonne gave the more conveniency of eeing; and by this means loved her a pretty while without being dicovered; and I fancy this Amour would have till been concealed, if Beuvron had never had Rivals: But the Duke of Candale being fallen in love with Madam d' Olonne, quickly perceived what had thitherto remained concealed for want of intereed People: Not but that d' Olonne
loved his Wife extreamly, but Husbands are tupid, and o are never Lovers, and the jealouie of thee is much more piercing than that of the others: So that the Duke of Candale aw things that d' Olonne did not, and never has een, for he is till ignorant that Beuvron has had an Intrigue with his Wife.

Beuvron had black Eys, a handom Noe, a little Mouth, a long Face, very black long and thick Hair, a fine Shape, and Wit enough; He was not one of thoe who talk all in Company, but was a Man of good ene and honour, tho he had naturally an averion for War, o that being fallen in love with Madam d' Olonne, he ought for an opportunity to dicover to her his Paion: Their Neighbourhood at Paris gave him occaions enough, but her Incontancy made him apprehend an Intrigue with her: At length happening one day to meet with her without other Company, If I only deigned, Madam, aid he to her, to let you know that I love you, words would be altogether unneceary, my cares and my looks have told you ufficiently what effect your Charms have had upon me; But, Madam, as I expect you hould one day make returns to my flames, it is requiite that I dicover 'em, and aure you
at the ame time, that whether you love me or not, I am reolved to be your Votary as long as I live.

Beuvron having ceaed peaking, Sir, anwered Madam d' Olonne, This is not the firt time I perceived you loved me, and tho you did not acquaint me with it, I did not fail to think my elf obliged to you for all you have done for me ince the firt moment you aw me, and this ought to be my Excue when I confes I love you: Therefore do not eteem me the les, having long undertood your ighs, and tho I hould be omething blamed for my little reitance, it would be a mark of the force of your merit rather than of my eaines. It is eaie to imagine that after this Confeion it was not long before the Lady delivered up her Fort to her Gallant: This Intrigue lated four or five Months without diturbance to either Party, but at length the Beauty of Madam d' Olonne was too much talked of, and that Conquet promied too much Glory in appearance to him who hould make it, for Beuvron to be at ret. The Duke of Candale, who was the handomet man of the Court, fancied that nothing was wanting to his Reputation, but the being beloved by the mot beautiful Woman of the Kingdom: Wherefore he took a Reolution
at the Army, three Months after the Campaigne, to be in love with her aoon he hould ee her; and made appear by a great Paion he had afterwards for her, that Love is not always the work of Heaven and of Fortune.

The Duke of Candale had blew Eyes, a handome Noe, irregular Features, a great and diagreeable Mouth, but very fine Teeth, light yellowih Hair both long and thick, his Shape was admirable, and he dreed o well, that the greatet Sparks endeavoured to imitate him; he had the air of a Peron of great Quality, he held one of the firt Ranks in France, was Duke and Peer, Governour of Burgundy joyntly with his Father, and ole Governour of Auvergne, and Colonel General of the French Infantry: His Genius was mean, but in his firt Amours falling into the hands of a Lady who had an infinite deal of Wit, and as they had loved one another extreamly, he had taken o much care to polih him, and he to pleae that fair One, that Art had urpaed Nature, and he was a much better bred man than a thouand others who have more ene than he.

Inomuch that being returned from Catalonia, where he had commanded the Army under the Prince of Conty, he begun by a thouand eagernees to acquaint Madam d' Olonne with the love he had for her, thinking he had never had an Amourous Intrigue: But eeing he made no returns to his Paion, he reolved to acquaint her with it after uch a manner as that he might not eem to be ignorant of it; but as he had a kind of bahful repect for all Women, he choe rather to write than peak to Madam d' Olonne, and his Letter was in thee terms.

body.p:
I Am grieved, Madam, that all Delarations of Love are alike, and that there is ometimes o much differences in Sentiments. I am very enible that I love you more than all the World is ued to love, and yet I cannot expres it otherwie then is done by all the World: Wherefore do not take notice of my words that are weak, and may be deceitful, but be pleaed to make reflexion on my Conduct towards you, and if you find that to continue it with the ame force, I must needs be deeply struck; yield to thee tetimonies and be aured, that ince I love you o much, not being beloved by you, I hall adore you, when
you oblige me to have acknowledgment.

div.p: Madam d' Olonne having read this Letter, made this Anwer:

p.hi: IF any thing hinders you from being believed when you talk of Love, it is not that it is importunate, but that you tell it too well: Great Paions are uually more diordered, and me thinks you write like a very witty Man, who is not in love, but would fain be thought o; and ince it eems o to me, who am infinitely deirous that what you ay were true, judge what People would imagine to whom your Paion hould be indifferent, they would preently think you had a mind to railly; For my part, I'le never make a rah judgment, but will accept the Offer you make me, and am willing to judge by your Conduct of the Sentiments you have for me.

div.p:
This Letter which grateful People would have thought very kind, did not eem o to the Duke of Candale; As he was very vain, he had expected les intricate Favours: and this obliged him not to pres Madam d' Olonne o much as he was willing he hould have done, and made her a hard task in pight of her elf; and the thing had lated a
long time, if the Fair One had not gained upon her Modety to make him o many advances, that he fancyed he might make an attack without being expoed to a Repule. The buines being done, he quickly perceived Beuvron's Commerce. Uually a Pretender looks only before him, but a Lover well treated, looks on the right and on the left, and is not long without dicovering his Rival: Hereupon the Duke complaines; His Mitres calls him Caprichious and Tyrant, and takes him up o roundly, that he aks her pardon for his upicions, and fancies himelf too happy in having appeaed her. This Calm did not long continue, Beuvron for his part reproached her to as little purpoe as the Duke did, and eeing he could not detroy his Rival himelf, he caued notice to be given under hand to Olonne that his Wife entertained the Duke of Candale for her Galant. D' Olonne forbids her to ee him, that is to ay, redoubled the Paion of thoe two Lovers, who having the more deire to ee one another ince it was forbidden, found a thouand more convenient oppurtunities than thoe they had before; However Beuvron remaining Mater of the field of Battails, the Duke of Candale renewed, his Complaints againt him,
and ued all his endeavours to have him Cahiered, but all to no purpoe; Madam d' Olonne told him that he perceived he only conidered his own Interet, and that he cared not if he ruined her, ince that if he hould forbid Beuvron to ee her, her husband and all the world would not doubt but that he made that acrifice to him; Madam d' Olonne did not love Beuvron o much as he did the Duke, yet he was not willing however to loe him, and as well becaue One and One make Two, as that becaue Cocquetts fancy they can retaine their Galants better by a little Jealouy than a great Tranquility.

In the mean time Paget a man pretty well tricken in years, meanly born, but very rich, fell in love with Madam d' Olonne, and having dicovered that he loved the port, he fancyed that his Money would erve him intead of Merit; and founded his greatet hopes upon the um he reolved to offer her; He had acces enough to her houe to have poke to her himelf, if he had durt; but he had not the boldnes to begin a dicoure, which might be of ill conequence if it was not kindly received, o that he thought the bet coure would be to write to her, which he did in thee termes.

body.p: I Have often in my life been in Law, Madam, but I never loved any thing o much as I do you: and what makes me think o is, that I never gaveth any of my Mitrees above an hundred broad Pieces to purchae the Fruition of them; but to enjoy you I am willing to exceed to two Thouand: Think of it I beeech you, Madam, and be mindful that Mony was never o carce as it is at preent.

div.p: Quentine, Madam d' Olonne's Waitingwoman and Confident, delivered her this Letter from Paget; and immediately after this Faire One made him he Anwer that follows.

body.p: I Had already perceived you had a great deal of Wit by the converation I had with you; but I knew not that you could write o well as you do; I never aw any thing o pretty as your Letter, I hould be overioyed if I might but receive often uch, and in the mean time hall be very glad to dicoure you this Evening at ix a Clock.

div.p:
Paget did not fail to be at the Aignation, and went thither in a Habit, that is to ay, with his Bag and the appurtenances. Quintine having introduced him into her Mitries
Cloet, left them together: See here, Madam, aid he to her, hewing what he brought, this is what is not daily met with: will you receive it? I am willing, aid Madam d' Olonne, and it will help to amue us. Whereupon having counted the two Thouand broad Pieces they had agreed for, he hut them up in a little Trunk, and placing her elf by them upon a little Couch, which did not lat her long, Sir, aid he to him, there is not a Man in France wrights like you; what I am going to ay, is not to hew my elf a Critick, but it is certain that I find but few people that have o much Wit as you have. Mot men entertain us only with Fopperies, and when they would write to us kind Letters, they think they have done Miracles in telling us that they adore us, that they hall dye if we do not Love them, and that if we will be o gracious to them, they will erve us as long as they live: we have much need indeed of their Services. I am overioyed, aid Paget, that my Letters pleae you; I hould not ay this elewhere, but to you, Madam, I hall not mince the matter, my Letters cot me nothing. This is hard to be beleived, anwered he, you mut then have a very great Stock. After ome other Dicoures, which Love interrupted two or thre times, they agreed of an other Interview, and at that of another: Inomuch
that thoe two thouand Broad Pieces procured Paget three Aignations.

But Madam d' Olonne being willing to make advantage of the Love of this Citizen, and of his Riches, deired him at the fourth Viit to begin again to write to her uch Letters of Gallantry as that he had received from him: But he eeing that this would come to be of Conequence, he fell to reproaching her, which did him no good; and all that he could obtain was, that he hould not be drove from her Houe, and that he might come and play when he hould end for him.

Madam d' Olonne fancied that by letting Paget ee her, he hould inflame his deires, and that perhaps he would be again o imple as to atisfie them at any rate; but tho he was o much in love as not to be able to forbear eeing her, yet he was not charmed to the degree of buying her Favours daily.

Things being in thee terms, whether pight made Paget blab, or that his frequent Viits and the Money that Madam d' Olonne had played away, caued the Duke of Candale to make reflexions, he deired his Mitres, when he departed for Catalonia, not to ee Paget any more, whoe Commerce
was injurious to her Reputation; which he promied him, but did not keep her word; Inomuch that the Duke being informed by thoe who ent him News from Paris, that Paget went oftner then ever to Madam d'Olonnes Houe, he wrote to her this Letter.

body.p: WHen I took my leave, I deired you, Madam, not to ee that Rogue Paget any more, and yet he is ever at your Elbow; are not you ahamed to give me reaon to be Jealous of a wretched Citizen, who could never be feared, were it not that you your elf did make him Confident? If you do not Bluh, Madam, I bluh for you and my elf, and for fear of meriting that Scandal you would heap upon me, I hall make an Effort upon my love to conider you only as an infamous Woman.

div.p: Madam d'Olonne was much urprized to receive o rude a Letter, but as her Concience reproached yet more harply then her Lover, he did not eek reaons for her excue, and contented herelf with anwering in thee termes.

body.p:
MY Conduct hitherto is o ridiculous, my Dear, that I hould depair of being
ever loved by you, if I could not redeem my Credit by the Aurances I give you of a more honet civil Carriage in the future; but I wear by you your elf, which is what I have mot dear in the world, that Paget hall never enter my Houe; and that Beuvron, whom my Husband forces me to ee, hall ee me o eldome, that you hall know, that you alone are in tead of all things to me.

div.p: The Duke of Candale was o fully aured by this Letter, that he reolved not to condemn his Mitris any more upon appearances, which he judged to be all deceitful. And for having been, as he thought, without reaon upicious, he fell into the other extremity of Confidence, and took in good part all the Cocquetry and Infidelity that Madam d'Olonne committed for ix Months together; for he continued to ee Paget, and to give Favours to Beuvron; and tho the Duke of Candale had notice given him of it from everal parts, he fancied that it proceeded from his Father or his Frinds, who were deirous to divert him from loving Madam d'Olonne, believing that this Paion would hinder him from thinking of Marrying.

So that he returned from the Army more in love than he had ever been; Madam d' Olonne likewie, with whom o long an abence made the Duke of Candale pase for a new Galant, redoubled her eagernes for him, even in the ight of all the Court; this Lover took the Imprudences he committed to ee him, for marks of a paion he was no longer Mitris of, tho they were only Tetimonies of the natural Irregularity of her reaon; when he did any Paionate act that made a Noie, he thought her deeply in love and yet he was only illy. And he was o perwaded of the kindnes he had for him, that tho he hould dye for her ake, he apprehended he hould be till ungrateful.

It is eay to imagine that the Carriage of thee Lovers made a great Noie; they had both of them Enemies; but the Fortune of the One and the Beauty of the Other made-a great many envy them: tho all the world would have erved them, they would have detroyed all by their Imprudence, and all the world would have done them hurt: They made Aignations every where, without having taken any meaures with any Body. They aw One another often in a houe, that the Duke of Candale kept in
the name of a Country Lady whom Madam d' Olonne pretended to viit mot commonly by night at her own Houe: all thee Rendevouzes did not take up all the time of this perfidious One, for when the Duke left her he went to the conquet of ome new Lover, or at leat to reaume Beuvron by a thouand kindnees for the fears the Duke gave him.

The Winter paed thus without the Duke of Candales upecting the leat ill in all he did, and he left her to return to the Army as well atisfied as he had ever been: he had not been there two Months but that he learnt news which troubled his joy: His particular friends who took trict notice of his Mitrees Conduct did not dare to ay any thing to him as long as they found him prepoeed by that faithles One; but omething very extraordinary having happened ince his abence, and not fearing a ight of her hould detroy the impreions they would give him, they altogether hazarded, without making appear any deign or concert, to acquaint him with her behaviour. Whereupon they each of them ingly ent him word that Ieannin was deeply engaged with Madam d' Olonne, that his
aiduities gave caue to believe, not only a deign, but a happy ucces; and in a word, that tho he were not culpable, he ought not to be atisfied with her, eeing he was upected by all People.
But while thee News are going to put the Duke of Candale in a rage, it is fit I hould peak of the birth, progres, and ends Jeannin's Paion.

Jeannin de Catille was well haped, had a pleaing Countenance, was very pruce, but had little Wit; his Quality and Profeion were the ame that Pagets, and was very rich as well as he. He was handome enough to have it believed that in cae he had worn a Sword, his Merit alone might have procured him the Ladies Favours, but his Profeion and his Riches made it upected, that all the Women he had had Intrigues with, were intereed, inomuch that when he was een to be in love with Madam d' Olonne, it was not doubted but that he would be beloved for his Money.

The King after having paed the Summers upon the Frontiers, uually returned to Paris in the Winters, and all the Divertiements of the World poeed his Mind by turns; Billiards, Tennis, Hunting, Plays, and Dancing had each their times
with him: At that time Lotteries were o much the mode, that every one had them; ome of Money, others of Jewels and Moveables. Madam d' Olonne reolved to have One of Money; but whereas in the mot part of them all the Cah was employed they had received, and that Fortune hared it, in this, which was of Ten thouand Crowns, there was not Five employed, and thoe Five too were ditributed according as Madam d' Olonne thought fit. Jeannin was preent when he made the firt Propoals of the Lottery, and as he asked a Sum of every one according to their Abilities, and that he told him he was to give an Hundred pound, he made Anwer, That he was willingly, and moreover promied her to procure amongt his Friends wherewith to make it up a Thouand. Preently after, all the Company being gone except Jeannin, I know not, Madam, aid he to her, whether you are yet acquainted with my Paion, for I have loved you a long time, and my ighs already mount to a very great um; but after having given my elf entirely to you, I mut needs ask the confirmation of my Bail, which I beeech you to ign, Madam; and oberve, that beides the Hundred pound you taxed me, I give you Nine hundred more for
the having your Affection; for what I aid of my Friends was only to deceive the People that were here when I poke to you of this Affair. I confes, Sir, anwered Madam d' Olonne, I never thought you in love till now, not but that I have oberved by certain Meenes in you, what made me upect ome things, but I am o diguted with thoe kind of ways, and ighs and languihings are in my mind o poor a Galantry, and uch feeble Tetimonies of love, that if you had not taken a more gentile Coure with me, you had lost your pains all your life time. Now as for Acknowledgment, you may believe that People are not far from loving, when we are well aured of being beloved: There need no more to make Jeannin believe that he was at the Critical Minute. He cat himelf at Madam d' Olonne's feet, and as he would have made ue of that Action of Humility for a pretext to higher Enterprizes, No, aid he, you are mitaken, Sir; In what Country have you heard ay that Women make Advances? When you hall have given me reall marks of a great Paion, I hall not be ungrateful. Jeannin, eeing that with her, Money was to be delivered before the Commodity, told her, That he had two Hundred broad Pieces, and that he would give them her if he
pleaed: She conented, and having received them; If you think fit, Madam, aid he to her, to grant me ome favour upon the account of this Money, you will extreamly oblige me; or if you will tay till you have received the whole Sum, give me a Note under your Hand of the value received. She choe rather to kis than write; and a Moment after Jeannin went away, auring her that he would bring the ret on the morrow, which he did not fail to do; and the Moment was no ooner counted, then that he kept her word with him with all the Honour that can be expected in uch a Treaty.

Tho Jeannin came in through the ame Door that Paget did, he ued him much better; whether he hoped to draw greater Advantages from him at length, or that he had ome concealed Merit that erved him intead of Liberality; he did not ask him new Proofs of Love for the giving him new Favours. The Thouand pounds made her love him three Months together, that is to ay, treated him as if he had loved him.
In the mean time the Duke of Candale having received Advice of his Mitrees new Intrigues, he wrote her this Letter.

body.p: THo you would jutifie your elf to me of all the things you are Accued of, I can no longer love you, tho all that is aid of you was done only out of Malice: All Lovers are uually overjoyed to hear their Mitrees named, as for me I tremble as oon as I hear or read your Name, I ever fancy in thee Occaions, that I hall learn ome Story wore, if poible, than the former: And yet I need not know more to have the utmot Contempt for you, you cannot add any thing to your Infamy; Wherefore expect all the Reentment that a a Woman without Honour deerves, from an honet Man that has loved her extreamly. I hall not come to particulars with you, becaue I do not eek for your Jutification, for you are Convicted in my Opinion, and I will never have more to do with you.

div.p:
The Duke of Candale wrote this Letter jut as he was upon returning to Court; he had newly lot a Battail, which did not a little contribute to the bitternes of his Letter: He could not uffer being beaten every where, and it would have been ome Comfort to him in the Misfortunes of the War, if he had been more happy in Love. So that he began his Journey under a terrible
Melancholy: At another time he would have come Pot, but as if he had had ome fore-knowledge of his ill Fortune, he came as lowly as poible; he began to find himelf omething Indipoed upon the way. At Vienna he fell very ill, but being but a days Journey from Lyons, he reolved to go thither, knowing he hould be better looked to. But the Fatigues of the Campagnia having brought him very low, his Troubles made an end of him; for notwithtanding he was young, and had the aitance of the bet Phyicians, yet they could not ave his Life: But as his greatet Sufferings could not make him forget Madam d' Olonne's Infidelity, he wrote to her this Letter jut before his Death.

p.hi: IF I could preerve any kindnes for you upon my Death-bed, I hould be very loath to dye; but not being able to eteem you any longer, it is without Regret that I leave the World; I only loved it that I might pas it the more weetly with you: But ince ome little Merit I had, and the greatet Paion imaginable, could not procure me your Affection, I do not deire to live any longer, but perceive that Death will free me from a great many Troubles. If you were capable of any tendernes,

you could not ee me in the Condition I am in, without dying for grief: But God be thanked, Nature has done the buines, and ince you could daily torment the Man of the World who loved you the mot, you may well ee him die without being concerned.

div.p: The firt Letter that the Duke of Candale wrote to Madam d' Olonne about Jeannin, had made her o much affraid of his Return, that he dreaded it like Death, and I fancy he wihed he might never ee him more. And yet the rumour of his being in that Extremity grieved her to the heart, and the News of his Death, which her Friend the Countes of Fieque brought her, had like to have made her dye her elf. She lot her Senes for ome moments, and came only to herelf at the Name of Merillus, whom he was told asked to peak with her.

Merille was the Duke's principal Confident, and brought Madam d' Olonne the Letter from his Mater that he had written to her as he lay a dying, and the little Trunk wherein he put his Letters, and all the other Favours he had received from her. After having read this lat Letter, he fell
a Crying more bitterly than before. The Countes not being willing to leave her in o deplorable Condition, propoed the opening that Trunck for the amuing her grief. The Countes found at firt a Handkerchief tained with blood in everal places. Ah! my God, cryed Madam d' Olonne, how has that poor Man, who had o many other things of greater Conequence, kept this Handkerchief till now; is there any thing in the world o kind! And thereupon he related to the Countes, that having cut her Finger as he was working by him ome years ago, he had asked that Handkerchief of hen, with which he had wiped her hand, and had kept it ever ince. After that they found Bracelets, Pures, Hair and Pictures of Madam d' Olonne, and coming to the Letters, the Countes deired her Friend that he might read ome of them. Madam d' Olonne having given her Conent, the Countes opened this firt.

p.hi: IT is reported here you have been beaten; this is perhaps a fale Rumour, and et on foot by thoe who envy you: But perhaps it is a Truth. Ah! My God! in this uncertainty I require my Lovers life of you, and I abandon to you the Army, yes, my God, and not

only the Army, but the State and all the World together. Since I have been told this ad News without particularizing any thing of you, I have made twenty viits a day; I fell to talk of the War, to ee if I could learn any thing that might give me eae: I am told every where that you have been beaten; but they donot peak particularly of you, and I dare not ask what is become of you, not that I am affraid of making appear thereby that I love you; I am in too great a fright to take care of my Reputation; but I fear to learn more than I am willing to know. This is the tate I am and hall be in till the arrival of the firt Pot, if I am able to expect it. What redoubles my diquiets is, that you have o often promied to end me expres Couriers upon all extraordinary Affairs, that I take it ill I have had none in this.

div.p:
While the Countes was reading this Letter with motions of Concern and Pity, Madam d' Olonne was melting into tears; after having perued it, they were both ome time without peaking: I'le read no more now, aid the Countes, for ince it puts me in pain, it mut needs trouble you much more. No, No, replyed Madam d' Olonne, continue, I beeech you, my Dear, it makes
me weep, but it puts me in mind of him. The Countes having opened a Letter, found it in thee terms.

body.p: HOw! Will you never leave me at ret: Shall I always be in fear of loing you, either by your Death or Inconstancy: As long as the Campaigne lats, I am in perpetual Alarms, the Enemies do not fire a Shot but what I imagine is aimed at you; and then I hear you have lot a Battail without knowing what is become of you, and though after a thouand mortal Apprehenions, I know at length my good fortune has aved you, (for you know by Experience you are not at all obliged to your own) I am told you are at Avignon in the Arms of Madam de Catillanne, where you comfort your elf for your Misfortunes. If it be o, I am very unhappy you did not loe your Life with the Battail: Yes, my Dear, I hould chooe rather to ee you Dead than Incontant; for I hould have had the pleaure to believe that had you lived longer, you would have till loved me, whereas my Heart is only filled with rage to ee my elf abandoned for another, who does not love you o much as I do.

div.p:
Is it true, Merille, aid the Countes, that the Duke of Candale was in love with Madam
de Catillanne? No, No, Madam, aid he to her, he was two days in Avignon at his return from the Army, to refreh himelf, and there he made two Viits to Madam de Catellanne; judge if this can be called Love. But, Madam, added he, addreing himelf to Madam d' Olonne, Who has given you uch good Information of all my Mater did? Alas! anwered he, I only know the publick report; but it is o common, that this Amour is even aid to be partly Caue of his Death: And then he fell a crying again more than ever. The Countes, who only ought to make a Diverion to her Grief, asked her if he knew not the Hand of a Supercription of a Letter he hewed her: Yes, anwered Madam d' Olonne, it is a Letter from my Steward. This must be omething very Curious, aid the Countes, I mut ee what he writes; and thereupon opened this Letter.

p.hi: LEt my Lady tell you what he will, her Houe is never empty of Normans; thoe Devils would be much better in their Countrey than here; I am mad, my Lord, to ee what I ee, which I do not end you the Particulars of, becaue I hope you will be here very uddenly, where you will take order for all your elf.

div.p:
By thee, Normans the Steward meant Beuvron and his Brothers, Jarry and the Chivalier de Sainct Earemond, and the Abbot de Villerceaux, who were very aiduous at Madam d' Olonne's Houe. The plainnes with which this poor Man ent this News to the Duke of Candale, did o move that foolih Woman, that after having looked upon the Countes to ee how he took it, he burt out a laughing; the Countes not having o much reaon to be afflicted as he had, did the like: But poor Merille not being able to bear with o unreaonable a Joy, redoubled his Fears, and went out of the Cabinet in a pet. Two or three days after Madam d' Olonne being perfectly comforted, the Countes and her other Friends advied her to mourn for her Honours ake, her Intrigue with the Duke of Candale having been too publick, to make a Mytery of it: So that he contrained her elf four or five days, after which he followed her old Coure, and that which hatened her laying by her Mask of Mourning was the Carneval, which by giving her an opportunity to atisfie her Inclination, helped her likewie to content her Husband, who had great upicions of her Correpondence with the Duke of Candale, and thought
himelf very happy in being freed from him. Wherefore to make him believe he was no longer concerned, he masked herelf four or five times with him, and being willing to regain entirely his Confidence by a great incerity, he not only confeed to him her love for the Duke, not only that he had uffered the Fort to be taken, but the particulars of their Enjoyments: And as he pecified the number, He had but little love for you, Madam, aid he, inulting the memory of the poor deceaed, ince he performed o eldom with o beautiful a Woman as you are.

She had left her Bed but a week, which he had kept above four, by reaon of a great hurt he had in her leg, when he reolved to mask herelf. And this deire advanced her Cure more then all the Remedies he had ued of a long time: So that he went in Maquerade four of five times with her Husband; but as thee were only little private Maquerades, he reolved to have a great and famous One that might be talked of; and to that intent he, and three more, diguied themelves like Capuchins, and caued two others of her Friends to be diguied like Nuns: The Capuchins were he herelf, her Husband, Jarry, and the
Abbot de Villereaux: The Nuns were my Lord Crofts an Englihman, and the Marques de Sillery. This Troop run into all Companies on Shrove-Tueday Night. The King and Queen his Mother having been informed of this Maquerade, were extreamly dipleaed with Madam d' Olonne, and aid openly that they would revenge the Injury and Contempt that had been had of Religion in that Occaion. Some time after their Majeties were pacified, and all thee Threatnings ended in their having no more eteem for Madam d' Olonne.

During all thee paages, Jeannin peaceably enjoyed his Mitres. When he caued the Lottery to be drawn, I have already aid that of Ten thouand Crowns he had received, he had employed but the half at mot, and the greatet part of this half was ditributed to the Capuchins, to the Nuns, and others of the Cabal. The Prince of Marillac, who was young, to act the chiefet part upon this Stage, had the greatet Lot, which was a Silver Cetern. Jeannin, with all the Favours he received; had only a Jewel of very mall value: The great Rumour that run of the deceit of this Lottery, vexed him to ee that he was no better treated than the mot indifferent.
He complained to Madam d' Olonne, he not thinking fit to acquaint him with her Roguery, received his Complaints very ill, inomuch that before they parted, they both fell to Reproaches, the one for his Money, the other for her Favours. The Concluion of which was, Madam d' Olonne's forbidding him her Houe, and Jeannin told her that he had never obeyed her o willingly as he hould do in that Occaion, and that this Command would ave him both Trouble and Expence.

In the mean time Beuvron's Commerce with her, lated till; whether the Spark was not much in love, or that he thought himelf happy in having her Favours at any rate, he tormented her a little about her Behaviour, he alo treated as one he made ue of when others failed her, and her love for him was as little as nothing.

Shortly after her falling out with Jeannin, Marillac who had Friends who were much brisker than he was himelf, was advied by them to apply himelf to Madam d' Olonne, and told him that he was of an Age to make himelf talked of, that Women procured Eteem as well as War, that Madam d' Olonne being one of the greatet Beauties of the Court, beides the great
Pleaures, would likewie be an Honour to him he hould love; and that it was very glorious to fill the place of the Duke of Candale. With all thee Reaons they egged on Marillac to make his Viits to Madam d' Olonne; but becaue he was naturally very ditrutful of himelf, his Cabal being alo very ditrutful of him, judged it was not fit he hould be left upon his word with her; and it was concluded that Sillery hould be appointed for his Governour, and to ait him upon occaion. Marillac had made great Application to her for two Months for this, without having poke to her of Love, otherwie then in general terms: He had however told Sillery, that it was above ix Weeks ince he had made an Amarous Declaration to her, and had likewie invented a very harh Anwer, that he aid he made him, that he might not think it trange he was o long without receiving Favours. Whereupon this Governour, to erve his Pupil, poke thus to Madam d' Olonne: I know very well, Madam, that nothing is o free as Love, and that if the heart is not touched by inclination, the mind will never be much perwaded by words; but I must however tell you, that when a Peron is young and unmarried, I do not
comprehend why a young amorous Gentleman is refued, who is as well provided, or I am much mistaken, as any man about Court; it is poor Marillac I peak of, Madam, ince he is deperately in love with you, why are you ungrateful? Or if you find you cannot love him, why do you amue him? Love him or dimis him. I know not ince when, anwered Madam d' Olonne, that Men pretend we hould love them, without their having made it their Requet; for I have heard ay, it was they who formerly made Court. I know very well that in thee latter days they treat Gallantry after a strange manner; but I knew not that they had reduced it to the point of requiring that Women hould be their Votaries. How, anwered Sillery, has not Marillac declared he loved you? No, Sir, aid he to him, it is you who firt tell it me. Not but that his Aiduities have made me upect he had ome deign; but till we are poke to, we do not undertand the ret. Ah Madam, replied Sillery, you are not then o much in fault as I thought, Marillac's Youth renders him fearful; but the ame Youth makes Women excue everal things: Perons of his Age are eldome faulty, and men but Twenty years old always meet with Compaion. I grant, replied Madam d' Olonne, that the Bahfulnes of a young Man raies
Pity, and never Anger; but I likewie pretend he hould be repectful. Do you call repect, Madam, aid Sillery to her, the not daring to ay we are in love? It is all meer folly, I ay, in regard of a Woman who would not make Returns: For in that Cae the Gallant would not loe his time; and would quickly know what he was to trut to: But this repect which you require, Madam, is only of advantage to you with thoe you have no inclination for; for if the Man you are inclined to love hould have too much of it, you would be very much perplexed. As he had done peaking, Company came in, whereupon he took his leave, and went to eek out Marillac, to whom having made a thouand Reproaches for his Timidity, he made him promie that before that day was at an end, he would make an amorous Declaration to his Mitres: He likewie told him part of the things it was requiite he hould ay, which Marillac had forgot within a Moment after; and having encouraged him as much as he could, he aw him et out for this great Expedition.

However Marillac was under trange diquiets, ometimes he thought his Coach went too fat, ometimes he wihed he might not find Madam d' Olonne at home, or that he might find ome body with her:
In a word, he feared the ame things that a brisk Man would have deired with all his heart. However, he was o unhappy as to meet with his Mitres, and to find her alone. He came up to her with o diordered a Countenance, that if Sillery had not already acquainted her with his Love, he would have dicovered it by eeing him only that time. This Diorder helped to perwade her more then all he, or the Eloquence of his Friend could have aid to her: And it is for this reaon that Fools are more happy than the Wie in Love.

The firt thing that Marillac did after being eated, was putting on his Hat, o little was he himelf; an intant after perceiving his folly, he took off his Hat and Gloves, then put on one again, and all this without aying a Word. What's the matter, Sir, aid Madam d' Olonne, you eem to be concerned at omething. Do not you Divine it, Madam, aid Marillac? No, aid he, I do not comprehend it; How hould I undertand what you do not tell me, being hardly able to conceive what I am told? I hall tell you then, what it is, replied Marillac impering, I am in love with you. But why o much Ceremony, aid he, for o mall a thing: I do not ee there is o much difficulty in
loving, there appearing much more in loving well. Ah Madam! I find it much harder to tell it than to do it; I find none at all in loving you, and I hould find it o difficult to ceae loving you, that I hould never be able to forbear, tho you hould order it me a thouand times. I Sir, replied Madam d' Olonne bluhing, I have nothing to Command you. Any other than Marillac would have undertood the cunning way that Madam d' Olonne made ue of to permit him to love her: But his Wit was gone a Wool-gathering, and all Delicacy upon him was lot. How Madam, aid he to her, do you not eteem me enough to honour me with your Commands. Well, aid he to him, hould you be glad I ordered you not to love me any longer? No, Madam, replied he bluntly. What would you be at then, aid Madam d' Olonne? Love you as long as I live, aid he. Well, aid he, love me as long as you pleae and hope. This had been ufficient for a more preing Gallant than Marillac to have pretended to enjoyment immediately; and yet notwithtanding all that Madam d' Olonne could do, he made her wait two Months, and at length, when they came to the point, he was forced to make all the Advances. The etablihing: this new Commerce did not
make her break that he had with Beuvron: The lat Lover was ever the mot beloved, but he was not o much in her Favour as to drive away Beuvron, who was a econd Husband to her.
A little before the Repture of Jeannin with Madam d' Olonne, the Chevalier of Grammont was fallen in love with her, and he being a very extraordinary Peron, it is fit I give a Decription of him.

The Chevalier had brisk Eyes, a handome Noe, a pretty Mouth, a dimple in his Chin, and I know not what of ine in his Phiiognomy, his Shape had been comely, had he not tooped, his Wit was delicate and gallant. However, his Meen and his Accent gave a Grace to what he aid, that became nothing in the Mouth of another. A mark of this is that he writ the wort of any Body, and he writ as he poke. Though it be uperfluous to ay that a Rival is incommode, the Chevalier was to that point, that it would have been better for a poor Woman to be troubled with four others then he alone. He was o prightly that he hardly ever lept, he was liberal to Profuion, and by that means his Mitres and his Rivals could not have Servants nor Secrets but what he knew, otherwie the
bet Man in the World. It was twelve years ince he began to love the Countes of Fieque, a Woman as extraordinary as he was a Man, that is to ay, as ingular in Merits as he was in ill Qualities; but as of thoe twelve years he had been banihed, five from Mademoielle d' Orleans, Gaton's of France's Daughter, a Princes whom Fortune perecuted, becaue he had Vertue, and could not reduce her great Courage to the baenees that the Court demands. During their abence the Chevalier had tied himelf to a very regular Contancy; and tho the Countes was very lovely, he merited ome excue for his Lightnes, being he had never received any favour from her. He had however caued everal to be jealous; Rouville was one of thoe who were o: As he was one day reproaching the Countes that he loved the Chevalier, that fair One told him that he was mad to believe he could love the greatet Cheat in the World. This is a pleaant reaon, Madam, which you alledge, I know you are a greater Cheat than he, and yet I cannot forbear loving you.

Tho the Chevalier was in love with all Women, the Countes however had that power over him, that what engagement
oever he had elewhere, o oon as he knew that any One viited her oftner that ordinary, he quitted all to return to her: And he was in the Right, for the Countes was a lovely Woman, he had blew and parkling Eyes, a handome Noe, an agreable Mouth, of a fine Colour, and white and mooth Skin; the forme of her Face was long, and never any One but he in the world was embelihed with a long Chin; her hair was brown, and he was ever Gallantly dret, but her finery proceeded rather from Art than the magnificence of her Clothes; her Will was free and naturall, her Humour cannot be decribed, for it was with the Modety of her Sex of the Humour of all the World. People by much thinking of what they have to do, think uually better at the end than at the beginning. The contrary happened uually to the Countes, her Reflections poyled her firt Motions. I know not if the Confidence he had in her Merit made her careles of eeking Lovers, for he took no pains at all to have them. And indeed when any One of himelf made his addrees to her, he neither affected Rigour to be rid of him, nor Kindnes to retain him, he left of his Courthip if he pleaed, if he pleaed he
continued it: and what coure oever he took he did not ubit to her cot. So that the Chevalier as I have aid, had not viited her in five years time, and during that abence that he might not loe time he had had a thouand Mitrees, amongt others Victoria Manciri, Duches of Mercoeur, and three dayes after her Death, Madam de Villars, and it was for this reaon that Benerade, who was in love with her, made this Sonnet upon the Chevalier.

lg.l: Can you rejoice after the Mortall troak
That kill'd the loveliet Object e're was een?
A real Lovers heart would have been broke,
In the ame Tomb he would have buryed been.
A Heart o Charm'd can it new flames receive?
? I is an unheard of infidelity!
When a fair Mitres's death you ought to grieve,
You turn Gallant and at new Game would fly.
For this unworthy weaknes you will mart;
You love have fail'd, & love will fail your heart,
And you're already fall'n into the Snare.
I. know the Beauty who does you decoy
I love her, and that all I may declare;
What gives you eae, alas! does me detray.

div.p: The Countes returning ome time after to Paris, the Chevalier not being tyed to Madam Villars by any favours, quitted her to return to the Countes; but as he was never long in the ame tate, and being tyred with her, he made his addrees to Madam d' Olonne, at the ame time that Marillac entred into an engagement with her, and tho the Chevalier was les Modet than Marillac with the Ladies, he was not however the more preing; on the contrary provided he might toy with 'em, have it aid in the world that he was in love, find ome People of eaie belief to flatter his vanity, put a Rival in pain, be better received than he, he was not at all fond of a urrender. One thing he did that made it more difficult for him to perwade than it was for another, was that he never poke eriouly. Inomuch that a Woman mut needs flatter her elf extreamely, to beleive he was in love with her.

I have already aid that never any Gallant that was not beloved was more incommode than he, he had ever two or three Lacquies without Liveries, whom he called his Bloodhounds, whom he caued to dog and oberve his Rivals and his Mitrees.
Madam d' Olonne being in pain One day how he hould go to an Aignation he had made with Marillac, without being dicovered by the Chevalier, reolved for her pleaure to go hooded up with her Chamber Maid, and to Pas the River in a Boat; after having given orders to her ervants to go wait for her at Fauxbourgs Saint Germain, the firt Man who gave her his hand to help her into the Boat, was the Chevaliers Bloodhound, before whom, without knowing him, he had been merry with her Chamber Maid, for that he had deceived the Chevalier, and talked of what they were going to do that day; this Bloodhound went immediately to acquaint his Mater, who trangly urpried Madam d' Olonne the next day, when he acquainted her with the perticulars of her Rendevouz of the Evening before.

An honet welbred Man having convicted his Mitres of loving another than himelf, withdraws immediately and without noie, particularly if he had not made him any promie; but the Chevalier was not of that humour; when he could not procure being beloved, he would rather choe to have been tabbed than leave his Mitres and Rival in repoe. Now Madam
d' Olonne having reckoned for nothing the Aiduities that the Chevalier had payed her for three Months together, and turned into Raillery all that he had told her of his Paion, and the more for that he was perwaded, that he had as great an one for the Countes as he could have for her, he hated him as the Devil. Then this Lover fancying that a Letter would do his buines much better than all he had done or aid thitherto, in that Opinion he writ to her in thee termes.

p.hi: IS it poible, my Goddes, that you hould be ignorant of the love, that your fair Eyes, my Suns, have kindled in my heart? Tho it be ueles to have recoure with you to thoe Declarations which we are forced to have with mortal Beauties, and that mental Prayers, ought to uffice you, I have told you athouand times that I loved you; yet you laugh and make me no anwer; Is this a good or an ill ign my Queen, I conjure you to explain your elf therein, that the mot paionate of mortals may continue to adore you, and ceae to dipleae you.

div.p:
Madam d'Olonne having received this Letter, carried it immediately to the Countes, with whom he fancyed it had been concerted,
but did not eem to beleive any uch thing at firt. As there was alwayes a eeming kindnes between them, he miling valued at a high rate her refuing her Lover, and the notice he gave of the infidelity he would have committed. This vexed the Countes, tho he did not love the Chevalier: mot Women are no more willing to loe their Lovers whom they had no kindnes for than thoe they favour, and particularly when they abandon them to give themelves to others, and their Vexation does not o much proceed from the los they have as from the preference of their Rivals: which was the Countees cae in this encounter. However he thanked Madam d' Olonne for the intention he had to oblige her, but proteted he had no engagement with the Chevalier, but that on the contrary he hould be obliged to thoe who would rid her of him. Madam d' Olonne did not content her elf with hewing that Letter to the Countes, he likewie vapoured with it to Marillac; and whether he or the Countes poke of it to others, every body knew that the Poor Chevalier had been acrificed, and he himelf was quickly acquainted with the jeats that were made upon his Letter.
Contempt offends all Lovers, but when Raillery is joyned with it they are netled to the heart: The Chevalier eeing himelf Caheired and laughed at, kept no longer any meaures, he aid all manner of ill things of Madam d' Olonne, and it was perceived in this Occaion, that this foolih Woman had found the ecret of loing her reputation by preerving her Honour of being Cruel, and cryed out upon for a Gilt.

The Chevalier hated none of his Rivals o much as he did Marillac, as well becaue he thought him better treated, as for that he fancyed he the leat deerved it: he called Madam d' Olonne's Lovers, the Philitins, and aid that Marillac by reaon he had but little Wit, had defeated them all with the Jaw bone Bone of an As.

In this ame time the Count of Guiche, the Marechal of Grammont's Son, as beautiful as an Angell, and full of Love, fancyed that the conquet of the Countes would be both eaie and honorable to him; inomuch that he reolved to undertake it out of motives of Glory; he mentioned it to Manicamp his aithful and neceary Friend, who approved his deigne, and offered to erve him in it. The Count de Guiche and Manicamp have o great a part
in this tory, that it is neceary to peak of them en paant, and make them perfectly known; and in order to that it is fit I begin with the decription of the former.

The count de Guiche had great black Eyes, a handome Noe, well made, his Mouth was omething wide, the forme of his Face round, his Complexion was admirable, had a great Forehead and a fine Shape: he had Wit, was very knowing, addicted to raillery, light, preumptuous, brave, haty and without friendhip: he was Colonel of the French Gards, jointly with the Marechal of Grammom his Father.

Manicamp had weet blew Eyes, a Hawk's Noe, a wide Mouth, his Lips were very red and full, his Complexion was omething yellow, his Face was flat, his Haire thick long and white, his Shape was fine if it had not been too much neglected: As for Wit he had enough of the Count de Guiche's ort; he had not acquired o much, but his Genius way at leat as good; his Fortune not being o well etled as the others, made him omething the more cautious; but they had naturally both the ame inclinations to the hinder parts and to raillery;
and indeed they loved one another as ardently as if they had been of different Sexes.

At the ame time Madam d' Olonne hewed all the World the Chevalier de Grammont's Letter, he dicovered the love the Count de Guicke had for the Countes of Fieque, this was of no mall ue to him for the making her fall out with Madam d' Olonne, fancying his Reconciliation would be the more eay with the Countes, the les he kept meaures with the others: but while he is endeavouring to make Peace for himelf, let us e what the Count de Guicke did to render himelf lovely. Firt you mut know then that the Count had a very great paion for Mademoielle de Beauvais, a Maid of mean Birth, but of a great deal of Wit; it mut likewie be known that he had been o travered by his Relations in that Amour, that they feared he would make him commit the ame folly, that his Siter had caued the Marques of Richilieu to do, whom that Conideration, as well as the Rigours of the faire One, had very much diguted, and had the deeper engaged him in the deign of Loving the Countes; but he had not for this fair One, all the inclination he deerved, and it was les a econd paion than a Remedy to the
former. But he got little ground, & all that he could do was to move the Countes and to put the Chevalier into dipair; and for that end he kept to Lookes and Aiduities, without caring to pur on fater. The Countes, whoe heart, as is beleived, was never mitten with any thing but the merit of Guitand, the Prince of Conde's Favourite, whom he had not een in four or five years, but with whom he had kept a commerce of Letters, felt her Contancy haken by the Count de Guiches addrees, and notwithtanding all that Geré, Guitavel's friend, could ay to her, for the obliging her to chace away the Count, he would not at firt yeild to it, but eemed to ridicule that Amour, and a long time eluded the Counels of all her friends: yet at length he her elf perceiving that the Count took no advantage of it, he reolved to procure her elf honour by making a Virtue of the neceity he beleived her elf in of loving her, and that this might not eem a Sacrifice to the Chevalier, who had bragged he could caue his Nephew to be Cahiered, he turned them both off, yeilding at that time to the advie of Geré, as he told him; and hereupon was made this jeat, that the Countes was
going to igne the Dicharges and Paports of her Lovers, but the Chevalier caued her to be o intreated by her bet Friends, that he obtained leave to ee her at a fortnights end, and it was upon this that this Song was made to the tune of Saraband.

q.l: So zealouly old Gere plaid his part,

l.hi: With uch ucces he erv'd his Flemmih Friend,
That the fair Lady, who has till my Heart,
Never to ee her did me Orders end.
He fancied then, and I was much afraid,
An everlating Doom on me was laid;
In a hort banihment yet all will end.

div.p:
Five or ix Months being paed, during which the Chevalier was too happy, he was not troubled with his Nephew, had enjoyed the pleaures of olely loving the Countes; ome friends of the Count de Gutche repreented to him that being the handomet Man of the Court, it was a hame for him to find any Lady cruel, and that the ucces he had had with the Countes had done him any injury in the world: thee reaons made him reolve to reingage himelf: He returned from he Campagne wounded in his Right Hand, but his Wound, tho great, not
having hindred him from going abroad ome times, he met the Countes One day in the Tuilleryes: He had the Abbot Fouequett with him, who was that Lady's particular friend, who thinking to do them a pleaure, engaged them in dicoure, and left them together a pretty long time. The Count aid nothing at all of love, but his ways and his looks made the Countes undertand but too much, nay more than he deigned he hould: This Converation was quickly ended by the Count de Guiche's ainting away, out of which he was recovered by the help of the Countes and the Abbot.

Their Opinion of the caue of his ainting away were divers, the Abbot attributed it to the Counts wound, and the Countes to his paion. A Woman believes nothing more willingly than that he is beloved, becaue Love makes her beleive that he ought to be beloved, and becaue One is not hard to be perwaded of what One deires. Thee reaons made the Countes not at all doubt of the Count de Guiche's Love. At that time Madam de Olonne not being willing that a young park o well made hould ecape her, deired Vieneuil to bring the Count de Guiche to her, but this Gentleman's time was not yet
come, he went from thence as free as he came thither. He continued his Deign for the Countes, his Aiduities having renewed the Chevaliers jealouie; he to inform himelf how his Nephew tood with his Mitres, wrote with his left Hand the following Letter to that fair One.

p.hi: IT is no mall trouble to have only a poor left Hand; I beeech you, Madam, to grant me the honour of eeing you ome time this day, but my dear nkle must know nothing of it, for I hould run a rique of my Life, and perhaps you your elf would come off but little better.

div.p:
The Countes having read this Letter, gave charge to her Porter to bid him who hould come for an Anwer, that he hould tell his Mater, That he hould end Manicamp to her at Three a Clock in the Afternoon. When the Chevalier had received this Anwer, he fancied he had wherewith to Convict the Countes of being in the deepet Engagement of an Amorous Intrigue with his Nephew; and in that Opinion he went to her Houe: The Rage he was in had o changed his Countenance, that had the Countes ever o little ditruted
him, he had dicovered all at the firt ight; but not upecting the leat, he took no notice of his looks. Madam, aid he to her, is it long ince you aw the Count de Guiche? Not thee five or ix days, anwered he. But, replied the Chevalier, It is not o long ince you received Letters from him. I, Letters from the Count de Guiche? aid he; Why hould he write to me? Is he in a Condition to write to any Body? Take care of what you ay, Madam, replyed the Chevalier, for it is of moment. The truth is, aid the Countes, that Manicamp has newly ent to ask me if the Count de Guiche might come and ee me to day; and I ent him word, he hould come without his Friend. It is true, replyed the Chevalier hatily, that you jut now ent word to Manicamp that he hould come without the Count de Guiche, but it was upon the Count's Letter that you ent him that Meage, and I come to know it, Madam, becaue that it was I that writ it, and had your Anwer delivered to me. Is it not ufficient that you do not make Returns to the Paion I have had thee Twelve years for you, but you mut prefer a young Boy before me, who does not love you, nor has eemed to love you above a Fortnight? After this Dicoure he was like a Mad-man for a Quarter of an hour together.
The Countes eeing herelf Convicted, would turn the thing into Raillery: But ince you upected an Intrigue between me and your Nephew, aid he to him, why did you not ask me things of greater importance than an hour to ee me? Ah! Madam, replyed he, I know but too much to make me believe that you are the mot ungrateful Woman in the World, and I the mot unfortunate of all Men, Manicamp came in jut as he had poke thee words, whereupon he went away to conceal the diorder he was in. What's the matter, Madam, aid Manicamp, I find you in a trange perplexity? The Countes related to him all the Chevaliers Deceipt, and their Converation thereupon; and after ome Dicoures upon this Subject, Manicamp went away, and within an hour brought this Letter from the Count de Guiche.

For fear Forgers hould injure me by acting my part, and let you hould be mitaken in the Character and the Stile, I was deirous to make known to you both the one and the other; the lat is more difficult, being dictated by omething above their Sentiments.

The Countes having read this Letter,
My God, aid he to him, how illy is your Friend! I am affraid he will bring trouble both upon me and himelf. Provided, Madam, anwered Manicamp, that you undertand one another, you cannot come to trouble. But, anwered the Countes, can he only act with me the part of a Lover? Yes, Madam, aid he, it is impoible for him to change; and what ought to perwade you, is that he returns to the Charge after having been routed: This hews a furious neceity in him of loving you. As they were going to continue this Converation, Company came in who interrupted it, Manicamp taking leave, went immediately to his Friend to acquaint him with what had jut paed between the Countes and him. The Count de Guiche not believing that the Letter he had written to the Countes, was ufficient to perwade her perfectly of his Paion, he wrote another, which expreed it more clearly, and gave it Manicamp in charge; who carrying it the next day to that fair One, lot it by the way, inomuch that he returned immediately to acquaint the Count with the Accident that had befallen him; whereupon that Count writ this Letter to the Countes.

body.p: IF you were perwaded of my Sentiments, you would eaily comprehend, that I am ill atified with o careles a Man as Manicamp; you are going to ee the greatet quarrel in the World, if you do not prevent it; think but what I do for you, ince I break with the bet of my Friends without Return on my ide; but, as he has till other Aitance, and that you are not o much dipleaed as I am, I fear he will force me to pardon him through your Interceion.

div.p:
Manicamp went and ought every where for the Countes, and having at length found her at Play at Madam de Bonnelle's, I bring good luck, Madam, to People I approach, aid he to her; and having placed himelf by her, he neatly lipt his Friends Letter into her Pocket, and went away. The Countes withdrawing ome time after to her own Houe, having left off Play, in taking out her Handkerchief, he ound the Count de Guiche's Letter, ealed and without Supercription; if he had thought what it was, he would not have opened it, but for fear he hould be obliged not to break it open, he was not willing to pend thoughts upon it, and opened it immediately
without the leat reflexion: All the Countee's vivacity could not make her imagine what the Count de Guiche meant by his being diatisfied with Manicamp; inomuch that he ordered one of her Servants to go tell him, he hould come and ee her on the Morrow, being reolved to rattle him for the Letter he had given her from the Count de Guiche, and to forbid him to charge himelf with any more for the future. As he entred the Chamber the next day, her Curioity made her forget her Anger: Well, aid he, tell me your quarrel with your Friend. It is, Madam, aid he to her, that as I was bringing you a Letter two days ago, I lot it, and he is enraged againt me, and I know not what to ay to him, for I am in the fault. The Countes fearing this lot Letter might be found by ome one who might make a Story of it, to make the publick Sport; Go, aid he to him, go eek it every where, and do not return till you have brought it me back. Manicamp went away immediately, and returned in the Evening to tell her, that he could not find it, that the Count de Guiche would no longer ee him, and that he came to beeech her to reconcile them. I will, aid he, tho you do not deerve it: And I hall go to morrow to
Mademoielle, bid your Friend be there. I have no more Commerce with him, aid Manicamp to her, and nothing can appeae him but a Letter from you. I write to the Count de Guiche! replyed the Countes, you are a pleaant Man to make uch a Propoal. Tho we are fallen out, Madam, anwered Manicamp, I cannot forbear telling you till that he deerves that favour. Do not think of him in this Occaion, give this Letter to the Friendhip you have for me, and I promie that when it has done the buines, I will return it into your hands. The Countes having made him engage his word he would bring back her Letter, he writ to him the day following in thee terms.

body.p: THe intention of thee Lines are only to ask Manicamp's pardon, and if it is neceary to ay anything more to oblige you to grant it me, give credit to what he hall acquaint you with from me; he is o much my Friend, that I cannot refue anything that may be ueful to him.

div.p: The Count of Guiche having received this Letter, ound it too hard to retore it; he fancied he hould get quit by diavowing Manicamp, and in the mean time he encharged him with this Anwer.

body.p: I Could infinitely deire you were as much inclined to grant me what I hould deire of you, as it was caie for me to grant pardon to the Criminal: I avow to you, that with uch a Recommendation it was impoible to refue any thing: If I was o happy as to be able to give you proofs thereof by omething more difficult, you would know that you did me an injutice, when you doubted of the truth of my Sentiments: They are, I aure you, as paionate as o lovely a Peron as you are can inpire, and hall ever be as middet as you can deire them. Notwithtanding all what our Governours ay, I conjure you to follow the advice of the Criminal; for tho he is omething careles, his zeal for our Service deerves to be Commended.

p.hi: IF you had had as much deire to informe your elf of things you eemed to doubt of, as I had by a thouand true reaons to take from you all manner of Scruples, you would not have undertaken o long a Journey, or at leat you would have been orry to have appeared o good a Friend. I would not forbid your having a kindnes, but I hould extreamly deire to have ome part in the Application, and I avow to you, that if I was happy enough to compas it by the ame means, I hould endeavour to render my elf worthy of it by my Conduct.

div.p:
While this Letter was a carrying to the Countes, the Chevalier went to eek out his Nephew, with whom he found Manicamp. After a Prologue of Raillery upon the good Fortunes of the Count de Guiche in General: Faith, my poor Friends, aid he to them, I confes you are younger and genteeler than I am, and I hall never dipute with you a Mitres I have not been a long time acquainted with: But however, you mut yield the Countes to me, and all thoe I have any Engagement with. The Vanity Women take in a great number of Galants may oblige them to give you ome hopes. There are few who at the firt onet will tifle the Vows of their Adorers: But ooner or later they return to reaon; and it is then that the new Comer paes his time very ill, and that the old Gallant jointly with his Mitres cry, Farewel you Gentlemen Serenaders. You promied me, Count de Guiche, never to torment me more, as to what concerns the Countes; you have broke your word, and committed an infidelity that has done you no good: For the Countes has given me all the Letters you wrote to her; I'le now you the Originals when you will: In the mean time here is a Copy of the lat Letter you ent her; and aying that, he took out a Letter of the Count de Guiche's, and having read it; Well! my
Dears, aid he to them, you'l hunt upon my grounds again, will you?

While the Chevalier was peaking, the Count de Guiche and Manicamp looked amazedly upon one another, not being able to comprehend that the Countes had o baely deceived them. At length Manicamp broak ilence, and addreing himelf to the Count, You are treated, aid he to him, as you deerved; but ince the Countes has not had any Conideration for us, added he, turning towards the Chevalier, we are not obliged to have any for her: We eaily perceived we have been Sacrificed, but there was a time, Chevalier, that you was o too; We have indeed great reaon to complain of her, but you have none at all to be atisfied with her: When we ome times rejoyced and were merry at your Cots, the Countes went halves with us at the leat. The truth is, aid the Count de Guiche, that you would not have, reaon to be atisfied with the Countees preference in your Favours, if you knew the esteem he has of you; and this makes me draw infallible Conequences that he is deeply engaged with you, ince after all the things he has told me, he only betrays me to give you atisfaction. Thereupon being all three really reconciled, and having given one another a thouand Aurances of
Friendhip for the future, they parted.

The Count de Guiche and Manicamp hut themelves up to make a Letter of reproaches in Manicamps Name to the Countes, to which the poor Countes being innocent, made anwer, that he and his Friend had been taken for Cullies, and that the Chevalier was cunninger than they; that he could not tell by what means he had got the Letter he had howed them, but that they One day hould clearly ee that he had not made a Sacrifice of them. This Letter not finding Manicamp any longer at Paris, he being gone out the day before with the Count de Guiche to follow the King in his Progres to Lyons, he did not receive it till he arrived at Court, and thought neither the more, nor the les advantageouly of the Countes: during all thee paages, Marillac's Intrigue with Madam d' Olonne jogged on; that Lover eeing her with the greatet conveniency imaginable by night at her Houe, and by day at Mademoielle de Cornuelle's, a lovely Creature, and of a great deal of Wit. Madam d' Olonne had by her Bedide a Cloet, in a corner of which he had caued a trap Door to be made, which went into another Cloet underneath, wherein
Marillac entred when it was night; a Foot-Carpet concealed the Trapdoor, and a Table covered it. Thus Marillac paing the Night with Madam d' Olonne, according to the common report, did not loe his time: This lated till he went to the Waters, in which time Marillac, who wrote to her a thouand Letters that are not mentioned here, becaue they are not worth the pains; wrote this Amourous Ticket to her one day, before bidding her Adieu.

body.p: I never felt o lively a Grief as that I am enible of at preent, my Dear, becaue I never yet parted from you ince we have been in love with one another. Nothing but abence, and that too the firt abence of what a peron infinitely loves, can reduce one into the lamentable Condition I am in. If any thing could leen my trouble, my Dear, it would be the belief that you would uffer as much as I do. Do not take it ill that I wih you in pain, ince it is a mark of your love. Farewel my Dear, be well aured that I love you, and that I hall love you ever; for if you are once really perwaded of this truth, it is impoible but that you mut love me as long as you live.

div.p: Her Anwer was:

p.hi: COmfort your elf, my Dear, If my Grief gives you cae, it is as great as you

could deire it; I cannot explaine it better, than by telling you that I uffer as much as I love you: If you doubt it, my Dear, come to me, but come early, that I may be a long time with you, and that I may in ome manner recompence my elf for the abence I am going to uffer. Farewell my Dear, be aured of my paion, it is at leat as great as yours.

div.p:
Marillac did not fail to be at the Aignation much ooner than ordinary; In accoting his Mitres he flung himelf upon her Bed, and was thus a long time melting into tears, and all his words were interrupted by obs. Madam d' Olonne for her part appeared no les concerned, but as he was deirous to receive other Marks of Love from her Galant than thoe of Grief; How! my Dear, aid he to him, you ent me word a little while a go that my Grief would cae yours, and yet the affliction you ee me in, does not render you the more capable of Comfort. At thee words Marillac redoubled his ighs, without making her an anwer, the dulnes of his Soul had caued the ame effect in his Body; and I fancy that this Lover deplored at that time more the abence of his Vigour, than that of his Mitres. However as young People recover eaily, and he being of a good complexion,
he began to come to himelf, and recovered his trength in a little time: Inomuch that Madam d' Olonne could hardly dicover he had been o lately ill. After he had given her o many tetimonies of his good health, he recommended to him to have care of it above all things, and told him that he hould judge thereby of the Love he had for her. Thereupon they made a thouand Protetations of loving one another all their life-time; they agreed of the means of writing, and then took leave, the one to go to Court, the other to the Wells. Prince Marillac went the next day to take his leave of Mademoielle. Cornuelle, his good Friend, he deired her to perwade his Mitres to be more circumpect in her Carriage than he had yet been. Rely upon me for that, aid this young Lady to him, he mut be very incorrigible if I do not keep her within bounds. Two dayes after Mademoielle Cornuelle went to Madam d' Olonnes, and having prayed her to order her Porter to ay he was gone out: I am too much your friend, Madam, aid he to her, not to peake franckly to you in all that concerns your Carriage and your Reputation; you are beautyfull, young, you are of Quality, you have Riches and will, you have infinitely
Charmed a Prince who loves you extreamly: All this ought to <> you happy, however you <> not o; you know what Reports run of you, we have talked of them ometimes together, and this being o, you are mad you are not <> : I do not pretend to conider your weakenees, I am a Woman as well as you, and I know by my elf the want of our Sex: Your Manners are inupportable, you love pleaures Madam, and I allow them, but you take delight to et People a talking, and it is that I condemn you for; Can you not leave off your Extravagances? it is impoible but that you mut be in a Rage, when you hear of the Reputation you have in the world, and Men conceal the love they have for you more out of Shame than Modesty. Well my Dear, aid Madam d' Olonne, do you here any thing new? does the World renew its Satyr's against me? No, Madam, aid Mademoielle, it does only continue them, becaue you till continue to give it new matters. I know not what I must do then, replyed Madam d' Olonne, all the Prudence that one can have in love, I fancyed I had; and that ince I have been concerned in loving, I never fruitlely delayed nor pun out any Intrigue, well knowing that the greatet Noie is uually made before the buines is agreed on; and when Lovers act
not in Concert together. Pret hee tell me exactly my Dear, added he, what I mut do to love well, and entertain a Gallantry, that hall do me no injury in the world, tho it hould be upected: For I am reolved to do my Devoir in the future with the utmot Regularity. There are o many things to ay upon that point, aid Mademoielle Cornuelle, that I hould never have don, if I would neglect nothing, however I hall tell you the principal as uccinctly as poible.

Firt you mut know Madam, that there are three orts of Women who make love, The Debauchées, the Cocquets, and the honet Mitrees. Tho the firt are abominable, they certainly deerve more compaion than hatred, becaue they are hurryed away by the force of their Temper, and that almot an impoible application is required to reforme Nature; however if in any encounter we ought to conquer our elves, it is in that, wherein no les is concerned than our honours or lives.

As for Cocquets, the number being much greater, I hall enlarge more upon that point: The difference between Debauchées, and them, is, that in the Ill the former commit, there is at leat incerity, and in what the Cocquets do there is Treachery: The Cocquets tell us to excue
themelves when they give ear to the Courthip of all Comers, that how honet oever a Woman is, he never hates a peron who tells her he loves her.

But one may anwer them that ditinctions are to be made: either that Lover addrees himelf to a Woman, who will be either honet for her elf or for a Lover: allow that he cannot hate a Man for the Sentiments he had for her, yet this will not hinder her from being carefull of not having o much Complaiance for him as for another, who had never declared any thing to her, for fear he hould thereby entertain his hopes, and that at length it might make a noie, and be injurious to the reputation he would preerve.

If the Woman be prepoeed that the Man declares love to her, he will have the ame precautions as the other to hinder it from continuing, but if he perits, I maintain that he hall hate him as much as he hall love her true Gallant: it being natural to hate the Enemies of the peron we love, becaue love will not allow love to be importunate, and becaue that a Lover well treated may upect that a Paion that continues in his Rival, is atleat nourihed by ome hopes; an honet
