Mitres coniders his Rival as her mortal Enemy, who maks her run the rique of loing her Lover whom he loves more than her life. This being plain, you mut likewie know that there are everal orts of Cocquets; ome take a pride in being beloved by a great many People, without ever loving any of them, and do not perceive that it is the advances themelves make which invite men, and which retain them rather than merit. Beides as it is not poible they hould dipoe their Favours o equally, but that ome one will eem better treated than others, and there being ome who will not content themelves with equality, but pretend to preference; This gives jealouy to the Malecontents, and makes them ay in quitting them, all, nay more than they know.

There are other Cocquets who manage everal Lovers, that they may ave the real one in the multitude, and caue it to be aid, they have no amorous Intrigue, ince they treat equally all thoe who viit them; but the bet luck that can happen to them is to have the truth dicovered; or at leat, it is better than by believing they love no Body, every one ancies they love All.

There are others who by managing everal
Gallants would fain perwade, that if they hould love any one of them, they hould hazard the vexing him, In the mean time they vex and loe him by thee means. For to imagine that it is in the abence of their true Lover that they make love, he will know nothing of it; or if it is in his preence, by acting in concert together, he will eaily ee that is nothing, ince he is taken for a Witnes of what is done, or at all hazards if he is troubled, their Careing him, and their Promies to do o no more, will oblige him to be atisfied. All this is very ubject to caution, a Lover is not long deceived, and if he does not dicover it to day, he will dicover it to Morrow.

q.l: And crying 'tis well, adieu my Dear,
I find no longer pleaure here.

div.p:
And tho his Paion hould be o trong, that he could not get rid of it, the reproaches and noie he would make, would occaion more vexation to the Cocquet Mitres than all thoe managements could have procured her Pleaure. There are Cocquets who fancy they have o ill a repute in the World, that they dare not be cruel and rigorous to any man, for fear it hould pas for a Sacrifice to ome other, and never
think that it would be better for their Honour that they were convicted of Sacrifice: This is, Madam, the Coure the Coquets take. I mut let you ee that of honet Mitrees.

As for them, they are either atisfied with their Lovers, or they are not: If they are not, they endeavour to reduce them to their Devoir by a tender and civil Carriage: If this cannot abolutely be, they break off without noie, upon a pretext of Devotion, or the Jealouie of a Husband, after having got from them, if they can, their Letters, and all that could Convict them: And above all things they o contrive it, that their Lovers do not fancy they abandom them for others.

If they are atisfied with their Lovers, they love them with all their hearts, they are continually telling it them, and they write them the kindet Letters they can: But as this does not prove their love, becaue Coquets ay as much, or more every day, their Actions and their Carriage does ufficiently jutifie the meaning of their Hearts, becaue there is only that inallible. We can indeed ay, We love tho we do not, but we cannot eem kind to any one long without having an affection for him.

An honet Mitres is more afraid of giving Jealouie to her Gallant than of Death, and when he ees him alarmed with any Supicion that the obtinacy of his Rival might give him, he does not content herelf with the tetimony of her Concience, he redoubles her Cares and Carees for him, and her rigours for the other; he does not defer the extreamet Severity till another time, fancying he could never be oon enough rid of an importunate Peron. She knows that as many Moments as he defers the chacing away this Rival, he hould give as many tabs in his Heart he is in love with. She knows that as oon as her Lover begins to have Supicious, the leat care he hould take to remove them, would preerve in him the eteem and love he has for her; whereas if he neglected to atifie and cure him, he would come again to have o little Confidence in her, that he hould not be able to recover his good Opinion, tho he even offered him to loe her Reputation for his ake. She knows that a Lover would ever believe, that it would be the fear he was in of him, had forced thoe Sacrifices from her, that at another time he would have took for great Marks of love. She knows that in the Woman
a Man confides in, all is excued, and that nothing is pardoned in her that is ditruted. She knows that at length a Man comes to be fatigued with the trouble a Mitres gives him, and the reproaches that he has made her after having pardoned her a thouand coniderable Faults, that he breaks off upon a Trifle, the meaures being plain, and he not able to uffer any longer o much vexation.

There are Women who love their Gallants extreamly, and yet make them jealous by their ill carriage, and this proceeds from their lattering themelves too much with the aurance they have of their good Intentions, and for that they do not ufficiently quah the hopes of thoe men, who make Court to them, or who only eem to love them by their Cares and their Aiduities; and they are ignorant that the Civilities of a Woman one loves, are uch Favours as all Lovers flatter themelves with ometimes, becaue they have Merit; or often becaue they think they have o: Sometimes becaue they have no good Opinion of the Perons they make their Addrees to, and who fancy that the reitance that they make is only to et a greater value upon themelves. Inomuch, that if a Woman,
who has never given occaion to be talked of, is till very jealous of her Reputation, he ought to take care, as I have already aid, not to entertain in any manner the hopes of all that has the Air of a Lover, and if it is a Woman who has not thitherto been careful enough of her Carriage, but deigns to be o for the future, which is your cae, Madam, it is requiite that he be more rude than another, and epecially that he be impartial in her Severity, for the leat favour he hall let herelf looe to, does more reingage a Lover than a thouand Refuals does digut him.

An honet Mitres has o much incerity for her Lover, that rather than fail to tell him things of conequence, he tells him even what are trifles: Well knowing, that if he came to be informed by other means of certain indifferent things, that are rendred Criminal at their being told again, it would have the wort effect imaginable. She keeps no Meaures with him in point of Confidence, he tells him not only her own ecrets, but even thoe he knew before, or what he learns elewhere every day. She calls thoe people ridiculous, Who ay, that being Mitres of anothers Secrets, we ought not to tell it our Lovers: She anwers
to that, that if they till love us, they will never ay any thing of it: And if they happen to abandon us, we hould have much more to loe than our Friends ecret; but he fancies, we ought never to conider them, as uch as will one day leave off loving us, and that otherwie we hould be Fools to grant them Favours.

In a word, her Maxim is, That who gives her heart has nothing more to manage; he knows that there are only two Encounters that can dipence her from telling all to her Lover; the one if he was indicreet, and the other if he had any Gallantry before hers. For it would be imprudence in her to peak to him in that cae, at leat without he preed her extreamly, and then it would be he himelf that occaioned his own Vexation.

Finally, an honet Mitres believes that what jutifies her Love even with the mot evere Men, is, when he is deeply mitten, when he takes pleaure in making it appear to her Lover, when he urprizes him by a thouand little favours, that he did not expect; when he has no reerve for him; when he applies herelf to procure him eteem amongt all People: and that in a word, he makes of her Paion the greatet
buines of her Life: Without this, Madam, he holds Love for a Debauche, and that it is a Brutal Commerce, and a Trade by which ruined Women ubit.

Mademoielle de Cornuelle having left off peaking, Good God! aid Madam d' Olonne, what fine things have you now aid; but how difficult are they to be put in practice? I even find therein ome injutice; for in a word, ince we even deceive our Husbands, whom the Laws have made our Maters, why hould our Gallants come off at a better rate? They whom nothing obliges us to love but the choice we make, and whom we take to erve us as long, and as little as we pleae. I did not ay, anwered Mademoielle de Cornuelle, that we ought not to abandon our Gallants, when they dipleae us either by their own defects, or our wearines; but I have hown you the nice manner by which you ought to diengage your elf from them, not to give them any reaon to cry out upon you in the world: For in a word, Madam, ince they have impoed that tyranny upon the Honour of Ladies, not to love what they find lovely, we mut comply with Cutome, and conceal our elves at leat when we will love. Well! my Dear, aid Madam d' Olonne to her, I
am going to act wonders, I am fully reolved of it, but withal I ground the greatet hopes of my Conduct upon avoiding Occaions.

Whether it be by avoiding, or reitance, aid Mademoielle de Cornuelle, it is no matter, provided your Lover be atisfied with you; and thereupon having exhorted her to remain firm in her good Intentions, he took her leave.

During Madam d' Olonne's eparation from Marillac, they wrote to one another very often, but as there was nothing therein remarkable, I hall not mention their Letters, which poke of their love, and of their impatience to ee one another again, but in a very common manner. Madam d' Olonne was the firt who returned to Paris; the Count de Guiche during the Progres to Lyons, perwaded Monieur, the King's Brother, with whom he was much in favour, to have a Gallantry at his return to Paris with Madam d' Olonne, and had offered himelf to erve him in it, and to procure him content in a hort time. This Prince had promied the Count de Guiche to make the neceary Paces to engage that Cocquet, inomuch that in the Converations he had with Madam d' Olonne, he only
poke to her of the love that Prince had for her: He told her that he had declared it to him more than an hundred times upon the Journey, and that he would certainly ee him igh aoon as he was returned. A Woman who had Citizens and Gentlemen her Gallants, ome handome, others ugly, might well love a comely Prince, Madam a' Olonne received the Count de Guiche's Propoition with an unexpreible joy; and it was o great, that he did not o much as make thoe Excues which Coquets make in uch like Encounters. Another would have aid that he would not love any one, but les a Prince than any man oever, becaue he would not have o much application. Madam d' Olonne, who was the mot natural Woman in the World, and the mot paionate, kept no bounds of Modety, but anwered the Count de Guiche, That he eteemed herelf more than he had yet done, ince he pleaed o great and o rational a Prince. When the Court was returned to Paris, the Duke of Orleans did not anwer the eagernees, the Count had prepared Madam d' Olonne for, who delivered herelf all entirely. All this produced nothing, and made her but the more know how indifferent he was to that
Prince. The Count de Guiche eeing that the Duke of Orleans did not bite at the Hook, changed his Deign, and was deirous at leat that the Services he would have rendred to Madam d' Olonne, hould be of ome advantage to him. Whereupon he reolved to act the part of a Lover himelf, and being the Commerce he had had with her upon the Amours of the Duke of Orleans, had made him very familiar, he did not balance to write to her this Letter.

body.p:
WE have laboured hitherto in vain, Madam, the Queen haters you, and the Duke of Orleans apprehends dipleaing her, I have reaon to be in depair, Madam, but you can comfort me if you pleae, and I do Conjure you to do it, ince the natural harpnes of the Mother, and the weaknes of the Son, have ruined our Projects, other Meaures are to be taken. Let us love one another, Madam, it is already done on my part; and I eaily perceive, that had the Duke of Orleans loved you, I hould quickly have fallen out with him, becaue I hould not have been able to have reited the inclination I have for you. I do not quetion but that at firt you will be hocked at the difference,
but lay aide your Ambition, and you will not find your elf o mierable as you imagine. I am certain that when Spight hall have cat you into my Arms, Love will there retain you.

div.p:
Let People ay what they will againt Women, there is ometimes more imprudence than malice in their Conduct: Mot of them no longer think, when they are courted, that they ought never to love: In the mean time they proceed further than they imagine, they do things ometimes, thinking they hall be always Cruel, which they extreamly repent of, when they are become more Humane. The ame thing happened to Madam d' Olonne; he was tung to the quick that he had failed of the Prince's Heart, after having reckoned it amongt her Conquets; in eeking ome one to apply herelf to for the amuing her grief, he found nothing more likely to believe, than that the Count de Guiche for his own Interet had hindred him from loving her. Inomuch that as well to revenge herelf of him, as to reaure Marillac, whom this Intrigue had alarmed, he acrificed to him the Count de Guiche's Letter, without conidering that Love would perhaps oblige
her to do the ame with thoe of Marillac, and he whom Madam d' Olonne gave a thouand Favours to, made the ue of them that is common, when one is atisfied with his Mitres, he rendred her a thouand thanks for her Sincerity, and contented himelf with triumphing over his Rivals, without howing any indicreet Pride.

In the mean time the Count de Guiche not knowing the Detiny of his Letter, went the day after to Madam d' Olonne's Houe; but o much Company was there that day, that he could not peak to her about buines at that time. He only oberved that he had eyed him very much, and from her Houe he went to acquaint Fieque with the tate of his Affairs, who ince his return from Lyons, he had made his Conident; he went likewie to tell the ame to Vinevil; and they both judged by the weaknes of the Lady, and the Gentlenes of the Spark, that his puruit would neither be long nor in vain: And the truth is, Madam d' Olonne had found the Count de Guiche o handome, and o much to her mind, that he repented the Sacrifice he had newly made to Marillac. The day after the Count de Guiche returned to her Houe, and
having found her alone, he poke to her of his Paion, the fair One was pleaed, and received that Declaration the mot agreably imaginable; but after having agreed upon loving one another, as they were upon certain Conditions, People came in; which obliged the Count de Guiche to go out a Moment after.

Madam d' Olonne having diingaged herelf from her Company as oon as he was able, took Coach, being deirous to dicover if the Countes de Fieque took no Interet any longer in the Count de Guiche: She went to her, and after ome Converations upon other ubjects, he asked her advice in the Deignes he told her the Count de Guiche had for her. The Countes told her that he was only to conult her Heart in uch Occaions: My heart does not ay to me much in favour of the Count, replyed Madam d' Olonne, and my Reaon tells me a thouand things againt him: He is a Spark I can never love. In aying thee words, he took leave of the Countes, without waiting for her Anwer.

On the other ide the Count de Guiche being returned to his Houe, he met with Vinevil, who waited for him with great impatience to know what poture his Affairs
were in; the Count de Guiche told him omething coldly, that he believed all was broaken off, conidering how Madam d' Olonne treated him; and Vinevil deiring to know the particulars of the Converation, the Count de Guiche not being willing to dicover what paed, changed dicoure every moment; this gave ome upicions to Vineuil who was cunning and in love with Madam d' Olonne, and only concerned himelf in the affairs of the Count de Guiche, that he might prevail with his Mitres by the things he hould have learnt. He went away eeing he could not make any dicovery, and was for three days in mortal diquiets, not being able to learn the certainty of what he upected, and what he would know. He went to Fieque's Houe with the Countenance of a digraced Favourite, ince he aw he had no longer any hare in the Count de Guiche's confidenc, he aid nothing of it to that fair One, not to dicredit himelf in howing his Mifortune,

At three days end he went to the Count de Guiche's Houe. What have I done my Lord, aid he to him, that obliges you to treat me thus? I eaily perceive that you hide from me your intrigue with Madam de OOlonne,
learn me the reaon of it, or if you have none, continue to tell me what you know as you ued to do I ask your pardon my poor Vinevil, aid the Count de Guiche to him, but Madam d' Olonne upon granting me enjoyment, exacted from me not to peak thereof to you nor to Fieque, much les then to any others, becaue he aid that you are malicious, and Fieque jealous. How indicreet oever a peron is, there is no Intrigue but what's kept ecret in the beginning, if there be no need of a Confident: This I have had experience of in this Occaion, for I am naturally enough inclined to tell an amourous adventure: And yet I have been three dayes without acquainting you with this, tho you know all my ecrets; but have patience, my Dear, I am going to tell you all that paed between Madam d' Olonne and me, and by the exactet Relation in the World, in ome manner requite the offence done to the friendhip I have for you.

You know then that the firt Viit made her, after having written to her the Letter you have een, I did not ind in her looks any averion or kindnes; and the Company that was at her houe hindred me from having any further information. All that I could remarke was, that he oberved me from time to time; but returning thither the day after, and having found her
alone, I repreented my love to her o well, and o eagerly preed her to make returns to it, that he Confeed he loved me, and promied to give me marks thereof upon Condition I have newly told you. You know very well that I would promie her all in thoe moments; we heard a noie, inomuch that Madam d' Olonne bid me come again the next day dreed in Womens Cloathes, and as one who brought her Lace to fell; whereupon being returned to my Houe, I found you there, and you might eaily perceive by the cold reception I made you, that all the World importuned me at that time, and particularly you, my Dear, whom I was more jealous of than any one; you likewie perceived it, and it was that which made you upect I did not tell you all: when you was gone, I gave order that my Porter hould ay I was not at home, and prepared my elf for my Macarade of the Morrow: All the pleaure that imagination can give beforehand, I had for four and twenty hours together: The four or five lat hours were more tedious than all the others; at length that which I expected with o much impatience, being come, I caued my elf to be carryed to Madam d' Olonne's Houe, I found her
in a Cornet upon her Bed, in a Roe Colour Undres. I cannot expres to you my Dear, how beautifull he was that day, all that can be aid, comes hort of the Charms he had: her Neck was half uncovered, he had more Hair looe than uual, and all in rings and curles, her Eyes were more parkling than the Stars. Love and the colour of her Face animated her Complexion with the finet Vermillion in the World. Well, my Dear, aid he to me, are not you full of acknowledgment that I pare you the pains of ighing a long time? do you find that I make you pay too dear for the Favours you receive? Tell me my Dear, added he, but you are mute. Ah! Madam anwered I her, I hould be inenible were I in cold Blood, eeing you in this poture. But may I aure my elf, aid he, that you have forgotten little Beauvais and the Countes of Fieque? yes aid I to her, Madam, you may; and how hould I remember others, added I, ince you may perceive I haue almot forgot my elf? I only fear, replyed he, the future; for for the preent, my Dear, I am much mistaken if I uffer you to think of any Body beides myelf; And in finihing thee words he took me about the Neck, and preing me you know how with her Arms, he
pulled me upon her; Both of us lying in manner, we kied ill one another a thouand times: But not willing to top there, and this eeking for omething more olid; but on my part in vain. We ought to know our elves, and what we are fit for: For my part I perceive I am no Womans man. It was impoible for me to come off with Honour, what effect oever my fancy made, and the Idea and the preence of the mot beautifull Object in the World. What's the matter aid he to me, My Lord, What ales you, What is it that puts you in o ad a Condition? Is it my Peron that diguts you, or do you only bring me the leavings of an other? This Dicoure made me o ahamed and out of Countenance, my Dear, that it quite deprived me of the forces I had left. I beg of you, Madam, aid I to her, not to ruine a wretch with reproaches! Certainly I am bewitched. In tead of giving me an anwer he called her Chamber-Maid, Prethee tell me Quentine how do I look to day? am not I very ugly? Do not deceive your Lady, there is omething about me that does not it well? Quentine not daring to anwer eeing her in that rage, Madam d' Olonne natching alooking-Glas from her he held in her hands? After having made all the getures
he ued to do when he deigned to Charm any one to judge if my inufficiency proceeded from her fault or mine. She got up and haked her Petticoat that was omething ruffled, and went in a fury into her Cloet that tood by her Bed-ide. For my part, I was like a Condemned Man, I asked my elf if all that had paed was not a Dream, with all the reflections that one can make in uch an Encounter; I went to Manicamps Houe, where having related to him all my adventure. I am mightly obliged to you, my Dear aid he to me, for certainly it was for the love of me that you were o inenible near o pretty a Woman. Tho perhaps you may be the Caue of it, aid I to him, I did it not to oblige you; I love you extreamely, and I do confes it; but with all that I had forgot you in that occaion; I do not Comprehend o extraordinary an Obligation by quitting the habit of a Man: I had quitted you before, but that part is dead in me, by which I have been hitherto a kind of Chancellour. As I had done peaking, one of my Servants brought me a Letter from Madam d' Olonne that one of hers had given him, here it is in my Pocket; in aying that the Count read this Letter to Vinevil.

body.p: IF I was a lover of Venereal pleaures, I hould lament my having been diappointed, but far from complaining; I am obliged to your inufficiency, it is the caue that in the expectation of delights you were not able to give me, I enjoyed others by imagination that lated much longer than thoe you could have been capable of furnihing, tho you had been as well provided as an other Man. I end at preent to know how you do, and if you were able to get a foot to your Lodgings: It is not without reaon that I make this inquiry, for I never aw a Man under uch ad Circumtances as you were when I left you. I Counel you to ettle your Affairs with more natural heat than you had when I aw you; for you cannot live much longer. Really my Lord, you raie my pity, and what outrage oever I have received from you, I hall not forbear giving you good advice. Avoid Manicamp if you are wie, you may recover your health, if you leave off eeking him for ome time, it is certainly from him that your impotence proceeds: for my part neither my Glas nor my looks belying me, I do not fear being either accued or reproached.

div.p: I had no ooner made an end of reading this Letter, than that I made her this anwer.

p.hi: I Confes, Madam I have had failings in my lifetime, for I am a man, and till young; but I never had a wore than that lat Night. It is not to be excued Madam, and tho your entence be never o evere, it can be but what I have deerved: I have killed, I have betrayed, I have committed acriledge; for all thee Crimes you need only eek out punihments, if you pleae, my Death, I will bring you my word; if you only condemn me to be whipt, I will come naked to you in my hirt; Remember Madam, that I failed in Power, not in Will; I was like a Brave oldier who finds himelf without Arms when he hould engage: I hould be extreamly puzzel'd Madam, to tell you from whence this prov'd; perhaps it happend' to me as it does to thoe whoe tomack is gone when they expect to eat mot, perhaps the force of Imagination conumed the force of Nature. See what it is, Madam, to be o Charming. An Ordinary Beauty who hould not have troubled the Coure of nature, would have been better entertained. Adieu, Madam, I have nothing more to ay to you, but that perhaps you would pardon me what is pat, if you would give me the opportunity of doing better herafter, to which purpoe I only demand till to morrow at the ame hour as yeterday.

div.p:
After having ent by one of my Footmen thee fair promies to Madam d' Olonne's Lacquis, who waited for an anwer at my Houe, I went home, and not doubting, but that my offers would be kindly received, I reolved to take all imaginable Care of my elf: I bathed and was rubbed with Eences, I eat new laid Eggs and Artichoaks, and then drunk ome Wine; I walked a while in my Chamber, and then went to Bed without Manicamp. My Head was o full of the deign of repairing my fault that I hun'd my Friends as I would have done the Plague. I got up the next day brisk both in Body and mind, I dined betimes, and eat what was Provocative, but as little as I had done at Supper; and having pent the Afternoon in preparing my little Equipages of Love, I went to Madam d' Olonne's Houe, at the ame hour as the time before. I found her upon the ame Bed, which made me immediately apprehend that it portended me ome ill Fortune; but in a word, having encouraged my elf as much as I could, I cat my elf at her Knees. She was half undret, and held a Fan he played with. So oon as he aw me he bluht a little, without doubt remembring the late affront he had received
and Quentine being retired, I placed my elf by her upon the Bed. The firt thing he did was to put her Fan before her Eyes, and that having rendred her as bold as if there had been a Wall between us both. Ah! Well, aid he to me, poor Paralitick, are you come here a compleat Man to day? Ah! Madam anwered I to her, let us talk no more of what is pat: And thereupon thundering into her Arms, I kied her a thouand times, and begged he would let me ee her naked: after a little reitance that he made to augment my Deires, and to affect Modety, which becomes a Woman o well, rather than out of any ditrut he had of her elf, he let me ee all I had a mind to. I aw a curious, white, plump and the bet proportioned Body in the world. After that I fell again to embracing her, we already made a noie with macking and Buing, our hands already claped in one another, expreed the utmot tendernees of love; already the mixture of our loves had made the union of our Bodies, when he perceived the ad pickle I was in. It was then that eeing I continued to outrage her, he thought of nothing but vengeance; he called me all manner of ill names, he there attended me
with the greatet violence imaginable. For my part without making either Prayers or Complaints, knowing what I had deerved, I went home in a fury and having put my elf to Bed, I turned all my choler againt the caue of my Digrace.

q.l: Fury then eiz'd me, patience me forook
A Razor in my hand, enrag'd I took,
But my deigne I found was all in vain,
Being the Author of my hameful pain.
All in a fright, and quite froze up with fear,
Some wrinckles of it only did appear.
And towards it's Center eem'd to crow'd, I thought,
And thus for refuge in my Belly ought.

div.p:
So that not being able to do any thing, the rage I was in made me talk to my elf much to this purpoe. Ah! Traytor, what hat thou to ay, infamous part of my elf, and really hameful Member, for it would be very ridiculous to give thee an other name? Tell me, have I ever obliged thee to ue me in this manner? and make me receive the cruellet Affronts in the World? to make me abue the favours that are done me? and being but two and twenty make me have the infirmities of old
Age? while that Choler made me peak thus.

l.hi: My Eyes towards Heaven I then did ghatly turn,
My cruel Fate I did lament and mourn;
I aw that all reproaches were in vain
To talk to it, to rocks was to complain.

div.p: I pent the Night in mortal Agonies, I knew not if I ought to write to Madam d' Olonne, or urprie her by an unexpected Viit: at lenght after having been a long time conidering, I choe to do the lat, at the hazard of finding an obtacle to our pleaures; but I was o happy as to find her a lone; jut as it grew dark. She had put her elf to Bed as oon as I was gone from her; At my Coming into her Chamber I told her, Madam, I come either to dy at your feet or give you atisfaction, I begg you would not be in a rage, I know what I have merited.

Madam d' Olonne, who feared as much as I did uch an other michance as thoe that had happned to me, took care not to daunt me with reproaches; on the contrary he told me all that might re-etablih in me a good opinion of my elf which I
had almot lot; and faith, if I was enchanted, as I told her, two dayes before I break the Charme, the third time you may imagine, added the Count de Guiche, that he called me no ill names at parting, as he had done the other times: This is the tate of our Intrigue, which I begg you would eem to be ignorant of: Vinevil having promied him he would, they parted, the Count de Guiche went to the Countes of Fieque's Houe, to whom amongt other things he aid he had no thoughts of Madam d' Olonne.

This Gallant's Intrigue had not continued long with his new Mitres when Marillac dicovered it, tho he had o little ence, and he had taken all imaginable care to deceive him; but jealouy that erves in tead of cunning, made him dicover in her les eagernes for him than was uual. Inomuch that having made her ome Modet Complaints in the beginning, and afterwards more harp ones, eeing at length they did not at all retrain her, he reolved to revenge himelf at one blow, both of his Rival and his Mitres. Whereupon he gave his friends, Madam d' Olonne's Letters, and deired them to how 'em in all Companies. Mademoielle d' Orleans hated
the Count de Guiche extreamly. He gave her the Letter the Count had written to his Mitres, in which he had poken ill of the Queen and the Duke of Orleans. The firt thing the Prince did was to how the Duke of Orleans the Count de Guiche's Letter, thinking to animate him o much the more againt him, for that he knew that Prince had had a great kindnes for him: however that Prince was not in o great a paion as he hoped he would have been, and contented himelf with telling Pequelain that his Coin was ungrateful that he had never given him reaon to talk of him as he did, and that all the reentment he hould have of it was, to have no longer the ame eteem for him he had had; but if the Queen knew after what manner he had talked of her, he would not certainly have o much moderation as he had. The Princes not being well pleaed to ee his Royall highnes o favourable, to the Count de Guiche, reolved to tell the Queen, and having acquainted one of her Confidents with her deign, the Marhal of Grammont came to hear of it. He went and beeeched her not to ruine his on; he promied him he would not, and kept her word. This Princes was haughty and did not eaily pardon
People, who had not for her all the repect her illutrious Birth and extraordinary Merit obliged all the World to; but when he was once perwaded they loved her, nothing was o good natured as he.

While that the Marhall and his Friends were endeavouring to tifle the Noie that Marillac had made with the Count de Guiche's Letter, Madam d' Olonne was known to how this for the breaking of a Marriage that made Marillac's fortune.

You do not think, Madam of the contraint I am in, I am orced to go two or three times a Week to viit Mademoielle de Rochegayon, to talk to her as if I loved her, and to this purpoe mut pend that time I ought only to employ in eeing, writing and thinking of you: and in what Condition oever I may be, it would be a great trouble to me to be obliged to keep company with a Child: but now that I live only for your ake, you may very well imagine that it is to me the cruellet of Tortures: that which makes me take patience in ome manner, is that I hope to revenge my elf on her by marrying her without loving her, and after that eeing more nearly the difference there is between you and her I hall love you all my life time, yet
more if it was poible than I do at preent.

This at firt urprized all the World: Thitherto indicreet Gallants had only been found, and never Mitrees: They could not imagine that a Woman to revenge her elf of a Man he no longer loved, would help one in that manner to convict herelf. This indicretion had not however the effect that Madam d' Olonne had promied herelf: Monieur de Liancourt, Mademoielle de la Rochegayon's Father, knowing that Madam d' Olonne was deirous to incene him againt Marillac, anwered thoe who poke to him of that Letter, That were it not for offending God, Marillac could not do better than apply himelf to gain the Heart of o beautyful a Lady as Madam d' Olonne; that this was not the firt time that Wives were poke ill of at Mitrees Bed-ide: But as the paion Men had for her, was more violent than that they had for others, it did not uually lat o long: As for example, that of Marillac was not o fixed to Madam d' Olonne, and he till loved Mademoielle de la Rochegayon. So that Madam d' Olonne did not poil Marillac's Fortune, as he hoped to have done; and only confirming what he had aid of her; he deprived her friends of the means of vindicating her.

Things being in thee termes and the Count de Guiche remaining Mater in appearance, Madam d' Olonne went one Evening to the Countes of Fieque, he prayed her to make her acknowledgments to the Abbot Foucquett for ome ervice he pretended to have received from him, and to exaggerate very highly the obligation he had to him: But the Abbot being one of the principal Peronages of this Hitory, it is requiite to decribe how he was made.

The Abbot Foucquett, the Treaurers Brother, was originally of Anjou, his Family were Gown-men till this Man made his Fortune, and then as Noble as the King. His Eyes were blew and lively, a handome Noe, a great Forehead, a pointed Chin, the form of his Face was flat, his Hair was a bright brown, his hape was ordinary, and his meen bae; his Conduct in the World was quite contrary to his profeion, he was active ambitious, and haughty towards People; he did not love, but the mot ardent and bet Friend that ever was; he had engaged himelf in an Amourous Intrigue more out of Pride than out of love; but afterwards Love became Mater: The firt Woman he had made love to was Madam de Chevruee,
of the Houe of Lorraine, by whom he was entertained with a very great Paion, the other was Madam de Chastillon, who in the Favours he had granted him, had more conidered her Intrets than her Pleaures: he being one of the mot Beautyfull and extraordinary Women of France, it is Convenient to make here the Decription of her Life.
LOVES EMPIRE; Or, The GALLANTRIES Of the FRENCH COURT. The Second Part.
LONDON, Printed for Dorman Newman. 1682.

div.head: LOVES EMPIRE, &c.
THE HISTORY OF Madam de Chatillon.
div.p:
HER Grace, the Dutches de Chatillon, Monieur de Bouteville's Daughter, who was Beheaded for having fought a Duel, contrary to the Edicts
of the late King, Lewis the Fourteenth's Father, Wife of Gapard Duke of Chatillon, had black and lively Eyes, a little Forehead, a handome Noe, a red Lip, and full Mouth, her Complexion was as he thought fit, but he had uually white and red, he was o Charming when he miled, that he et all hearts on a flame; her Hair was very black, he was tall, had a good Aire, but long, dry, and black hands, her Arms were flat, and of the ame colour, which made People draw ill Concluions of thoe parts they did not ee: She had a loft and agreeable Wit, was ininuating and given to flattery, was faithles, intereed and uncapable of Friendhip; and yet what Experience oever Men had had of her ill Qualities, when he had a mind to Charm, it was impoible for them to forbear loving her; he had ome ways with her that were very tempting, and others that made her be depied by all People; for Money and Honours he would have dihonoured herelf, and have acrificed Father, Mother, and Lovers.

Coligny being under Age when he married his Wife, it rendred his Marriage invalid, but being of Age at his Return, a Contract of Marriage was made in the Hostel of Condé before all the young Ladies Relations, and they were afterwards married in Notre Dame by the Coadjutor of Paris. Sometime after Madam de Chatillon being indipoed, went to the Wells, where he met with the Duke of Nemours, who fell in love with her.

The Duke of Nemours had very white Hair, a handome Noe, a little Mouth, and of a fine Colour, and was the prettiet hape Man imaginable: The leat of his Actions was attended with an unexpreible Grace, his Humour was gay, wanton and toying, and his Will was admirable brisk and quaint. The liberty of eeing one another at all hours, which Cutom has introduced in Places where the Waters are taken, gave a thouand opportunities to the Duke of Nemours of acquainting his Mitres with his Paion: But knowing that an Amorous Intrigue was never better regulated, at leat with Ladies we have ome eteem for, than by making a Declaration by word of Mouth or by Writing: He reolved to peak; and being one day alone with her at her Lodgings, I have been above three weeks, Madam, aid he to her, conidering whether I hould tell you the impreion your Charms have made upon my heart; and when I determined at length to acquaint you with it, it is after having een all the Difficulties that I can find in this Deign: I do my elf Jutice, Madam, and for that reaon I ought not to entertain any hopes. Beides, you have lately married a beloved Lover, and it is a difficult
Enterprize to remove him out of your heart, and to put my elf in his place. However I love you, Madam, and tho you hould not to be ungrateful, make ue of that reaon againt me, I confes that it is my Star, and not my Choice that obliges me to love you. Madam de Chastillon never had had o much joy as this Dicoure gave her. Monieur de Nemours appeared to her o lovely, that if it had been the Cutom for Women to have made Declarations of Love firt, he would not have deferred it o long as her Gallant did. But the fear of not eeming modet enough perplexed her o extreamly, that he was ometime without knowing what Anwer to make. At length forcing herelf to peak for the concealing the diorder that her ilence made appear; You are in the right my Lord, aid he to him, with all imaginable potures, to believe that I love my Husband very much; but give me leave to tell you, that you do your elf wrong in being o Modet as you are: And if I was in a Condition to acknowledge the kindnes you have for me, you would ee that others eteem you more than you do your elf. Ah! Madam, replyed the Duke of Nemours, it is in your power, Madam, and
only in yours, to make me the mot happy and mot eteemed Man in France. He had hardly finihed thee words, then that the Countes of Maure came into the Chamber, before whom it was requiite to change Converation, tho thee two Lovers did not change their thoughts; Their ditraction and diorder made the Countes of Maure judge that their Intrigue was much more advanced than it really was, and for this reaon he was preparing to make a very hort Viit, when the Duke of Nemours prevented her. The amorous and dicreet Prince well knowing that he acted but an ill part before uch a harp-ighted Woman as the Countes of Maure was, went out, and being got home, he wrote this Letter to his Mitres.

body.p:
I Leave you, Madam, that I may be more with you then I was; the Countes of Maure oberved me, and I durst not look upon you; and he being cunning, I was even afraid that my Affection would dicover me; for in hort, Madam, it is o well known that People mut eye you when they are in the ame place, that thoe that do not are upected of ome Deign. If I do not ee you at preent, Madam, at leat it is not perceived that I am in love, and I
have the liberty of acquainting you only with it. How happy hould I be, Madam, were I able to perwade you, to the point it is, and how unjut would you be in that cae, Madam, if you had not ome kindnes for me.

div.p:
Madam de Chatillon was very much perplexed at the receipt of this Letter; he knew not whether he had bet be cruel or kind. Kindnes might gain the heart of her Lover, and Severity his eteem, and both might digut him. At length he reolved to do what was mot difficult, as being mot honet: And notwithtanding all that her heart inpired her with, he choe rather to follow the counel of her Reaon: Wherefore he made the Duke no Anwer; and as he came on the Morrow into her Chamber, Are you come again my Lord, aid he to him, to commit ome new Offence? becaue my humour and looks are eaie and oft, you think there is no more to do than falling on: And if your eteem is only to be purchaed by rudenes, et that value on it as to contrain my elf for ome time: Yes, my Lord, I hall be angry, and I perceive I mut be o with you. Thee lat words were as a Thunder-clap fallen upon this poor Lover; tears came into his Eyes, and his tears poke much better for him
than all he could have aid. After having been a moment without peaking, I am infinitely grieved, Madam, anwered he her, to ee you thus in anger; and I wih I was dead ince I have dipleaed you. You hall ee, Madam, that in the Vengeance I am reolved to take of the offence you have received, that your interets are much more dear to me than my own; I am going o far from you, Madam, that my Love hall no longer importune you. This is not what I require of you, interrupted that fair One, you may till tay here, without dipleaing me. Cannot you ee me without telling me you love me, or at leat without writing me it? No, no, Madam, replyed he, it is abolutely impoible. Well then, my Lord, I conent that you ee me, replyed Madam de Chatillon; but oberve well all that I do for you. Ah! Madam, interrupted the Duke, throwing himelf at her feet, if I have adored you when you were o cruel, judge what I hall do when you are kind: Yes, Madam, be pleaed to gues at it, for it is impoible for me to expres the ene I have of it. This Converation did not end as it began: Madam de Chatillon dipened herelf from keeping all the rigour he had promied herelf,
and if the Duke of Nemours had not great Favours, at leat he had hopes of being beloved. In confidence of this he was no ooner got home, then that he wrote this Letter to his Mitres.

p.hi: AFter having told me, Madam, that you conented I hould ee you, ince it was impoible for me to ee you without telling you that I love you, or at least without writing it, I ought to write to you in confidence that my Letter will not be ill received: However, I tremble, Madam, and Love that is never without fears of dipleaing, makes me imagine, that you may have changed your mind within thee three hours: Do me the favour, Madam, to inform me by two Lines. If you knew with what ardour I deire it, and with what tranports of joy I hall receive it, you would not judge me unworthy of this Grace.

div.p: Madam de Chatillon had no ooner received this Letter, then that he made this Anwer.

p.hi: WHy hould I have changed my Mind, my Lord? but my God, how preing you are! Are not you atisfied with knowing your power, and mut you needs triumph likewie over anothers weaknes?

div.p:
The Duke of Nemours received this Letter
with uch a joy, as put him almot out of himelf, he kied it a thouand times, not being able to forbear reading of it. In the mean time the Paion of thee two Lovers augmented every day; and Madam de Chatillon, who had already yielded up her heart, no longer defended the ret, but only to render it the more coniderable by the difficulty. In hort, the time of taking the Waters being paed, they were to part, and tho they both returned to Paris, they both imagined they hould not ee one another again with o much Conveniency as they had done at Bourbon: In the view of thee Difficulties their Farewel was very moving! The Duke of Nemours aured his Mitres more by his tears that he hould ever love her, than by the things he aid to her; and the contraint that Madam de Chatillon ued not to weep, had the ame effect in her Lover: They parted very ad, but deeply perwaded that they would love one another paionately, & that they hould ever do o. They eldom met the ret of the Autumn, becaue they were oberved; but Letters paed often between them.

In the beginning of Winter, the Civil War which begun to break forth, obliged the King to leave Paris omething urprizeingly,
and retire to St. Germains. At that time, the Marhal, Coligny's Father, happened to dye, and the Prince of Condé, who was then the Cardinal of Mazarine's right Arm, obtained the Patent of Duke and Peer for his Coin de Coligny. The Troops coming from all parts, the City was blocked up; the Court however did not eem very ad, and the Courtiers and Souldiers were over-joyed at the ill poture of Affairs; the Cardinal only, whom they might ruin, concealed part of them from the Queen, and all from the young King, whom when they talked to of War, it was only to acquaint him with the defeats of the Enemies, and the ret of the time they amued him in Plays that were utable to his Age: Amongt other Perons with whom he loved to play, the Dutches of Chatillon held the firt rank; and hereupon Bencrade made this Sonnet under her Husband's Name.

l.hi: For another Lover,
Tho you tand with open Arms,
And keep a mighty Pother.
The King's too young to quench the Fires
Of uch an eager Beauty.
How can uch raging hot deires
Be till'd by Minority.

div.p: In thee little Playes the Duke of Nemours did not loe his time, they ever furnihed the Dutches and him with occaions of giving one another tetimonies of their love; and by the ame degrees that the paion of thee two Lovers augmented, their prudence did the Contrary: it was oberved that at a Play called the Bohemien they placed themelves oppoite to one another, and were always whipering, and that when one was blind-folded, the other tood o as to be caught; to the end that the hand in eeking to know who it was that was taken might have a pretext to feel every where: In hort there was not one of thee Plays but what furnihed them with the means of tickling their amourous fancy.

In the mean time the Prince of Condé, was wholly taken up in Contriving how to reduce the People of Paris by Famine, to deliver the Parliament, that had promied a um to thoe who would bring the Cardinals Head, fancyed that the taking of Charenton would much advance this Succes, which Clanle guarded with five or ix hundred Men: he reaembled part of the Quarters, and with a thouand Men, at the head of whom Gaton of France, the
King's Unkle, and Lieutenant General of the Regency, would needs place himelf, he came to Attack Charenton in three places. As the Retrenchments at the Avenues were but bad, it was not difficult for the King's Troops to force them. But the Duke of Chastillon, who commanded the Attacks under the Prince was wounded in the belly with a Musket hot in the Burrough, of which he dyed the Night after. The Prince regretted him extreamly, and his grief was o violent that it could not lat. By what had paed you may judge that the Dutchees Affliction was not very great, and you may judge it much better by what hall happen in the equel; however he wept, he tore her Hair, and made appear the Appearances of the greatet Depair imaginable, the Publick was o deceived, that this Sonnet was made upon his death.

l.hi: Jut as the Court the Honours did prepare

lg.l: That Chatillon had merited by his Arms,

l.hi: Death did deprive us of this Conquerour,
And natch'd him from the midst of great Alarms.

lg.l: How great was, fairet Dutches, your Depair,
When you had lot all hopes of his return,
All must have wept who aw you tare your Hair,
Or ele their Hearts with Love did ever burn.

l.hi: In uch a ad Etate, o strange urprize

lg.l: Never Alcionne, nor Artenie

l.hi: Of Fate with o much reaon could complain:
You igh, you weep, but all's, alas in vain.

div.p:
The Duke of Nemours, who was better informed than the ret of the World, was not atonihed at Madam de Chatillon's affliction: He timed his buines o well, that the exces of grief had altered in that poor depairing fair One, and was o earnet with her to grant him Enjoyment, that the fear he had had of her Husband, had hindred her from allowing him during his life, that he made an Aignation with him on the day of his Burial. Bordeaux, one of her Women, who ancied that the Duke's death would ruin the Fortune of Ricoux, who ought her in Marriage, was under a real Affliction; inomuch that when he aw the Duke of Nemours upon the point of receiving the leat Favours from her Mitres, on a day that the mot diolute contrain themelves, the horrour of this action redoubled her grief, and without going out of the Chamber, he diturbed the pleaure
of thoe Lovers by her ighs and by her tears. The Duke well-eeing that if he did not appeae this Woman, he hould not have for the future in his Amour all the weetnes that he wihed for, took care to comfort her, at his going out, and told her that he was enible of the los he had of the Duke; but that he would be a Friend to her, and take care of her Fortune as the deceaed had done; and that he hould find as much good will in him as he had done in the other, and perhaps more power; and that till he could do omething coniderable for her, he deired her to receive Four thouand Crowns that he would end her on the morrow. Thee words had o much virtue that Bordeaux wiped away her tears, and promied the Duke to enteree herelf for him as long as he lived; and told him that her Mitres had all the reaon in the World not to pare any thing for the giving him marks of her Love. On the Morrow Bordeaux had the Four thouand Crowns which the Duke had promied her, and ince that time he erved him preferably to all thoe who would not give her o much.

The Peace being made, in the beginning of the Spring, the Court returned to Paris. The Prince, who had newly freed the
Cardinal out of a dangerous buines, old him his Services at a very dear rate, that he had done him in that War. The Cardinal was not only unable to perform what he daily demanded of him; but was not able to upport the Inolence with which he demanded Favours: The Government of Pont de Letreht, that the Prince had forced from him for his Brother in Law the Duke of Longueville, contrary to the intention of the Court, and the boldnes with which he had exacted from the Queen that he hould ee Geré, after the confidence he had had to write an Amorous Ticket to her Majety, made the Cardinal at length reolve to free himelf from the tyranny he was under, under pretext of revenging the Contempt that was had of the Royal Authority; he communicated this Deign to the Duke of Orleans, who remembred his Exempt's broken Staff by the Prince, and who for that and the jealouie of his great Merit, had reaons to hate him; and the Cardinal letting him know that Riviere, who governed him, was the Prince's Penioner, he made him give his word that he would conceal this Affair from his Favourite. The Prince of Condé, the Prince of Conty, and the Duke of Longueville their Brother in Law, were
took into Cutody in the Palace where the King then lodged: In the mean time Monieur Thurenne, who for the Engagements he had with the Prince of Condé, had reaon to fear being taken, and who beides was enraged againt the Court for the Principality of Sedan, which his Family was deprived of, withdrew to Sthney, where Madam de Longueville arrived preently after, and the Prince's Officers cat themelves into Bellegarde; Madam de Chatillon applyed herelf to the Princes Dowager, and engaged the Duke of Nemours her Lover in her Interets.

Sometime after that the Princes were in Prion. The Princes Dowager had leave to go tay at her Coins Madam de Chatillon's. A Priet called Cambiac, who had introduced himelf to Madam de Bouteville's, by the means of Madam Brienne, was ent to Madam de Chatillon by her Mother; he had not been there long, but that he governed her, inomuch that he interpoed between her and the Duke of Nemours. This Commerce giving him occaion of having great Familiarities with Madam de Chatillon, he fell in love with her, and to that degree, as to aint away as he was aying Mas. The Princes Dowager falling into that fit of
Sicknes, which he died of, Cambiac, who had acquired great Credit with her, employed it in favour of Madam de Chatillon: He procured her a hundred thouand Crowns worth of Jewels, and the Lordhip of Marlou for her life, which was worth two thouand pounds a year. The Duke of Nemours, whom the cares of Cambiac for Madam de Chatillon had omething alarm'd, was quite jealous at the News of the Princees Will. He did not believe that it was eaie to reit uch coniderable Service; and though he could not blame his Mitres for having received them, he was enraged that he was obliged for them to a Man whom he conidered as his Rival. And he was not mitaken; for what Cambiac had done had cot that fair One Favours; for though he loved the Duke of Nemours bet, he loved Riches bet of all. However, as he had no longer occaion for Cambiac after the Princees death, it was not difficult for her to et her Lovers mind at ret, by turning off that poor Priet.

The Coadjutour of Paris, and Madam de Chevreue, who had been in the Plot of eizing the Princes, finding that the Cardinal became too inolent, caued the Duke of Orleans to take it into conideration, and repreented
to him that if he contributed to the Liberty of the Princes, he would not only be reconciled with them, but would engage them altogether in his Interets, beides the deign of weakning the Cardinal's Authority, which gave ombrage to the Party called la Fronde, every one had till his particular Interet. Madam de Chevreue would have had the Prince of Conty, for whom the Court had demanded a Cardinals Cap at Rome, to have married her Daughter; and the Coadjutour would be ubrogated to the nomination of the Prince. It was upon this promie that the Princes of Condé and Conty gave under their hands to Madam de Chevreue, that he and the Coadjutour endeavoured to free them out of Prion. The thing having ucceeded as they had projected; and the Cardinal himelf having been contrained to leave France, the Prince had no moderation in his new Properity, and this obliged the Court to entertain new Deignes upon his Peron. He withdrew immediately to his Houe at Saint Maure, and ometime after to Monrond, and from thence to his Government of Guyenne. The Duke of Nemours followed him, and Madam de Longueville, who was with her Brother, being taken with his
Merit, had o much Complaiance for him, that this Prince, tho very much in love elewhere, could not reit her; but yielded through the weaknes of the Fleh, rather than the inclination of the heart. The Duke of Rochefoucault, who had been for three years the beloved Gallant of Madam de Longueville, aw the Infidelity of his Mitres with all the rage that can be had in uch like Occaions. But he being full of a great Paion for the Duke of Nemours, was not at all careful to pleae her ancient Lover. The firt time that he aw the Duke of Nemours in private, he asked him in the mot paionate moment of the Aignation, what had paed between him and Madam de Chatillon: The Duke having anwered her that he had not had any Favour: Ah! I am undone, aid he to him, ince in the Poture we are in at preent, you have the power to conceal the truth. This Commerce did not lat long, and the Duke of Nemours not being able to force himelf to pretend love where he had none; and you may imagine that the Princes, who was naty, and had an ill mell with her, could not conceal her ill Qualities from a Man, who was infinitely in love elewhere. Thee Diguts did likewie further the Journey that the Duke of Nemours
was to make into Flanders, to bring a Succour of Strangers to the Princes Party: But the real caue of his impatience was, to ee Madam de Chatillon again, whom he ever loved more than his life; whereupon he paed through Paris, where he aw her again, and put her into that wretched Condition that may be called the Shipwrack of Widows. When he perceived her misfortune, he ought for the means to be freed from it. Des Fougerets, a famous Phyician, undertook this Cure, and while he had her in hand, the Prince of Condé, returned from Guyenne to Paris, and brought la Rochefoucault with him.

The Prince had lively Eyes, a Hawks and harp Noe, hollow lean Cheeks, a long Face, and the Phyiognomy of an Eagle, frizled Hair, his Teeth were ill et and naty, a careles Aire, had but little care of his Peron, but was well haped; his Wit had a great deal of flame, but was not exact, he laughed much and diagreably, his Genius was admirable for War, and particularly for Battails. On the day of Battail he was mild to Friends, and fierce to Enemies: He had an unparallel'd neatnes of Wit, force of Judgment, and eaines of Expreion; he was Roguihly inclined, but
had Faith and Probity in great Occaions: He was naturally inolent and without regard, but Adverity had taught him how to live. This Prince finding himelf dipoed to fall in love with the Dutches, La Rochefoucault helped till to inflame him by the great deire he had of being revenged on the Duke of Nemours. Rochfoucault perwaded him to give her the Propriety of Marlou, which he had only the uu-fruit of, telling him that Madam de Chatillon was younger than he, and that this Preent would only injure his Poterity; and that a Lordhip of two thouand pounds a year, more or les, would neither render him richer nor poorer.

When the Prince fell in love with Madam de Chatillon, he was in the hands of Des Fougorets, who made ue of Vomits to free her of thoe ill Circumtances. The Prince, who was continually at her Bedide, asked her what her Sicknes was; he told him that he believed he was poyoned. This Lover being extreamly grieved to ee his Mitres in danger of her life, told the Apothecary, who erved her, that he would caue him to be hanged: This poor man not daring to jutifie himelf, went and told Bordeaux, who was married to Ricoux,
that if he was preed too much, he would tell all. In hort, the Remedies had the effect that they had promied themelves: And hortly after this Cure, the Prince having given her Marlou, Madam de Chatillon was not ungrateful, but he only gave him the uu-fruit of what the Duke of Nemours had the Propriety. However, Rochefoucault took full Vengeance of the Duke of Nemours, and gave him dipleaures by o much the more cutting, that he had not the power to cure himelf of his Paion, as Rochefoucault had done of that he had had for Madam de Longueville. Beides Rochefoucault, Vinevil was likewie the Prince's Confident, who in erving him with his Mitres, endeavoured likewie to be beloved himelf. Vinevil was the Preident d' Ardiers Brother, of a pretty good Family in Paris, had a pleaing Face, much Learning, and was a well-bred man: His Humour was pleaant and Satyrical, tho very fearful; this had often brought him into trouble; he was undertaking with Women, and that made him almot always uccesful, he had had an Intrigue with Madam de Montbazon, Madam de Movy, and likewie with the Princes of Wittembergh: And this lat Gallantry had o embroiled him, with the
late Duke of Chatillon, that without the Prince's protection he would have uffered ome Violences, and Chatillons hatred for him, had ufficiently dipoed his Wife to love him. But let us leave Vinevil for ometime, and return to the Duke of Nemours.

His Jealouie o tranported him, that having one day found the Prince at Madam de Chatillon's whipering with her, he all cratched his hands without perceiving what he did; and it was one of his Servants who made him take notice of the Condition he had put himelf in. At length, not being able to uffer the Prince's Viits to his Mitres, he deired her to go for ome time to her Country Houe. She loving him extreamly, and not thinking that a hort abence would cool the Prince's Paion, granted him his requet; and likewie promied him to turn off Bordeaux, who had quitted his Interets for to be for thoe of his Rival. Madam de Chatillon was not long in the Country; and at her Return, the Duke of Nemours was jealous to that degree, that he was twenty times upon the point of cauing the Prince to draw; and he would at length have been overcome with this Temptation, had it not been for the Duel he fought with
his Brother in Law, in which he lot his Life.

Madam de Chastillon, who of twenty Lovers he had favoured in her life time, had never loved any o much as the Duke of Nemours, was really grieved for his death. One of her Friends, who brought her the News of it, told her at the ame time, that it was requiite that he hould get out of one of Monieur de Nemours his Valet de Chamber's hands, a Cabinet full of her Letters. She ent for him, and upon the promie he made him of giving him five hundred Crowns, he got the Cabinet from him, but the poor Fellow could never get any of the Money.

As for the Prince, what obligation oever he had to the Duke of Nemours, jealouie had o diunited them, that he was very glad of his death. Glory as well as Love had caued o much Emulation between them, that they could not bear with one another; and this is o true, that if the Prince had had a mind to have taken all the Precautions neceary to hinder the Duke of Nemours from fighting, he might have prevented the Duel. One thing more which made appear that there was more of Glory than of Love in the Prince's Heart, was that
a moment after the death of his Rival, he hardly loved Madam de Chastillon any longer, and contented himelf with keeping meaures of Civility with her, to make ue of her upon occaion, and when he hould think convenient.

And indeed at that time, the Cardinal thinking that he governed the Prince, ent the Great Provot of France to her, to offer her from him an hundred thouand Crowns ready Money, and the Place of Superintendant of the future Queens Family, in cae he would oblige the Prince to grant the Articles he deired, and abandon the Count d' Oignon, the Duke of Rochefoucault, and Preident Viole. During the Negotiation of the Grand Provot, an Officer of the Guards, called Mouchette, negotiated likewie on the Queens part with Madam de Chatillon; but he, eeing that he could not perwade the Prince to do the things that the Count deired, ent the Queen word that he counelled her to grant the Prince all that he hould deire of her, and that afterwards her Majety would know well enough how to deal with a Subject, who taking advantage of the diorder of the Affairs of his Mater; had forced from her hameful Conditions, and uch as were
prejudicial to her Authority.

At that time, the Abbot Foucquett having been taken by the Enemies, was brought to the Palace of Condé; he had a very harp Converation with the Prince, but on the morrow things began to cool, and ome days after the Treaty of Peace was renewed with him. As he was a Prioner upon parol, and that he went every where he had a mind to, he made ome Viits to Madam de Chatillon, believing that nothing could be done with the Prince but by her interpoition; and it was in thoe Viits that he fell in love with her.

Vinevil governed then Madam de Chatillon pretty peaceably; Cambiac was retired ince that the Prince was in love, and that the Duke of Nemours was dead, and this had very much diminihed the Prince's Paion; inomuch that ome days after having been contrained to retire into Flanders by the accommodation of Paris, he was upon the point of departing without taking leave of Madam de Chatillon, and when at length he went to ee her, he was but a moment with her.

The King being returned to Paris, the Abbot Foucquett fancied that if Madam de Chatillon tayed there, he hould have Rivals
upon his back, who might be preferred before him; inomuch that he perwaded the Cardinal to end her away, aying that he would every day et on foot a thouand Intrigues againt the Interets of the Court, which he could not do elewhere; and this obliged the Cardinal to end her to Marlou: The Abbot Foucquett went thither as often as he could; but there were in her neighbourhood two men who made her yet more frequent Viits; The one was my Lord Crofts an Englihman who had hired a Houe near Marlou, where he uually kept his Equipage, and where he came to ly ometimes, and the other was Digby Earl of Britol, Governour of the Ile of Man: Thee two Noble men fell in love with the Dutches; Crofts was a peacable Man and addicted to Pleaures, and Britol was haughtly, brave and full of ambition,

When that Cambiac had een the Prince go out of France, he had made his applications to Madam de Chatillon; inomuch that he tayed with her at Marlou; and as he was not o much afraid of the Abbot Foucquet or of Bristol, as of the Prince, he freely told Madam de Chatillon his Sentiments of her carriage with all her Lovers. She, not being willing to be contradicted
in her new deigns, and particularly by a Party concerned, took his Remontrances very ill; inomuch that things growing daily wore and wore between them, Cambiac at length retired grumbling, and as a Man that ought to be eared. Sometime after he wrote a Letter without a Name, and with a forged Hand, in which he gave her notice of the ill they talked of her in the World. She upected however that this Letter came from him, becaue he ent her word of things, that no body but he could know of. At length Madam de Chatillon learning from everal parts that Cambiac railed againt her, he deired madam Piieux, whom he was very well acquainted with, and who had a power over him, to withdraw ome Letters of Conequence that he had of hers, which Madam de Piieux promied her to do, and at the ame time ent word to Cambiac to come to her at her Houe at Marins near Pontoie. It is to be oberved that ince that Cambiac was gone from Madam de Chatillon, he had made a thouand Complaints againt him to my Lord Digby. This Lover, who only thought of pleaing his Mitres, and who ruined himelf in expences for her ake, did not tick at
promiing her a Vengance that hould cot him nothing, and wherein he would find his particular interet: He took the time that Cambiac being at Marine, was one day on Horeback to go abroad, and having eized him with five or ix Troopers, he ent him to Marlou. Madam de Chatillon knowing that Lovers that had been well treated ought never to be offended by halves, was much perplexed at the manner that Cambiac was now ued, and perceived that no Body would be uspected but her; he was very ill atisfied with Digby, and would have ooner pardoned him the Death of Cambiac than the eizing him after this manner: But in hort, not being able to undo what was done. I am extreamly grieved, aid he to him, at what has now happened to you, I perceive that the Impertinent who has done you this Affront, would make you upect me, by ending you to my Houe; but you hall ee by the reentment I hall have of it, that I have no hare in this Voilence; In the mean time, Sir, if you have a mind to tay here, you are Mater; if you think fit to return to Marine, you hall have my Coach, you need only Command it. I know, Madam, anwered Cambiac to her coolly, what I ought to think of all this, I give you
thanks for the offers you make me; I hall return on Horeback if you think fit: God, who will defend me from the attempts of the wicked, will have care of me to the end. And having poke thee words he went away in a pett, and returned alone to Marine. He was no ooner arrived there than that he and Madam de Piieux wrote thee two Letters to one of their Friends at Paris.

body.head: A Letter from Cambiac to Monieur de Brienne.
body.p:
YOu will be much urprized when you hall have learnt the adventure that has happened to me; but to tell you the occaion of it, I mut acquaint you with everall particulars that happened before, as that Madam de Chatillon ent hither to oblige Madam de Piieux to come to her Houe, in order to the obtaining of me certain things he was deirous having. Madam de Piieux, as you know, wrote to me; and you likewie know that I undertook the journey the ame day that I arrived; Madam de Chatillon ent la Fleur, to know if I was here, and on the Morrow a Man unknown under fale Colours, came to ask me, and know if I would return eddenly to Paris. Yeterday I departed from bence at four a Clock; being an hundred Paces
from Pontois, after having paed the River, I was inveted by ix Hormen, with their Swords in their hands, at the head of whom was my Lord Digby. He told me immediately, that if Madam de Chatillon would have done me jutice, he hould have caued me to receive a hundred tabs, but that I hould fear Nothing. I hall tell you without any Bravado, that I acted very briskly in this encounter, and that I did nothing in this Affaire that was unworthy; he ued me very civilly, and after having dined, be conducted me himelf to the foot of Marlou, and then ent me with four Hormen to make atisfaction to that worthy peron; he eemed to be dipleaed at this accident, and was really o at the haughtines with which I poke to her, which made her comprehend that it was the wort thing he had ever done. I returned to Marine, to tell Madam de Piieux the treachery that Madam de Chatillon had done her as well as me. She has all the reentment that a peron of her Qualisy, Honour and Courage ought to have. You ee this is omething an extraordinary accident, I conjure you let me know your opinion of it, and what coure you think I ought to take; you perceive I uppoe that I ought not to ret atisfied, ince that this bae peron has written to Madam de Piieux, to conjure her to obtain of me
to tifle my reentment, by auring me that he knew nothing of all this. The anwer that has been made her, is worthy of the generoity of Madam de Piieux. I am reolved to tay three or four days here, to have leizure to think of what I have to do, and to hinder my elf from attempting any thing that I may repent of: Beides, to vent One's elf in Complaints, is but a feeble revenge, and I have a deign to do otherwie if I can. I impatiently long to hear from you, and am wholly yours. A Letter does not permit me to give you a very particular account; I hall do it when I ee you. Farewel.

body.head: Madam de Piieux's Letter to Monieur de Brienne.
body.p:
I Have too great a hare in the Adventure of Monieur de Cambiac, not to add one word of my Hand to the Relation he has given you by his; there is not a Circumtance but what is urprizing, and the best that can be thought of me in this occaion is, That they have had but little Conideration for me; for according to all appearances, I ought to have a hare in o worthy an Action: The truth is, that the offended
justifies me ufficiently, ince he retired into the ame place where the Snare was laid for him. All my tudy is at preent o to carry my elf, that I may not be tranported with a jut Anger, which I hall entertain all my life time, to make appear that I was a Friend ufficiently ueful to Madam de Chatillon. You know my Name and my Courage, I have ever poke to you with incerity enough; I moreover add, that I make profeion of a very autere Chritianity, and that I deign to erve my God and my Mater without Art and without Deceipt. Thee Foundations laid, I hall not be wanting in any thing that Reentment and Jutice can permit me. Oblige me with imparting this to Monieur de Aubigny, and to no others: This will be no ill Entertainment for the Princes Palatine, which I give you leave to tell it to. I do not believe that Cambiac's Crime of returning to his Duty, by the means of the Bihop of Amiens, nor mine for having concealed him, were great enough to occaion o ill an Accident. I hall come on purpoe to Paris to dicoure my Friends in particular, and you in the firt place. I cannot hold in this little word of Revenge, Madam de Chatillon is not forgotten when an occaion is offered to peak of her: I wih you happines, I am too angry to have any to day.

div.p: In a hort time after thee two Letters were ent, Cambiac returned to Paris, and no longer kept any meaures with Madam de Chatillon; he railed at her in all Companies, and that he might fully glut his Vengeance, he nowed the Queen all the mot extravagantly paionate Letters of Madam de Chastillon, the modety of the Hitory does not permit them to be repeated; but by the mot civil Fragment we follow, the ret may be judged of.

In everal parts he let Cambiac know, that he might talk of her as he pleaed, but that it was more generous in him to peak well of her than otherwie; that when a Woman lay at the mercy of People, as he did at his, they might make an ill ue of the opportunity; and that what a poor Woman had to do in thoe Encounters, was to uffer and to be ilent. In another place he let him know, that notwithtanding all he did, he till loved him, and that though he was preparing to make a general Confeion at Eater, there was nothing therein which concerned him.

The Queen was much urprized at Madam de Chatillon's Extravagancy in her Letter, however he was not orry at the contempt it brought upon her; and when that
he had learnt the Inult that had been done to Cambiac, he made a great noie of it, and aid publickly, That ince People were o ill treated, who returned to do their duty, the King would know how to do them jutice.

When my Lord Digby came to ee Madam de Chatillon, after what had been done to Cambiac, he was atonihed that he only received reproaches from her, intead of the thanks that he expected. When I let you know, aid he to him, my being dipleaed with Cambiac, it was not meant that you hould ue him as you did: And it is eaie to ee that in this fine Action you conidered your elf more than you did me; but I hall now be careful of my Interets, and neglect yours. Digby would have excued himelf upon his Intentions, that had been good, and eeing that notwithtanding all that he aid to her he was not pacified, he likewie fell into a pet; and Madam de Chastillan fearing by loing him to loe a Protectour and a Lover, oothed him up, and deired him to conider at another time, that he ought to ruin quite, or diemble Injuries with uch people as Cambiac.

While that Digby began to fall in love with Madam de Chatillon, my Lord Crofts, who in the time the Diorders of England, had followed Charles into France, had taken a Houe in the Neighbourhood of Marlou; and leiure, conveniency, and the ininuating ways of Madam de Chatillon, had inflamed this Lord's heart with love; but as he was of a milder dipoition than the Earl, his Paion had not made uch progres as the Earl of Britol's.

Things were in thee terms, when that the Abbot Foucquett, eeing that his Affairs did not advance with Madam de Chatillon, made ue of this Stratagem to hatem them: He had learnt that Ricoux, Brother in Law to one of Madam de Chatillon's Women, was concealed in Paris, where he had Correpondence with them for the Prince's Interets; he ent o many People in quet of Ricoux, that he was taken and carried to the Batille. The Abbot Foucquett having caued him to be examined, he accued Madam de Chatillon of everal things; and amongt others, of having promied him ten thouand Crowns to kill the Cardinal, and aid that he had already given him two thouand beforehand upon that account. The Abbot Foucquett uppreed thee Informations,
and caued others to be given, by which Ricoux till confeed that he was at Paris with deign to kill the Cardinal; but did not accue the Duches of having any hand in this Conpiracy: And all that he aid againt her was, That he kept Correpondence with the Prince, and received a Penion of Four thouand Crowns from the Spaniards. He hewed thee lat Informations to the Cardinal, and the firt to Madam de Chatillon, by which having, as may be imagined, extreamly terrified her, He told her he would ave her, if out of acknowledgment he would give him the leat marks of Love: Madam de Chatillon, who feared death more then all things, did not tick to atisfie the Abbot Foucquett, but reited jut as long as was neceary to make him value this lat Favour. The Abbot Foucquett his whole thoughts were now, how to love his Mitres; and to that end he caued her to leave Marlou one night, and carried her into Normandy, where he made her change her Abode every day, diguied ometimes like a Gentleman, ometimes like a Religious, and ometimes like a Fryer. This lated ix Weeks, during which the Abbot Foucquet went and came from Court to the place where Madam de Chatillon
was: At length he procured her an Amnety, when Ricoux had been Executed, and caued her to return to Marlou, where he was not long in repoe; for he cat her Eyes upon the Marehal d' Hocquincourt, as well for the Advantages he might draw from him by the Pots he held upon the Somme, as to free her from the tyranny of the Abbot Foucquett, who began to become inupportable to her.

Charles Marhal d' Hocquincourt had black parkling Eyes, a handome Noe, a little Forehead, a long Viage, and black frized Hair, and his Shape was very fine: He had but little Wit, and yet was cunning by being very ditrutful; he was brave and ever in love, and his Valour erved him intead of Wit and good Carriage amongt the Ladies. Madam de Chatillon knowing him by Reputation, fancied that he was a proper Peron to commit the Follies he had occaion for. Monieur de Vignacourt, a Gentleman of Picardy, her Neighbour, was the Peron he employed to him. Whereupon the Marhal having agreed with Vignacourt, that at his going to Command the Army of Catalonia, he would ee her as he paed thorow Marlou, as if Chance had occaioned this Interview. The thing hapned
as it had been projected, and Madam de Chatillon took Hore to go to Conduct the Marhal two Leagues from Marlou. On the way, he related to him the ad Circumtances of her Fortune, deired him to be her Protectour, flattered him with the Title of the Refuge of the Afflicted, and the Reource of the Mierable. In hort, he o inpired him with Generoity, that he promied to erve her with and againt all, and even gave her his Table-Book, in which he gave order to the Governours of Towns and Places to receive her and hers, as often as he had occaion. This Interview was dicovered by the Abbot Foucquett, who eeing the Marhal d' Hocquincourt upon the point of returning to Court, judging his and Madam de Chatillon's Neighbourhood dangerous for his and the Courts Interets, perwaded the Cardinal to remove her to the Frontiers of Picardy, and caued an Order to be ent her to go to her Dutchy. As Madam de Chastillon was on her Journey, he met with the Marhal d' Hocqiuncourt at Montarquis, with whom he renewed the Meaures he had taken ix Months before, and after having mutually given one another, he poitively words to protect her againt the Court, and he hopes to grant him one day
marks of her Paion.
