They parted, The Marhal went to find out the King, and he to her Dutchy, where he paed the Winter, during which the Marhal d' Hocquincourt, and the Abbot Foucquett, who being the mot difficult Patron to be atisfied, impatiently upported the Interviews that paed between the Marhal d' Hocquincourt and Madam de Chatillon, and the Commerce he kept with him. To excue herelf, he told him that the Marhal ued his endeavours with the Cardinal that he might have Bordeaux again, who was taken from her, and to obtain of him for herelf, leave to return to Court: She added, That he could have wihed he might not have been indebted for thoe Favours to any other than himelf, but that he was willing to pare his Credit for Affairs of greater moment. What perwaded the Abbot Foucquett that the Intrigue between the Marhal did only concern the Court, was that in the Spring he returned through his Interceion, firt to Marlou, afterwards to Paris and Bordeaux with her. During the Marehal's Campaign in Catalonia, the King of England, whom the misfortunes of his Family obliged to tay in France, and who had found the Dutches much to his mind, aw her at Marlou in the
little Journeys he made to my Lord Crofts's his Houe; and this Commerce had inpired this Prince with o much love for her, that he reolved to marry her: Crofts perwading his Mater to atisfie her at any rate, upon the promies that Madam de Chatillon had given this Lord that he hould enjoy her, in cae he would contribute to the making her Queen: And indeed he had been o, if God, who took care of the Fortune and Reputation of that King, had not amued Madam de Chatillon with a foolih hope, which made her fail of o fair an Occaion.

Charles King of England had great black Eyes, his Eye-brows were thick, and met together, was of a brown Complexion, a handome Noe, a long Viage, his Hair was black and curled; he was tall, and finely haped; he had an autere Preence, and yet loft and civil more in good than in ill Fortune: He was brave, that is to ay, that he had the Courage of a Souldier, and the Soul of a Prince: He was a great Wit, and loved Pleaures, but yet he loved his Duty more: In hort, he was one of the greatet Kings in the World: But however, tho Nature had gifted him with admirable Advantages, Adverity, that had been his Governour,
was the principal Caue of his extraordinary Merit.

The Prince at his leaving of France, had hown, as I have already aid, very little conideration for Madam de Chatillon; but having known the value that the Spaniards et on her, by the Penion they had given her, and the Credit that he had at the Court of France, by the means of the Abbot Foucquett, was reinflamed for her: And his Paion was o violent, that he wrote to her the mot paionate Letters in the World, and amongt others, this was intercepted that he wrote to her in Cyphers.

body.p:
THo all your Charms hould not oblige me to love you, my dear Coin, the pains that you take for me, and the perecutions you uffer for being in my Interets, and the hazards wherein this expoes you, would oblige me to love you as long as I live; Iudge then what all this together can do upon a heart, which is neither inenible nor ungrateful; but judge likewie of the alarms that I am continually in for you. The example of Ricoux makes me tremble, and when that I conider that what I have mot dear in the World is in the hands of my Enemies, I am in diquiets that never give me ret. In the name of God, my pooret Dear, do not longer hazard
your elf as you do; I hould chooe rather never to return into France, than be the caue of your having the leat apprehenion: It is for me to expoe my elf, and by a War put my Affairs in uch a poture, as that they may treat with me; and then, my dear Coin, you may aid me with your Interceion; and in the mean time, as events are doubtful in War, I have one ure way to pas my life with you, and yet engage our Interets to one another more than they have hitherto been. Do not believe that the Princes is an invincible obtacle to this; people break through much greater, when they are as much in love as I am. In this part, my dear Coin, I give no bounds to my Imagination, nor to your Hopes: You may puh them as far as you pleae. Farewel.

div.p:
The hopes that Madam de Chatillon had upon this Letter of marrying the Prince, made her think of refuing the offers of the King of England; hereupon he conulted one of her female Friends in Bordeaux's preence. She, whoe Husband was with the Prince, told her Mitres that he was mad once to think of marrying a haddow of a King, a Wretch who had not wherewith to live, and who in making her to be laughed at, would ruin her in a little time, that if
it was poible, contrary to all appearances in the World, that he hould one day recover his Throne, he might very well believe that being weary of her, he would be divorced from her upon the pretext of the inequality of Condition: Her Friend told her on the contrary, that her madnes was to marry the Prince who was married, and whoe Wife was in health, that perons of the Quality of the King of England might be ometimes under ill Fortune, but that they could never be in that extream neceity o common to private Perons: That it was fine for a Lady to live a Queen, tho he hould live unhappy; and that he ought never to refue an honourable Title, tho he was only to bear it upon her Grave. As for you Mademoielle, turning towards Bordeaux, you have reaon to talk as you do to her Grace, conidering only your own interet; but for my part, who only conider her Graces, I tell her what I ought to ay. Madam de Chatillon gave them thanks for the kindnes they howed her, and told them that he would take time to think of their Reaons before he came to a Reolution. She was not willing to give a more poitive Anwer before her Friend in an Affair he was ahamed he hould chooe what
was contrary to her advice; In the mean time there came Notice from everal parts to the King of England of the Life of Madam Chatillon, and of her preent Conduct with the Abbot Foucquett. Never any Man that had the leat ene of Honour, did loe his Reaon o much as in the beginning of his Paion to marry a Woman without Honour.

The King of England went from the Neighbourhood of Marlou as oon as He had learnt all thee news, and would not hazard, by eeing Madam de Chatillon, a Conflict that might be doubtfull between his ences and his Reaon. Madam de Chatillon was not then enible of the los he had: the deires and hopes he had of marrying the Prince rendered all other things indifferent to her.

Madam de Chatillon being returned from her Dutchy to Marlou in the beginning of the Spring, through the interceion of the Marhall d' Hocquincourt, and ometime after to Paris, he did not find her ungratefull for this favour. This little ervice and the promies he gave her of killing the Cardinal and putting his Places into the Princes hands, touched Madam de Chatillons Heart to that point, that he
granted enjoyment to the Marchal. The Summer paed in this manner during, which the Abbot Foucquett who perceived this Commerce, was often under trange diquiets; and he had done at that time what he did afterwards, if Lovers did not love to deceive themelves, when they are either to quit or condemn their Mitrees.

The Winter after, the Duke of Candale at his return from Catalonia, eemed to be in love with Madam de Chatillon; The Abbot Foucquett allarum'd at o dangerous a Rivall, caued Boligneux to deire him to ceae his peruit. The Duke of Candale being at that time really in love with Madam d' Olonne, and had only engaged himelf with Madam de Chatillon to make her erve for a pretext, eaily granted the Abbot Foucquett's Requet. But as with this Mitres Lovers were as an Hydra, of whom one head was no ooner cut off, but that an other prung up in the room, la Feuillade took the place of the Duke of Candale; The Abbot Foucquett who knew it immediately, poke himelf pretty harply of it to la Fuillade, who whether that he fancyed that his Rivall being beloved he hould not ucceed in his Enterprize, or whether that his blooming Paion left him all his Prudence,
he did not judge it Convenient to incurr the hatred of o violent a Man; wherefore he did not perevere in that Amour. The Marques de Cozuvres had not o much Complaiance as Feuillade had, he continued to ee Madam de Chatillon maugre the Abbot Foucquett; but as he had neither Fortune nor Merit enough to touch her Heart, he only made a Conquet of him, and only kept him in play to inflame the Abbot Foucquett, and oblige him to renew his Preents, and let him know that he had Perons of Quality on her ide who would not uffer her to be miued. Wherefore the Abbot was forced to bear with this Rivall but he vented his Choler upon poor Vinevil; who was one of the firt Lovers of Madam de Chatillon, beloved, a Man of good Sene, and whoe Wit was to be feared. The Abbot Foucquett gave the Cardinal to undertand that it was dangerous to leave him at Paris; inomuch that the Cardinal eeing only through the Abbots Eyes, ent an order to Vinevil to go to Tours till further order; and he not being uffered to take his leave of Madam de Chatillon, wrote her this Letter on the lat of October 1651.

body.p:
HOw deirous oever you eem to be that I hould make you a Viit, I fancyed that the little pleaure you took in the lat, I hould do much better to abtain; ince that indeed your coldnes deprives me of the joy, that I received at other times in eeing you: for the truth is, I am perwaded that I ought not to pretend to any hare in your Favour, nor your Confidence; the engagement you are under, does not permit you to conider any thing beides, and that you are neceitated to be wanting in what you owe by eential obligations; I am likewie of Opinion that you would take it more kindly to forget you altogether, than to remember you on this occaion; and that you willingly approve of my abandoning your peron and your Interet. And yet Madam, I do not pretend that you hould loe me quite, becaue I am very ure, you will be very glad to find me again one time or other, tho you depie me at preent: I will erve my elf as much as the knowledg of the preent Circumtances you are under will uffer, preand the Friendhip I have promied you, which makes me that I cannot diemble that all human kind talk mot diadvantageauly of your Conduct, and that you are become the perpetual Theme of all the Converations of the time. They decribe your Engagement to be the mot pittyful
and abject that a peron of your Quality was ever Concerned in; and your friend is aid to exercie over you a tyrannical Empire, and more epecially that he caues all to be dicarded that come near you, and that he even threatens thoe whom he is told are his Rivals, as he has done Feuillade; and I pas over in ilence everal particulars of his private Viits which are ufficiently known. Do but conider, Madam, of the prejudice that your Reputation receives from this Commerce; and make reflection upon what you are, and upon what he is who has deprived you of your Honour; for the Credit and Conideration he procures you are not very honorable, and they are fale lights which reflect upon you, rather to offend you than to give you a lutre. Ah! Madam, if the poor deceaed had but the leat ence, they would cratch their way out of their Graves, and come and approach you with o hamefull a dependance, but I do not believe that you are concerned for the memory of them, fear the living, who ooner or later will be informed of your Conduct and will doubtles behave themelves accordingly. I do not repreent all thee things to you out of a motive of jealouie; for I aure you I am not infected with a Paion o afflicting and o ueles as that. If I was transported with love for you I hould vent my elf in Invectives,
which would do you irreparable Injuries, and I hould revenge my elf of the wrongs you do me with o much Ingratitude. If I had no love for you, I hould railly as well as others: but in what concerns you I keep my elf in a Mediocrity, which gives me a mute grief for the blindnes of your Conduct, which at length will bring you into the wort of troubles, if you have not a care, and let your elf be governed by your prudence without expecting events. To morrow I hall go towards Tourraine, wherefore I take my leave of you, Madam; If you take kindly the advice I give you I hall continue to love you; if ill, I hall endeavour to get rid of a Principle that is the caue of it: In the mean time I doe not demaund any good Offices for my Concerns, but only that you would hinder ill ones from being done me, and you will oblige me in o doing.

div.p: Notwithtanding Vinevil's Banihment, The Abbot Foucquett was no more at eae than he was before, Madam de Chatillon making him mad every moment; but that which diquieted him mot was the Intrigue between her and the Marhall d' Hocquincourt. This had rendred her o haughty that he had often treated the Abbot Foucquett as if he had not known him.

During thee paages the Marhal de Hocquincourt finding himelf preed by Madam de Chatillon to perform the promies he had made her, which not being willing to do, he gave notice to the Cardinal of all that he had promied Madam de Chastillon, by one of his Gentlemen, who eemed to betray him, and at the ame time caued the ame notice to be given to the Abbot Foucquett by Madam Calvoiin, the Governour of Roye's Wife. This peice of Cunning had the effect, that the Marhall had promied himelf; the Cardidinal was alarum'd, and to break of o dangerous an Intrigue caued the Marhal d' Hocquincourt to be treated with. The Abbot Foucquett for his part, having had the information from Calvoiin, deired the Cardinal that he would caue Madam de Chatillon to be took into Cutody, and put in uch a place where he might not have any Correpondence till that he hould think fit to retore her to her liberty. The Cardinal having given his conent, the Abbot Foucquett caued Madam de Chatillon to be eized on at Marlou, and conducted with one of her Women to Paris, where he caued her to be brought in by Night, and lodged her at one de Vaux's Houe in
Poitow-tret. On the morrow after her arrival, the Abbot Foucquett took a Note under her hand by order from the Cardinal, and directed to the Marhal d' Hocquincourt, by which he deired him to come to an accomodation with the King, and not to think any longer of the Prince or of her, becaue it might endanger his Life; & as ome days before he was taken he had agreed with the Marhal, that in cae they hapned to be taken into cutody, and that Letters were exacted from them, contrary to the meaures they had taken together, they hould give no Credit to them if they were not written with a double C. Which he did not do in this Letter, but he did in an other which he wrote at the ame time to the Marhal; by which he let him know that he hould remain firm in the firt reolution that he had taken of erving the Prince, and of delivering up his Places to him; which the Marhal never intended, and had only promied Madam de Chatillen that he would, that he might obtain favours from her, and to procure advantages from the Cardinal, which he could not have without making himelf be feared; he uppreed the Letter of intelligence, and ent that to the Prince which the Abbot
Foucquett had caued Madam de Chatillon to write to him, by which knowing that he was in danger of her life, he ent him word to make his peace with the Court, provided he got Madam de Chastillon releaed out of Prion. The Cardinal believing the Marhal to be really in love with Madam de Chatillon, and that he would give all that he hould demand of him to et her at liberty, would have deducted upon her account an hundred thouand Livers, out of the hundred thouand Crowns they had agreed of together: But the Marhal would not conent to it, and yet that he might not think him a cheat, and to keep ome meaures with her till, he would not put his places into the Cardinals hands, til he knew that the Dutches was et at liberty; inomuch that to atisfy him in that point, they deceived him, and ent the Dutches to the fathers Oratory to hew her elf to a Gentleman he had ent on purpoe for that end; with whom he was free, after which he returned to her prion, where he was eight days longer. During the three weeks that he was a Prioner in Poitoutreet, the Abbot was not o free as he, he became daily more and more mitten; for as with the liberty of going and coming
he likewie deprived her of that of deceiving him; he found her a thouand times more lovely than before. Beides the Dutches being willing to recover his eteem that he migh procure being et at liberty, ued him after uch a manner as was capable of melting the heart of a Barbarian, and had a thouand kindnees and Complyances for him: and he eemed to put o entire a Confidence in him, that he could not forbear beleiving that he would never depend again on any Body but him.

Things being in this Poture, the Abbot urprized a very kind Letter, that the Dutches wrote to the Prince of Condé. This grieved him o extreamly, that in reproaching her, he would have poioned himelf with Quickilver from behind a Looking-glas; but beginning to find himelf ill, he lot the deire of dying for a faithles one, and took Theriaque which he uually carried about him to ecure himelf from Enemies, which the employ he had about the Cardinal procured him daily. Except going where he pleaed, the Dutches paed her time very pleaantly in the prion; The Abbot treated her with all manner of Delicacies, and made her daily very coniderable Preents in Knacks and Jewels;
he went from thence at two a Clock in the Night, and came again at eight in the Morning, thus was he with her eighteen hours in four and twenty.

It was impoible but that the Cardinal mut know where the Dutches was, and this is pleaant that this great Man, who decided the Fate of Europe, hould go halves with the Abbot Foucquett in an amourous ecret: I beleive that the reaon he had to approve this Commerce was, that knowing the Dutches to be Intriguing, he choe rather he hould be in the Abbots hands, whom he was ure of, than in an other; and beides the Abbot keeping her in a Chamber, and abolutely dihonoring her thereby, he was glad that the Prince of Condé her Couin and lover, might receive thereby an extraordinary mortification. But at length the Marhal d' Hocquincourts' accommodation being made, upon Condition that the Dutches hould be releaed out of prion, he was to be let at liberty. They ent her to Marlou, where ome time after the wort accident imaginable happened

The Abbot Foucquett and he had agreed together, that every Saturday they would mutually return the Letters they had written to one another all the week long, and
that he would end for them by a Man who hould ay that he belonged to Mademoielle Vertus. This Man being one day at Marlou, a footman came thither from the Marhal d' Hocquincourt, with a Letter for the Dutches, who having writ her anwers, and given them to a Chambermaid to deliver them to the Bearers, this Woman mitook, and gave the Abbot's Man the anwer that her Mitris ent the Marhal, and to the Marhal's Lacquie the Pacquet deigned for the Abbot. It is eaie to imagine in what allarms the Dutches was o oon as he knew the Mitake, and particularly when it is known that in the Letter, which he wrote to the Abbot, beides a thouand kind things, there was alo a long Chapter againt Madam de Bregi, whom he hated, becaue he had naturally the Charms of Body and of mind which the Dutches had only by Art. It is certain thet the Dutches had ever envied her and was never able to pardon her Merit. In an other place, he railed againt my Lord Mountague, and almot in every part of it made the mot biting railleries imaginable upon the Marhal. And when he thought of the Abbot's Letters which he had ent to him, wherein there
were tendernees and tranports of love, which might be good to a Mitres, but which uually appear very ridiculous to the indifferent, and that all this was in the hands of a haughty and a laughed at Rival, he was almot mad: The Abbot for his part was in no les pain. As for the Marhal o oon as he had een all the Abbot's Letters, and thoe that the Dutches wrote to him, he judged that he might be one day obliged to retore them her out of his weaknes to her, or through the deires of her Friends, inomuch that he might be in a capacity to take his revenge on her when he pleaed: He caued copies to be taken of them all, and then went and howed the originals to the Duke of Rochefoucault, to Madam Piieux, whom he knew to be the Dutchees Enemies. After that the Abbot had been one Night at Marlou, he returned to Paris to the Merhals Houe, of whom he demanded his Letters. The Marhal did not content himelf with refuing him them, but added all the raillery after his way that he could bethink himelf of; while the Marhal was thus drolling he held the Dutches, Letter open to the Abbot, who had liever have been killed, than have uffered his Mitres to have laine at his Rival's dicretion,
as he did by this Letter, caught hold of it, and tore half of it off, which he went to how to the Dutches, telling her that the Marhal had burnt the other halfe; but the Marhal being enraged at this enterprize of the Abbots; bid him be gone immediately out of his Houe, and that if ome repects did not withhold him, he would caue him to be thrown out of the Window.

The Dutches being ometime after returned to Paris, fancied that to undeceive the Publick of a thouand Particulars, that the Marhal had aid of her, it was requiite that he hould let People of Merit and Virtue ee after what manner he would treat him. In order to which, he made choice of the Houe of the Marques de Souches, Great Provot of France, to whom and his Wife he had a mind to jutifie herelf more particularly: The Aignation being made with the Marhal, he perceived her deign. God keep thee, my poor Child, aid he accoting her, How does my little Buttocks do, are they till very lean? It is impoible to imagine the ad Condition this dicoure put the Dutches in! he was as if he had been tund with a blow upon her head, it made her forget to call the Marhal Fool and Inolent; but
he fancied that having begun as he did, he would proceed to the mot hameful particulars imaginable for her, if he dipleaed him never o little. The Grand Provot and his Wie looked upon one another, and turning towards the Dutches, found her with her Eyes towards the ground, but indeed he did not change her Colour; but thoe who knew her did not believe her perplexed. At length the Great Provot breaking ilence, You do ill, aid he, my Lord Marhal; Gallant men ought never to quarrel with Ladies, they ought to be thankul to them for the Preents they make them of their Hearts, and ought not to offend them when they refue it. I grant that, aid the Marhal, but when their Hearts are once given, if they change after that, it is requiite they ue civilly thoe they have loved, and when they droll upon them, they expoe themelves to great Affronts. You understand me, Madam, added he, turning towards the Dutches, I am ure you believe that I have reaon for what I ay, but you urprize me with your diorder; you ought to be prepared for uch Accidents, ince you lay Snares for people who revenge themelves. I vow I would not have believed that you had o much Modety as you have. And in ending this Dicoure he went away, and left the Dutches more dead
than alive. The Great Provot and his Wife endeavoured to bring her to herelf; telling her, That what the Marhal had aid, had not made any impreion upon their minds; however from that day they had no great Commerce with her.

A fortnight after the Abbot was obliged to go to the Court, which was at Compeigne; The Dutches foreeeing the Prince of Condés return into France by the general Peace that was much talked of, and not being willing that he hould find her in o hameful an Intrigue for her, reolved to break off after uch a manner, as that there might not remain the leat appearance of it. In this deign he went to the Abbots Houe, where having found one of his Servants in whom he put mot confidence, and asked him for the Keyes of his Mater's Cloet, aying he had a mind to write him a Letter. This Fellow without penetrating further, and only conidering the Abbots Paion for the Dutches, he gave her immediately what he demanded. Seeing herelf alone, he broak the lock of the Cabinet where he knew that the Abbot kept her Letters, and not only took them all, but likewie others from the Prince of Condé, which he had acrificed to them, and went and burnt them
at Madam de Sourches Houe. The Abbot having ound this diorder at his return home, went to the Dutchees Houe, and began to threaten to cut off her Noe, and then broke a Chrital Candletick, and a great Looking-glas that he had given her, and went away after having called her a thouand Names. During all this butle, one of the Dutchees Chambermaids fancying that the Abbot would take away from her all that he had given her, laid hold upon her Mitrees Cabinet of Jewels, and carried it to Madam de Sourches Houe, from whence he ent for it again the ame Evening, and gave it to a devout Relation of her Mothers to keep. The Abbot having notice of it on the Morrow, went to that Devout Womans Houe, and took it away by force. The Dutches being informed of the los he had, was extreamly grieved; but he did not loe her judgment, he employed people to the Abbot, who had o much credit with him, that he retored the Cabinet; and by the means of this retitution they were as well reconciled as they had ever been; and this reconciliation was o udden, that Madam de Bouteville coming the morrow to comfort the Dutches her Daughter for the accident that had hapned
to her, the Abbot was already with her, who concealed himelf in a Cloet during the Viit, and heard all the Comedy.

Some time after, the Dutches not being willing to take alwaies the pains to conceal that he aw the Abbot again; and fancied that ince their quarrel was known abroad, their reconciliation ought likewie to be publick: Wherefore he caued all her friends to deire her to pardon the Abbot upon his ollicitation, and at length having made it a point of Concience, the Mother Abbes, of the Convent of Mercy, a Woman ubject to beatifical Viitations, made them ee and embrace one another. This Mediation brought the Reverend Mother into ome dicredit with the Queen and the Cardinal: They fancyed that that he had not o particular a Commerce with God, ince he uffered her elf to be o eaily deceived by Men.

However this reconciliation lated but ix Months; The Prince of Condé's return into France coming on daily made the Dutches apprehend that he would find her under the Abbots Tutorhip, and the Ladies de Saint Chaumond and de Feguiers made her o much ahamed of him, that he broak with him upon a pretext of Devotion. It
was very difficult for the Abbot to conent to the Dutches's deign, and would not have done it at an other time; but eeing his Credit very much diminihed with the Cardinal, and fearing that the Prince of Condé, who hated him beides, and Bouteville, who would revenge the dihonour he had done to his family, might caue him to be tabbed, if he gave the Dutches the leat new Reaon of Complaining, he left off Viiting, but not loving her.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Part

div.p: LOVES EMPIRE; Or, The GALLANTRIES Of the FRENCH COURT. The Third Part.
LONDON, Printed for Dorman Newman. 1682.

div.head: LOVES EMPIRE, &c.
div.p:
AT that time Madam d'Olonne was gone as I have aid, to deire the Countes of Fieque, to thank in her name the Abbot Foucquett for ome pretended Obligation which was properly nothing; but he had a mind the Abbot Foucquett hould make Reflections upon the Compliment, and make him Comprehend that when people have thanks returned them for uch mall things, they are willing to be indebted to them for the greater Obligations. The ame day that Madam d'Olonne aw the Countes, he found the Abbot at Madam de Bonelles, and there he
herelf made him the ame Compliment: The Abbot, being very deirons to have an Intrigue with Madam d' Olonne, to endeavour the curing himelf of the Paion he had till for the Dutches of Catillon, returned her Civilities as obligingly as he was able; and on the Morrow the Countes having ent to eek him, and telling him what Madam d' Olonne had deired her to ay: I know more than you of that, Madam, aid he to her, and I received yeterday Evening marks of acknowledgment from herelf: But I would willingly know of you one thing, added he, Whether the Count de Guiche is not in love with Madam, d' Olonne; for if he is, I will avoid the Occaion of being o: He has had o much repect for me upon all Occaions, that I hould be ridiculous hould I play him uch a prank. No, aid the Countes, at leat Madam d' Olonne and he have each of them told me, that they had not any thoughts of one another. If this is true, replyed the Abbot, I beeech you Madam, to let Mad. d' Olonne know that you have een me, & that upon what you have told me in her Name, I appeared to you o tranported with joy, to ee how he received what I did for her, that you do not doubt but that I hall be infinitely in love; and thereupon, Madam,
ask her, I beeech you, what he would do in cae I hould be o. The Countes having given her word that he would, the Abbot went away; and on the Morrow Madam d' Olonne having received a Letter from the Countes, made her this Anwer.

body.p: YOu deire to know what coure I would take in cae the Abbot Foucquett was in love with me; I am not o mad as to tell you; for I am till as much taken with him as I was two dayes agoe. Farewell, la Chatillanne.

div.p:
The Chevalier de Grammont, being come to the Countees a moment after he had received this Ticket, found her in Bed, and eeing a Paper lying by her, he took it. The Countes having redemanded this Paper, the Chevalier retored her another much of the ame bignes. The Company that was then in her Chamber, o took her up, that he did not perceive the Chevaliers roguery, who went away almot as oon as he had done. Seeing what it was, it is not to be quetioned, but that his joy was extream, to have in hand wherewith to injure Madam d' Olonne, and put the Count de Guiche in a rage. He remembred, he had been acrificed
to Marillac, and the diquiets that his Nephew had given him upon the Countees account, and was very glad he had now an Occaion to torment him. The noie that this Letter made, had all the effect that he could deire; the Count de Guiche was allarm'd, and conulted Vinevil; they reolved together, that he hould peak himelf of it to the Abbot, and in the mean time he wrote this Letter to Madam d' Olonne.

body.p: YOu make me mad, Madam, but I love you too much to fall out with you; and perhaps this Carriage may move your Heart more than reproaches; however my reentment must fall upon ome body, and I ee not one that has incurred it more than the Countes; It was certainly he who engaged the Abbot Foucquett to think of you, to reclaime me to her, or be revenged on me for changing, being in dipair that I had abandoned her; and therefore has raied me up a Rival, who hould caue me to be dicarded or disgut me from loving you. I cannot think Madam, he will effect either of her deigns, and yet I think my elf as much obliged to her as if he had brought them to pas, and he is to expect that I will have no longer any regard for her, and that I will ue all means imaginable to be revenged.

div.p:
Madam d' Olonne, not being o ecure of
the Count de Guiche, but that he apprehended the Countes might reclaim him, was willing to embroil them to uch a point, as that in all appearance they could not be reconciled; and for that end he had no ooner received this Letter, then that he ent it to the Countes: Which putting her in a rage againt the Count de Guiche, he ent for Vinevil to come to her. I deired your company, to tell you that your Friend is an impertinent Fool, and whom I will have nothing more to do with. See the Letter he has newly written to Madam d' Olonne; he complains that I perwade the Abbot Foucquett to engage in an Intrigue with his Mistres, and does not remember that he told me, that he had no longer any thoughts of her. I ask your pardon for him, anwered Vinevil, excue a poor Lover, who eeing they deign to deprive him of his Mitres, knows not what he does, nor whom to have recoure to: As oon as I hall have him recollect himelf, he will come and cat himelf at your Feet. After ome other Dicoures, Vinevil went away, and within an hour after returned with the Count de Guiche, who told the Countes o many things, that he promied to forget his rudenes. On the Morrow the Count having reolved to peak to the Abbot, went to him, and having taken
him aide, If we had both begun at the ame time, aid he to him, to be in love with Madam d' Olonne, it would be ridiculous to think it strange that you hould dipute her with me, neither hould I do it; and I would leave it to herelf to decide by Favours the good Fortune of us both. But ince you come to disturbe me in an Intrigue, I have been long ingaged in before you, give me leave to tell you, that this is not civil, and I deire you to leave me at quiet with my Mistres, without giving me other troubles than thoe which proceed from her rigours. I am a Friend of Madam d' Olonne's, and nothing ele, anwered the Abbot, thus you have no reaon to complain of me; However, if I thought the Dicoure you have now held to me, was by the advice of People, who had a mind to bring me into trouble, I declare to you I would become your Rival from this moment. I know why I talk to you after this manner, and you may undertand me. The Abbot pretended to peak of Varde his mortal Enemy, and the Count's Friend. No, anwered the Count, I know not what you mean; but what I have to ay to you is, that being jealous, that Humour has advied me to deire you not to make me any longer o. The Abbot having given him his hand, they parted the bet Friends imaginable. Some time after
the Abbot finding Madam d' Olonne at a place where he made a Viit, he took him aide, to impart to him ome ecrets of mall moment, and the Abbot not knowing what to ay to her, told her his dipute with the Count. I am very glad, aid he to him, to ee that you, Gentlemen, dipoe of me, as if I was your own: Thus I find I am at preent the Count de Guiches, ince you have made him your declaration that you have no pretences to me. Ah! Madam, anwered the Abbot, I would not give you to any Body, if it was in my power to do it; as I love my elf better than any one in the World, I would keep you for my elf; but upon the upicions that the Count de Guiche has, that I have a Paion for you, I declare to him that I have no uch thoughts, and this betwixt you and me, Madam, becaue I trut my good Fortune, for—No, no, interrupted Madam d' Olonne, do not continue talking to me contrary to what you think; you know well enough that you are not o unhappy as you ay. The Abbot finding himelf o preed, could not forbear anwering, That he knew him better than he did himelf; that it being in her power to make King's themelves happy, he hould think his Fortune made, if he would aure him of it; and moreover, that the Promies
he had made the Count, hould not hinder him from loving her, when he hould ee any likelyhood of being beloved. This Converation ended with o many Favours from Madam d' Olonne, that the Abbot forgot that he was till in love with Madam de Chatillon, inomuch that he reolved to engage himelf without inclination with Madam d' Olonne; he fancied that by entereing the Body by Pleaures, he might diengage the Mind, whoe Interets are o interwoven: And indeed, Madam d' Olonne, whom time was very dear to, did not let the Abbot languih; but as their Correpondence could not lat long without the Counts perceiving it, he went to her Houe to make her his Complaints: Being at her Chamber door, he heard a noie, which obliged him to liten to what it was. He heard Madam d' Olonne aying a thouand kind things to ome Body, which increaing his Curioity, he looked through the Key-hole, and aw his Mitres making as tender Carees to her Husband, as if he had been a Lover. This did not a little digut him; he went home in a pet, where having taken Ink and Paper, he wrote this following Letter to Vinevil,

body.p: YOu are ignorant that I have dicovered a new Lover of Madam d' Olonne's; but what a new Lover, good God! a Lover kindly ued, a Dometick Lover: I am not able to bear with it any longer; I newly caught d' Olonne upon his Wife's knees, receiving a thouand Carees from that faithful One.

lg.l: Happy hould I my elf betide,
If the Beauty I adore
Could at length ret atisfied
With a thouand Gallants; nay more,
I am willing he hould have a Friend
If there her Lechery would end.
But he her Husband does likewie love,
'Tis this that does my Anger move.

p.hi: For in hort, my Dear, he is no Husband, he has all the Favours of Gallants; he receives other Carees beides thoe which proceed from Duty, and he receives them by day; which is a time peculiar to Lovers.

div.p:
The Count de Guiche being returned on the morrow to Madam d' Olonne's Houe, referred his reproaching her upon her Hubands account till another time, and thought it to peak then only of the Abbot Foucquett.
Madam d' Olonne being ever full of Conideration, when he was to loe a Gallant, not o much out of fear of his Vexation, as becaue he leened the number, told the Count de Guiche that he was Mater of her Conduct, that he might precribe to her what manner of life he pleaed; that if the Abbot gave him umbrage, he would not only ee him no more, but if he was willing he hould be witnes after what rate he would rattle him. The Count, who never durt have asked her o great a Sacrifice, accepted the Offers he made him: The Aignation being made to be at my Lord Croft's Houe the next day; where Madam d' Olonne having no other Company than the Count and the Abbot, poke to the lat after this manner, after having concerted all the Evening before. I deired you, Mr. Abbot, to come hither, to tell you in the preence of my Lord the Count de Guiche, that I do not love you, and that I can never love any Body but him; we were both very willing that you hould know it, that you might not plead ignorance: Not that you have hitherto carried your elf towards me otherwie than as a Friend; but as you had no deign, you have not perhaps taken notice that your Viits were omething
too frequent, and you know that that is not uually very pleaing to o amorous a Man as the Count, what confidence oever he has in his Mitres. For my part I hall pend my whole life in thinking how to pleae him: I was willing to make you this Declaration, let that you without thinking, hould bring your elf into trouble; I hall be overjoyed to have you for my Friend, but the les commerce we have together, the better it will be. 'Yes, Madam, I give you my word, aid the Abbot to her, I am very much of the Count de Guiches Opinion, I have paed through all the degrees of Jealouie, and this is not the firt time that he and I have dicoured upon this point. I know the promies I made him, and I am ure I have not broken them. 'The truth is, interrupted the Count, that I cannot complain of you; but as her Ladyhip has aid very well, that as you have no deign, you did not think you did contrary to what you promied me, and appearances are only againt you. 'Well, replyed the Abbot to him, let not this hinder you from being happy, for I give you my word that I will not. Her Ladihip deignedly but once a Month, but for incounters I cannot anwer for them; but it
is your part to take ecurities in that cae.
After a thouand Civilitiess on all ides, they parted.

It will be perhaps wondred at, that the Abbot uffered Rivals o impatiently in his Intrigues with the Dutches of Chastillon, and was o tractable with Madam d' Olonne; but the reaon is, that with the former there was love in the cae, and with the latter nothing but Debauche; and that the Body can bear with Aociates, which the Heart can never do.

Sometime after d' Olonne being informed of the ill Conduct of his Wife, reolved to end her into the Country, as well to hinder her from committing new Follies, as to tifle the Reports which her Preence daily renewed: And indeed, o oon as he was departed, there was no more thoughts of her; and a thouand other Copies of Madam d'Olonne, which Paris is full of, caued that great Original to be forgotten in a hort time.
There likewie hapned an Intrigue, which without being of the nature of Madam d' Olonne, did however uppres them for a time.

The Count Vivonne, firt Gentleman of the King's Chamber, and for whom his Majety had naturally an inclination, being retired to a Houe he had near Paris, to
pend the Eater Holy days with two of his Friends, the Abbot le Camus and Manchini this lat Cardinals Nephew, and the other one of the Kings Almoners; and having paed there three or four days, if not in a great Devotion, at leat in very innocent Pleaures, the Count of Guiche and Manicamp, being weary of Paris, went to him. As oon as the Abbot le Camus aw them, knowing them to be very diolute, he perwaded Manchini to return to Paris, and that the next day, for that the World would ay there had paed trange things amongt them: And Manchini that very evening declaring this deign, Manicamp and the Count de Guiche, propoed to Vivonne to deire Buy to come and pas two or three days without them, telling him that he was very capable to fill the place of the other two: Vivonne having given his Conent, wrote a Letter to Buy in all their names, that he was deired to quit for ome time the hurry of the World, to come to them, that they might with the les ditraction, give them elves up together to the thoughts of Eternity. But before I pas further, it is fit I decribe Vivonne and Buy.

The firt had great blew Eyes even with his Head, whoe Balls were often half
hid under his Eyelids, and contrary to his intention, made him look languihingly; he had a handome Noe, a little and full Mouth, a fine Complexion, a fine, great and fair head of Hair; He was indeed omething too fat, he had a quick Wit, and a good Fancy; but he tudyed too much how to be pleaant; he loved to peak Equivoques, and words with a double ence; and that he might be the more admired, he often made them at home and tarted them in the Companies where he came, as if they had been freh thoughts; he was quickly engaged in Friendhip with people without any dicretion; But whether he found them perons of Merit or no, he as uddenly abandoned them; What made his inclination lat longet was flattery, but it was to no purpoe for a peron to be extraordinary, if he did not admire him, he would have had no great eteem for him. As he fancyed that a igne of a good will was a nicenes for all works, he found nothing to his mind of all he aw, and uually he judged of Books without knowledg and reaon: In hort, he was o blinded with his own merit, that he aw none in any Body ele; and to peak like himelf, he had both a great deal of ufficiency, and
a great deal of inufficiency; he was Bold in War, and fearfull in Love: And yet if any body would have believed him, he had his will of all the Women he had attempted; but the truth is he had been denied by certain Ladies, who, till then had never refued any Man.

Roger de Rabutin, Count of Buy, Major General of the light Hore, had great weet Eyes, a handome Mouth, a omething hawkih Noe, an open Face, and a happy Phiiognomy, fair, clear light Hair; His Wit had delicacy and force, Gaity and Mirth; he talked well; he writ exactly and agreably; he was of a oft dipoition; But thoe, whom his Merit had caued to envy him, had netled him, inomuch that he willingly made merry with people he did not love; He was a good and regular Friend; he was brave without otentation; he loved Pleaures more than Fortune, but he loved Glory more than Pleaures: He was Gallant with all Ladies, and very civill, and the familiarity he had with his bet Friends, never made him wanting in the repect he owed them. This kind of behaviour made it thought that he had a paion for them; and it is certain that he had ever ome ence of love in all
the great intrigues he had had, he had been long in the Wars and had done good ervice, but as in this Age it was not ufficient to be of a good Family, to have Wit, Courage, and have done great Services to procure Honours, with all thee Qualities, he was got but half way of his fortune; he had not the baenes to flatter thoe people, whom Mazarine, the Soveraign Dipenour of Favours, put Confidence in, or had not been in a Condition to force them from him, by making him afraid, as mot of the Marhals of his time had done.

Now Buy, having this Letter from Vivonne, took Hors immediately, and went to his Houe: he found his friends very much dipoed to mirth, and he, not being uually a Diturber of Feats, ordered it o that their joy was altogether Compleat: and accoting them, I am very glad my Friends, aid he, to find you diengaged from the World as you are, a particular Grace from God is neceary to work out our alvation: In the hurreis of Courts, Ambition, Envy, Buckbiting, Love, and a thouand other Paions; do uually engage the best People in Crimes, which they are encapable of in uch Retreats as this, let us ave our elves then together, my friends, and as to be pleaing to God, it is neither neceary
to weep nor to dye of Hunger; let us be merry, my Friends, and make good Chear. This Sentiment being generally approved of, they prepared themelves for Hunting in the afternoon, and gave order to have Conorts of Intruments for the next day: After having hunted four or five hours, thee Gentlemen having got themelves a great tomach, eat as heartily as is imaginable: upper being ended, which had lated three hours, during which the Company had been in that Mirth which alwaies accompanies a good Concience, caued Hores to be brought to walk in the Park: where thee four Friends finding themelves at liberty, to encourage themelves to have the more contempt for the World, they propoed to rail againt all human kind; but a moment after Reflection made Buy ay that they ought to except their true Friends from that general procription; this advice having been approved of by them all, Every one demanded of the ret of the aembly Quarter for what he loved: This being done, and the the ignal given for the contempt of things here below thee good ouls begun a Canticle. You may judge that having took this Coure, all was comprehended in the Canticle, except thoe four Gentlemens
Friends, but as the Number were but mall, the Canticle was great and harp, inomuch that hould nothing be forgot, it would make a Volume: Part of the Night being pent in thee rural Pleaures, they reolved to go to ret; Wherefore they left one another very much atisfied to ee the progres they had begun to make in Devotion. Vivonne and Buy being got up earlier the next morning than the others, went into Manicamps Chamber; but not having found him, and thinking he was gone a Walking in the Park, they went into the Count de Guiches Chambers, with whom they found him in Bed: You ee My Friends, aid Manicamp to them, that I endeavour to make good ue of the things you spoke of yeterday touching the Contempt of the world, I have already Won my elf to depie the half, and I hope in hort time, except it be my particular Friends, to have no great inclination for the other; we often Compas the ame and by different methods, anwered Buy to him; for my part I do not Condemn your manners; Every one is aved after his own way; But I hall never take that coure to be happy that you do. I am amazed to hear you talk after this rate, aid Manicamp, and that Madam de Savigny has not diguted you from loving of Women; But now you talk
of Madam de Sevigny, aid Vivonne, pray you tell us why you broak off with her, for they talk differently; ome ay that you were jealous of the Count of Lude, and others that you acrificed her to Madam de Monglas; and no Body has beleived what you both have aid, that it was a reaon of interest. When I hall have made appear replyed Buy, that I have been thee ix years in love with Madam de Monglas, you will beleive that there was nothing of love in the falling out that was lat year between Madam de Sevigny and me. Ah! My Dear, interrupted Vivonne, how hould we be obliged to you, if you would take the pains to relate to us an amourous Hitory; But firt of all be pleaed to give me an account of this Madam de Sevigny; for I never aw two perons agree in their Opinions of her. What you ay is defining of her in a few words, anwered Buy, peoples opinions of her do not agree becaue he is unequall, and that one peron alone is never long enough in her favour, to oberve the change of her humour; but having known her from her Infancy I will give you a faithful relation.

div.head: The Hitory of Madam de Sevigny.
div.p:
Madam de Savigny, continued he, has uually the finet Complexion imaginable, little parkling Eyes, a flat Mouth but of a fine Colour; a lofty Forehead, a Noe only like it elf, neither long nor little, broad at the end, and the ame at the Middle, and all this which in particular is not handome, take it altogether is very agreable: he is finely haped and yet has no good Aire, he has a handome Leg, her Neck her Armes and Hands are not well formed, her hair is white and thick, he has danced well, and has till a good Ear, he has an agreable Voice, and undertands inging pretty well: as to the outide he is uch as I have decribed her, no Woman has more Wit than he, and very few have o much: he has a diverting way with her, ome ay that for a Woman of Quality her Character is omething too Wanton: In the time I aw her, I found this judgement ridiculous, and I know her Burleque under the name of gayety; not eeing her at preent, her Charmes do not dazle me; and I
grant that he is too pleaant: If a Peron has wit, and particularly of that kind of wit which will be free and merry, there needs no more than to ee her, there is nothing lot with her: She undertands you, comprehends exactly your meaning, he divines you, and uually leads you much farther than you think of going; ometimes you give her a mighty propect, the heat of pleaantry hurries her away, and under thoe Circumtances he receives with joy all libertine expreions, provided they be finely wrapt up, & keeps pace with her anwers, and thinks it for her honour to urpas all that can be aid to her. It is no trange thing that you find not much dicretion in a Peron of o much fire; thoe two things being uually incompatible, and Nature cannot work Miracles in avour of her: A brisk Fool takes more with her than a wel-bred erious Man; the gaiety of People prepoees her, that he hall be judge whether you undertand what he ays; the greatet mark of wit that can be given her, is to admire her. She loves Incene, he loves being beloved, and in order to that he loves that he may reap, he gives praie that he may receive it; he generally loves all men, of what Age, of what Birth, of what Merit, and what Profeion oever they are, from the Royal Robe to the Frock, from the Scepter to
the Inkhorn; amongt Men he loves a Lover better than a Friend, and amongt Lovers the merry more than the ad; the Melancholy flatter her Vanity, and the Brisk her Inclination; he diverts herelf with thee, and flatters herelf with an opinion that her Merit mut be great, ince he is able to make thoe others languih.

She is of a cold temper, at leat if we might believe her deceaed Husband, and it was to it that he was obliged for her Vertue as he aid; all her heat is in her will. The truth is it makes full recompence for the coldnes of her temper; I believe that Conjugal Faith has not that violence if we conider the intention; it is another thing to peak freely, I believe her Husband clear before Men, but I take him for a Cuckold before God. This fair One being willing to hare in all divertiements, has found a ure means, as he thinks, to take her Pleaures without injuring her Reputation in the leat: She has contracted Friendhip with four or five pretended Lucretia's, with whom he goes into all places imaginable; he does not o much conider what he does, as with whom he is: By thus doing, he perwades herelf that the civil Company rectifies all her actions, and for my part, I fancy that the critical Minute, which is uually found with all women when
only a Man and a Woman is together, would oonet be met with her in the midt of her Family. Sometimes he openly refues a match of publick walking to etablih herelf in regard of the World in an Opinion of great regularity, and ometime after thinking herelf afe by o publick a refual, he will make four or five matches of private walks; he has naturally a love for Pleaures; two things oblige her ometimes to deprive herelf of them, Policy and Inequality; and it was for one of thoe two reaons that he goes ometimes to a Sermon, the nex day after an Aembly. With ome uch publick Actions he thinks to prepoes all the World, and imagines that in doing a little good, and a little ill; all that can be aid is, that one producing the other, he is a Civil Woman. The Flatterers, which her little Court is full of, entertain her after another rate, they never fail to tell her, that it is impoible to reconcile Widom with the World, and Pleaure with Vertue, better than he does. To have Wit, and be of Quality, he uffers herelf to be too much dazled with the grandeurs of Court; the day the Queen has poken to her, & perhaps only asked whom he came with, he will be o tranported with joy, and a long time after he will find means to acquaint all thoe, whoe repect he has a mind to procure,
how obliginly the Queen poke to her. The King having one Evening caued her to dance, and being returned to her place, which was near me; It mut be confeed, aid he to me, that the King has great Qualities, I believe, he will obcure the Glories of all his Predecors. I could not forbear laughing in her face; and anwering her, There is no doubt to be made of it, Madam, after what he had now done for you. She was then o atisfied with his Majety, that I aw her upon the point of declaring her acknowledgment by aying, God bles the King.

There are people who only let holy things put bounds to to their friendhip, and who would do all for their Friends except offending God. Thee people call themelves Friends to the very Altars: the friendhip of Madam de Sevigny has others Limits, that fair one is only a friend as far as the pure; There was never any pretty Woman but he in the World, that dihonored her elf by ingratitude; he mut needs be much afraid of neceity, ince to avoid only the hadow of it, he is not apprehenive of hame. Thoe who would excue her ay that he has too much regard to the Counell of people, who know what hunger is, and who till remember their poverty: Whether this humour proceeds
from others or from her elf, nothing is o natural as what appears in her Oeconomy.

The greatet application that Madam de Sevigny has is to eem what he is not; ince he has tudied that Coure, he has already learnt to deceive thoe who had no great acquaintance with her: but as there are people who have intereed themelves in her more than others, they have unfortunately for her perceived and dicovered, that all is not Gold that gliters.

Madam de Sevigny is unequal to the very Balls of her Eyes and to her Eye-lids; her Eyes are of different Colours, and the Eyes being the mirours of the Soul, thee irregularities are as a mark that nature gives to thoe who come near her not to rely much upon her kindnes.

I know not if it is that her Armes are not very handome, that he is not very tender of them, or that he does not think it a favour, the thing being o general; but in hort who will may take and kis them, I fancy that it is ufficient to perwade her that there is no ill in it, that he belives they take no pleaure in it. Nothing but Cutome can now contrain her, but he will not tick to how it rather than Men well knowing, that having made modes when they pleaed Civility is no longer included in uch narrow Bounds,

This is, my Dear, the Picture of Madam de Sevigny: her etate which would have been a great help to mine and had belonged to our family, obliged my Father to deign I hould marry her; But tho I was o well acquainted with her then, as I am at preent, I did not anwer my Fathers deign, certain looe Coures I aw her take made me apprehenive; And I found her the prettyet Creature imaginable to be the Wife of another. This entiment helped me mightily from marrying her; But as he was married a hort time after me, I fell in love with her, and the tronget reaon that obliged me to make her my Mitres, was that which had hindred me from deiring to be her Huband.

As I was her near Relation, I had a very great acces to her Houe, and I aw the vexations her husband daily gave her, he complained thereof very often to me, and deired me to make him ahamed of a thouand ridiculous inclinations he had: I erved her in this very happily for ome time; but at length her Husbands nature being too trong for my Counels, after ome deliberation it came into my head to be in love with her, more through the Conveniency of the Coniuncture, than through the force of my inclination. Inomuch that Sevigny having one day told me that he had paed the
Night before the mot agreable imaginably, not only as to himelf, but the Lady with whom he had pent it. You may believe, added he, that it was not with your Coin; it was with Ninon. So much the wore for you, aid I to him; my Coin is a thouand times a finer Woman than he, and I am ure if he was not your Wife, you would make her your Mitres. All this may be, anwered he: I had no ooner left him then that I went to give him an account of all to Madam de Sevigny. This is a fine thing to brag of, aid he to me bluhing for vexation. Do not you eem to know any thing of it, anwered I, for you ee the Conequence? I think you are a fool, replyed he, to give me that advice, or that you take me for one. You would certainly be o, Madam, replyed I, if you do not pay him in his own Coin, or if you hould tell him again what I have told you: Take revenge, my fair Coin, I will go halves with you in your Vengeance; for in hort, your Interests are as dear to me as my own. Hold, good my Lord, aid he to me, I am not o vexed as you imagine: Having met with Sevigny the next day at the Court, he came to me into my Coach; as oon as he was in, I fancy, aid he to me, that you told your Coin what I yeterday acquainted you with of Ninon, becaue he has hinted omething of it to me: I, replyed I, I have not poke to her; but as he has a great deal of Wit, he has aid to me o many
things upon the point of jealouie, that he ometimes hits at the truth. Sevigny being atisfied with o good a reaon, fell to dicoure of his good fortune with the Ladies, and after having told me of a thouand advantages that there was in being in love, he concluded with telling me, that he was reolved to be o as long as he lived; and likewie that he was o at that time with Ninon, as deeply as it was poible for a man to be; that he was going to pend the Night at Saint Clouds with her, and with Vaé, who gave them a Feat, and which they laughed at together. I repeated to him what I had told him a thouand times, that tho his Wife was dicreet, he might at length, by the continuation of his actions, o provoke her, that ome welbred Man coming to fall in love with in the time he played her uch pranks, he might perhaps eek for in the weets of Love and in Vengeance, what he would not have thought of in love alone; and thereupon being parted, I went home, and wrote this Letter to his Wife.

body.p:
I Had reaon yeterday, Madam, to ditrust your imprudence, you told your Husband what I aid to you; you may eaily perceive that it is not for my own interets that I make you this reproach; for all that can happen to me is to loe his Friendhip; and you have Madam, much more to fear. I have however been o happy, as to undeceive him; moreover, Madam, he is o
perwaded that one cannot be an honet welbred man without being in love, that I depair of ever eeing you atisfied, if you do not learn to be beloved by others than himelf; but let not this allarm you, Madam, as I have begun to erve you, I will never abandon you in the Condition you are in. You know that jealouie has ome times more virtue to reclaim a heart than Charms and Merit; I advie you to make your Husband jealous, my fair Coin, and to that end I offer my elf: I have o much love for you, as to act over my former part of your Agent to him, and to acrifice my elf likewie, to render you happy; and if he mut needs ecape you, love me, my Coin, and I will help you to take your revenge on him by loving you as long as I live.

The Page I gave this Letter to, carrying it to Madam de Sevigny, found her aleep, and as he waited till he was awake, Sevigney arrived from the Country: He having known from the Page, whom I had not given intructions therein, not foreeeing that the Husband was to return o uddenly; having known, I ay, that he had a Letter to deliver from me to his Wife, asked him for it, without upecting any thing, and having read it at the ame time, he bid him be gone, and that there was no Anwer to be made to it. You may judge how I received him, I was upon the point of killing him, eeing the danger he had expoed
my Coin to, and I lept not an hour that Night. Sevigny for his part was no more at cae than I; and on the Morrow after the great reproaches he made his Wife, he forbid her to ee one, he ent me word of it, and that with a little patience all this would be hortly reconciled.

Six Months after Sevigny was killed in a Duel by the Chevalier d' Albert, his Wife eemed inconolable for his death; the reaons he had to hate him being known by all the World, they fancied that her grief was only feigned. For my part, who had more familiarity with her than others, I did not wait o long as they to peak to her of agreeable things; and preently after I made love to her, but without Ceremonies, and as if I had never done nothing ele: She made me one of her Oracle anwers, which Women make uually in the beginning, that my Paion was o much at ret, that it made me appear but little favourable, and perhaps it might be o, I know not. Tho Madam de Sevigny had no intention to love, it is impoible to have more Complaiance for her than I had in that Encounter. However, as I was her near Relation on the mot honourable ide, he made me a thouand proffers to be her Friend, and for my part, finding in her a ort of Wit which diverted me, I was not orry to be o. I aw her almot every day, I wrote to her, I made love to her after a raillying way, I fell out with my nearet Relations, to erve with my Credit and Etate thoe
perons he recommended to me. In hort, if he had occaion for all I have in the World, I hould have thought my elf extreamly obliged to her if he would have given me an occaion of aiting her. As my Friendhip was pretty like love, Madam de Sevigny was very well atisfied as long as I did not love elewhere: but Chance, as I hall tell you in the Sequel, having made me fall in love with Madam de Preey, my Coin, he did not how me o much affection as he had done, when he thought that I loved nothing but her. From time to time we had little quarrels, which indeed were made up, but which left in my heart, and I believe in here, uch eeds of Diviion for the firt occaion we hould both have, and which were even capable to imbitter indifferent things. In hort, an occaion being offered, wherein I had need of Madam de Sevigny, and wherein without her aitance I was in danger of loing my Fortune, this ungrateful Woman abandoned me, and did me in Friendhip the greatet infidelity in the World. This, my Dear, made me fall out with her, and far from acrificing her to Madam de Monglas, as was reported: This Lady whom I had long been in love with, hindred me from having all the reentment which uch an ingratitude deerved. Buy having done peaking, Vivonne told him all that was aid of the Count de Lude, and of Madam de Sevigny; Was he ever much in her favour? Before I anwer
to that, replyed Buy, it is neceary I give you an account of this Count de Lude.

He has a little ugly Face, a great head of Hair, a fine Shape; he was not born to be at; but the fear of being incommode and diagreable, makes him take uch extraordinary care to be lean, that at length he has effected his deign; his fine Shape has indeed cot him omething of his health, he has poiled his tomack in the Summer by the Dyets he has taken, and the Vinegar he has made ue of. He is active on Horeback, he dances and fences well, which is brave; he fought very well with Vardes, and they do him injury, when they upect his Valour, the ground of this lander is, that all the Sparks of his Circumtances, having ingaged themelves in the War, he would needs make one Campaign as a Voluntier; but the reaon of this was, that he is idle, and loves his pleaures; In a word, he has Courage and no Ambition, he has a oft Wit, he is pleaing with Women, he has ever been well ued by them, but does not love them long; the reaons that he is o happy in their avours are, beides the reputation he has of being ecret, his good Meen, and his being well provided for love Engagements; but that which makes him o uccesful every where is, that he cries when he will, and nothing perwades Women
o much that we are in love as tears. However whether ome michance has hapned to him in his intrigues, or that thee who Envy ay that it is his ault they have no Children, he does not much dihonour the Women he has to do with. Madam de Sevigny is one of thoe for whom he has had a love; but his paion ending then when that fair one begun to make returnes to it; Thus Cros accidents have aved her, their paions could never meet. And as he has ever viited her ince, tho without applications, it has occaioned the report that he has had to do with her. And tho it is not true, there is great likehood it was o. He has however been the weakide of Madam de Savigny, and the Man for whom he has had the mot inclination, notwithtanding the jeats he had made of it: this puts me in mind of a Song he made wherein he caues Madam de Sourdis who was with Child to peak after this manner.

l.hi: That you have both, I heard it aid,
Wherewith a Man to Charme and lure;
I mean a Man that is well bred
And for our Drudgery fit and ure;
Not like Him whom I do know,
Who never yet the Feat did do,
Nor caue the pain I undergo.

body.p: No Body in the World is more gay, has more Wit, nor a more-agreeable Wit than he; Menage being fallen in love with her, and his Extraction, his Age and his Figure obliging him to Conceal his paion as much as he could, he happened to be one day at her Houe jut as he was going out about ome buines. Her Woman not being ready to attend her, he bid Menage come into the Coach with her, and that he was not afraid people hould talke ill of it, Menage jeasted in appearance, but indeed was angry; made her anwer that he found it very evere to ee that he was not atisfred with rigours he had o long treated him with, but that he likewie depied him to the point of beleiving that nothing could be aid of her and him. Come in aid he to him, Come into my Coach; If you are angry I will make you a Viit at your own houe. As Buy finihed thee lat words, word was brought this Gentleman that the meat was upon the Table. They went to dinner, which having done with the uual merriment they went into the Park, where they were no ooner come, that they deired Buy to relate to them the tory of Madam de Monglas and his Amours, which having granted them, he begun after this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Madam de Monglas and of Buy.
div.p:
FIve years before Madam de Sevigny's and my falling out, being at Paris in the beginning of Winter, and much a friend to Feuillade and Darcy, it came into all our heads to be in love, and becaue that we were not willing that our affairs hould part us from one another, we cat our Eyes upon all the pretty Women, to ee if we could find three who were as much friends as we were, or who might come to be o: we ought a long time without meeting with what we wanted. The Ladies of Monglas, Precy and L' Ile were very much friends and very lovely; but as perhaps we hould have been troubled to have agreed upon the the Choice, and that the Merit of thoe Ladies was not o equall, that our inclinations hould Carry us to love them equally, we agreed to make three tickets of their three names, and to put them into a pure, and to keep to her that fate hould give us in drawing them. Madam de Monglas fell to Feuillade's hare Madam de L' Ile to Darcy and Madam de Precy to me: Fortune in this occaion hewed how blind he is; for he
did a favour to Feuillade which he knew not o well the value of as I did; but I was forced to be contented with what he had given me: And as I had een Madam de Monglas but five or ix times, I fancyed that the applications I was going to make to Madam de Precy would efface out of my mind the beginning of a Paion.

We thereupon made our Addrees to our Mitrees, la Feuillade having for a Fortnight or three Weeks, made love to Madam de Montglas by aiduities, reolved at length to make her a Declaration. At firt he found her a Woman, who without being too evere, eemed to him o natural an Enemy of Engagements, that he almot depaired of effecting his deigns with her, or at leat of effecting them uddenly: Yet he was not quite diencouraged, and ometime after he found her more uncertain, and in hort he preed her o much, and eemed to her o much in love, that he gave him leave to hope being beloved one day: But before I peak further, it is convenient that I decribe to you Madam de Monglas and Feuillade.

Madam de Monglas has little black parkling Eys, an agreable Mouth, a Noe omething turned up, fine white Teeth, a too lively Complexion, fine and delicate Features, and a pleaing turn of Countenance;
her Hair is black, long and thick; he is extream neat, and the Air that comes from her is purer then that he breathes; he has the finet Neck imaginable, her Arms and Hands delicately haped, he is neither great nor little, but of o eaie a hape, that it will be ever agreable, if he can ave it from the inconveniency of too much fat. Madam de Monglas has a quick and penetrating Wit, like her Complexion, even to exces; he peaks and writes with a urprizing Facility, and the mot naturally imaginable; her thoughts are often diverted elewhere in Converation, and you cannot ay to her things of o great Conequence, as to take up all her attention; he deires you ometimes to tell her omething he had then a mind to know; and as you begin your Relation, he forgets her Curioity, and the fire, he is full of, makes her interrupt you to peak of omething ele.

Madam de Monglas loves Muick and Veres, he makes very pretty ones her elf, he ings the bet of any Woman in France, of her Quality; no Body dances better than he, he fears Solitude, hè is a true Friend, even to take the part of thoe he loves with indicretion, and to the very giving them all her Etate, if they have occaion for it: She keeps their Secrets, religiouly; he knows
very well how to convere with the World; he is as Civil as a Woman of Quality ought to be: And tho he is not willing to dipleae any Body, her Civility has more of Pride than Flattery; for which reaon he does not gain hearts o oon as everal others that are more ininuating: But when they know her tedfatnes, they apply themelves much more earnetly to her.

La Feuillade is not altogether for a Man what Madam de Monglas is for a Woman; their Merits are different; he has however ome fale Charms, with which the weak are at firt dazled, but which never deceives uch People as make Reflections; he has blew lively Eyes, a great Mouth, a hort Noe, frizled Hair, and omething reddih; his Shape is pretty good, his Knees turn inwards, he has too much vivacity, he peaks much, and will alway be pleaant, but he does not always do what he has a mind to, that is to ay, with civil Perons, fancy to the populace and meanet Wits, with whom there needs no more than to have always the Mouth open to laugh orto peak; he is admirable; he has a light wit, and a hard heart, even to ingratitude; he is envious, and it is to him an affront, to be in properity; he is vain and haughty, and at his firt coming to Court, he had o often told us that he was brave, that he made
a Concience of upecting it; however at preent we make a Concience of believing it.

I have told you that Madam de Monglas being perwaded that he had a violent Paion for her, gave him hopes of being beloved. Any other than Feuillade would have made of this buines the mot agreable Intrigue imaginable; but he was lodged as I have told you, and only loved by tarts; he did enough to heat his Mitres, and too little to engage her. When I told that fair One that he loved her extreamly, becaue that Feuillade had deired me before her to peak for him in his abence, he drolled upon me, and made me oberve ome parts of his procedure, which detroyed the good Offices I would have done him. I did not fail to excue him, & not being able to ave his Conduct, I jutified at leat his intentions. We were much upon thee terms, Darcy and I with the Ladies of Precy and L' Ile, that is to ay, they were willing that we hould love them, but indeed we did our Devoir better with them, than Feuillade did with Madam de Monglas; in hort, three Months being pent, during which that fair One found herelf more engaged by the things I had aid to her in favour of Feuillade, than by the love he had hown her; this Lover was forced to go erve in the Army with a Regiment of Foot he
had. This Farewel made her enible that he had omething more kindnes in her heart for la Feuillade then he had thitherto beleived; She let him perceive omething of it; but tho it was enough to render a welbred Man happy, it could not hock the everet Vertue. Feuillade at parting made her a thouand Protetations of loving her as long as he lived, tho he hould even continue ever obtinately reolved not to make any returns to his Paion; and he and I preed her o much to give him leave to write to her, that he gave her conent.

Sometime before his departure, perceiving that the Commerce I had had for my Friend with his Mitres, had the more touched my heart for her, in making me the better acquainted with her, and that the efforts I had made to love Madam de Precy, had not cured me of my budding Paion for Madam de Mongl as. I reolved not to ee her o often, that I might not be divided between Honour and Self-love. As long as Feuillade was at Paris, his Mitres did not take notice that I did not viit her o often as I ued to do; but when he was gone, he perceived a Change in my way of living, and this put her in pain, thinking that my retreat was a ign of Feuillade's being become indifferent, and of whom likewie he had not had any tidings ince his
departure. Some days after having ent to deire me to come to her; What have I done to you, my Lord, aid he to me, that I ee you no oftner; has our Friendhip any hare in your abence? No, Madam, aid I to her, it only repects my elf. How, aid he, have I given you any reaon to Complain? No, Madam, replyed I, I can only complain of Fortune. The diorder with which I aid this, obliged her to pres me to tell her more. How! added he, do you conceal your Affairs from me, whom I let ee all I have in my heart? if it be o I hould complain of you. Ah! how preing are you, anwered I her, is it dicretion to force a Secret from ones Friend? ought not you to believe that I hould not tell you mine; ince I do not tell it you in the Circumtances I am in with you, or rather ought not you to divine it, Madam, ince—Ah! do not proceed, interrupted he, I am afraid to undertand you, I am afraid of having reaon to be angry, and of loing the eteem I have for you: No, no, Madam, aid I to her, be not afraid, I am under thoe Circumtances you are not willing I hould be, and yet I hall not be wanting in my Devoir; but ince we are come o far, I will tell you all the ret: As oon as I aw you, Madam, I found you very amiable, and every time I aw you afterwards, I thought you more beautiful than the time before; however, I was not yet enible of any thing o preing as to oblige
me to follow you up and down, but I was very much pleaed when I met with you. The firt thing which made me perceive that I was in love with you, Madam, was the trouble your abence gave me; and as I was upon the point of abandoning my elf to my Paion, and of thinking of the means of making it known to you, Darcy, Feuillade, and I, drew lots, whom we hould each of us make our addres to, of you. Madam de Precy, and Madam de L'Ile, tho what my heart was enible of for you, Madam, was yet very weak, I hould not have left to chance a thing of that Conequence, if I had not been thitherto very lucky; but in hort, my Fortune changed in that occaion, for you fell to Feuillade's hare, and I hould have gained more by having lot all my life time, than in that unhappy moment, all my Comfort was, as I have aid, that the application that I was going to make to Madam de Precy, whom I had formerly loved, would root out of my heart what was budding there, but all to no purpoe, Madam; you may judge that the Commerce that the interet of my Friend obliged me to have with you, giving me the opportunity of knowing you more particularly, and of oberving in you admirable principles for Love, I could not get rid of a Paion which your Beauty alone had produced, when Feuillade deired me to erve him; I felt omething beyond the joy we have uually in erving our Friends, and I quickly perceived
afterwards, that without deigning to betray him, I was overjoyed with being concerned in his Affairs, to have only the pleaure of eeing you more nearly, but at length it put me into terrible pains; this, Madam, has obliged me to ee you les frequently, and tho you did not take notice of it, but ince Feuillade's departure, it is above a fortnight ince I retrenched my Viits. Not but that you mut have oberved, Madam, that I have erved my Friend as I would have erved my elf, I have ometimes justified him when he was apparently Culpable, and I might if I had had a mind, have ruined him with you without eeming unfaithful, leaving it to be done by the reentment of a thouand Faults which you pretended he committed againt the Love he hewed you. But I confes that my Duty makes me uffer extreamly in eeing you, and were I out of your ight, it would spare me a great many efforts I make upon you my elf: beides, Madam, I would never have told you the reaons of my retreat, if you had not asked me them. Nothing can be more civil, my Lord, Madam de Monglas replyed to me, than what you now do; but you ought to compleat your Duty, and end your Friend an account of all things; that he may not be urprized when he hall learn perhaps by other means, that you hardly ever ee me, and that he may not to no purpoe rely on your good Offices to me: And thereupon Madam de Monglas having caued Ink and Paper to be brought, I wrote this Letter.

body.p: SInce, conidering the coure I take, the Paion I have for your Mitres neither offends my honour nor the friendhip I owe you, I may well without hame acquaint you with it; and on the contrary, I hould dihonour my elf by concealing it from you.
