Know then that I have not been able to ee Madam de Monglas any longer without loving her; and that ending for me to day to know the reaon of a Retreat, I told her he had Charmed me, but that I might not do any thing that was contrary to my duty, I would ee her no more; I thought my elf obliged to give you notice hereof; that you might take other meaures as to her, and that you might ee by the misfortune that has hapned to me of becoming your Rival, that I am not unworthy of your friendhip, nor your eteem.

Having read this Letter to Mad. de Monglas, Well, Madam, aid I to her, is this fair dealing: Ah, my Lord, replyed he, nothing can be more handome; but tho I believe you have the bet Soul in the world, it would be very difficult for you, having a hand in your Rivals Intrigues, finding a thouand reaons to do one another ill Offices, and thinking to take advantages of our fallings out, that you hould reit, conidering the paion you have for me, the temptation of breeding quarrels between us: And as you are a witty man, you would not find it difficult o to order your buines, as that one of us might eem to be faulty, and to lay upon one of us, or upon Fortune,
the michance you only were the caue of; & though your Friend hould leave off loving me through his own Incontancy, after what I know of you, I hould ever believe, if you concern your elf in our Intrigue, that it was by your Artifices: So that you have great reaon, my Lord, not to ee me any more, and tho I hould loe infinitely thereby, I cannot forbear commending that Action. After ome other Dicoures upon this Subject, I went away to dipatch the Letter I had written to Feuillade, and ten days after I received this Anwer.

YOu have done your Devoir, my Dear, and I am going to do mine; I have more confidence in you than you your elf; wherefore I deire you to continue your Viits to Madam de Monglas, and to erve me with her: When perons are o nice upon interet, as you eem to me, they are certainly incapable of treachery; but tho the Merit of Mad. de Monglas hall have o blinded you, thay you hould be no longer able to retire, I hould willingly excue you, upon the neceities there are of loving her when we know her perfectly.

div.p: With this Letter there was the following one incloed for Madam de Monglas.

body.p:
I Am not at all urprized, Madam, to learn that you have charmed my Friend, my wonder would be the greater if a wel-bred Man, who daily ees and converes with you, hould defend his heart againt o much Merit. He ends me word that he
will ee you no more, for fear he hould yield to the inclination he has for you; and for my part I deire him not to retire upon the aurance I have that he has more force than he imagins, and tho he hould not be able to reit any longer, you would not give your heart to a Traytor, having refued it to the mot faithful Lover in the world.

div.p: As oon as I had received thee two Letters I went to carry them to Madam de Monglas; but not to injure my friends whoe Mitres was very Nice, I efforced all the end of the Letter he wrote to me, from that part where he tells me, that tho the Merit of Madam de Monglas hould have o blinded me that I hould not be in a Condition to retire, upon the neceity there was of loving her: When he was well acquainted with, I was afraid he would think, as well as I, that that part was very gallant, but not very paionate. You are in the right anwered the Count de Guiche, and not only that part but both the Letters eem to me well written, but how the peron indifferent: The equel, replyed Buy, will not undeceive you.

You mut know then, continued he, that Madam de Monglas eeing this cratching, asked me what it was: I told her, that evillade poke to me of an affair of Conequence which Concerned me. Since he is deirous, aid he to me, that you continue your
Viits to me, I give you my Conent; but my Lord it is upon Condition you never peak to me of the entiments you have for me. I will not, ince you are o pleaed, replied I; Not but that I ought to peak of it, without being upected by you; for tho I love you more than I do my life, if to a knowledge my love you hould depie that of my friend, in ceaing to eteem you, I hould likewie ceae loving you; The reaon why I love you, Madam, is I aure you, not for that you are beautifull, but becaue you are alo no Cocquet. I beleive you, my Lord, aid he to me, but ince you neither deire nor pretend nothing, love me no longer; for what is a love without deires and hopes? I pretended to Nothing, aid I to her, but I hope and I deire: And what can you deire, replied he? I deire, replied I, that la Feuillade hould leave off loving you; and that it hould be indifferent to you. And in cae that hould be, aid he, hould you think to be the more happy? I know not if I hould be o, Madam aid I to her, but at leat I hould be nearer happines than I am. And thereupon I made this Song.

q.l: Since only loving you I find

l.hi: Does o much pain procure,
Me thinks you hould be omething kind,
And moan what I endure,
My Rivall does all to me dicloe,
And me his Confident has choe.

div.p: What gave me ome Comfort in the Propect of all the pains that an Amour without hopes is attended with, is that I was upon the Point of having the charge of Major General of the Hore, and that this Charge obliging me to go uddainly to the Army, honour would Cure me of an unfortunate paion. Some days before my departure, I was willing to do divert the trouble I had through the violence I ued upon my elf to Conceal my paion, and for that end I gave Madam de Savigny a very fine and extraordinary treat which you will certeinly be well pleaed to have the decription of.

Firt, igure to your elf in the Gardon of the Temple which you know, a Wood, wherein two Allyes cros in the place they meet, there was a great Oval of Trees, on whoe Branches a hundred Chrital Candleticks were tyed; on one ide of this Oval was a magnificent Theater raied, whoe Decoration well deerved to be o lighted as it was, and the lutre of a thouand Wax Candles, which the leaves of the Trees hindred from preading, rendred o bright a light in that part, that the Sun could not have given more, and for the ame reaon all about was o obcure that your Eys were of no ue: The Calmet Night imaginable; as oon as the Play was begun it was found very
pleaant: After this Divertiement, four and twenty Violins having played a Conort, played likewie Brawls, Courants, and Country Dances; the Company was not o great as it was well choen; ome danced, others looked upon the Dancers, and others, whoe Intrigues were more forward, walked with their Mitrees in the Allyes, where they ported without eeing one another. This lated till day, and as if Heaven had acted in Concert with me, the morning began to appear when the light went out: This Feat ucceeded o well, that Letters were ent to all places of the particulars of it, and it is till talked of with admiration; ome fantied that Madam de Sevigny was in that Occaion only the Pretext of Madam de Precy; but the truth was, I gave that Treat to Madam de Monglas, without daring to tell her o; and I believe that he upected, without letting me know her thoughts. In the mean time I toyed with her before people, I was ever aying to her a thouand kind things in a drolling way; and I made this Song to Sarabrand Tune, which you have certainly heard Sung.

l.hi: All thoe who ee you, do you adore,
But tho your Eyes do all things that me,
It is requir'd you hould deplore,
And of your Coynes your elf diarm.
Deigns upon your heart I laid
To loe my own, I thought was fine;

q.l: But fair Beiza, I me afraid

l.hi: Your heart is harder much than mine.

div.p:
You may judge, that having thee Sentiments for Madam de Monglas, my Addrees to Madam de Precy, were not very extraordinary: I lived with her with the greatet cae imaginable, and my little eagernes uted extreamly well with her lukewarmnes. However, when he begun to upect that I was
in love with Madam de Monglas, her Paion for me begun to be inflamed: I thereupon admired the Caprichio's of Ladies; they are vexed to loe a Lover, tho they are not willing to love them; but notwithtanding all this, what Madam de Precy did was not o urprizing, as the Actions of Madam d' Le Ile; I had made love to the firt, and it was not trange that he took ome interet therein; but for Madam d' Olonne, whom I had never hown any thing but a Friendhip to, I cannot ufficiently wonder at the coure he took, which was thus: So oon as he upected my Paion for Madam de Monglas, he ued all manner of Artififices to be perfectly informed of it; he told me ometimes after a drolling way, that I was in love with her; ometimes he poke well of her; and becaue I feared he would thereby dicover the ecret of my heart, I was ufficiently reerved in my Commendations; at other times he would peak ill of her, and for my part, being willing to acquaint Madam de Monglas, that he was not to rely upon the Friendhip of Madam de' L' Ile, having found her in a thouand other Occaions betraying Madam de Monglas, I let her talk, and gave her a very favourable Audience, to make her believe I took pleaure in it: At length, not being able one Evening to uffer the Rage he was in againt her, I gave Madam de Monglas notice of it, which • caioned their falling out; and in the Sequel, this fai • One had all the reaons imaginable to believe I had a real Paion for her.
